title: Question 8
content:
Consider the expansion of
$\left(\dfrac{x^2}{2} + \dfrac{a}{x}\right)^6$. The constant term is
$960$.
Find the possible values of $a$.
markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2.5em} 960 &= \binom{6}{4}\bigg[\dfrac{x^2}{2}\bigg]^{6-4}\bigg[\dfrac{a}{x}\bigg]^4 \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $a$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
960 &= 15\bigg[\dfrac{x^4}{4}\bigg]\bigg[\dfrac{a^4}{x^4}\bigg] \\[5pt]
960 &= \dfrac{15a^4}{4} \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{7.3em} \answer{a = \pm 4} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
$$

title: Question 13
content:
Consider the expansion of $\bigg(3x + \dfrac{p}{x}\bigg)^8$, where
$p > 0$. The coefficient of the term
in $x^4$ is equal to the coefficient of the term in $x^6$. Find $p$.
markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bigg(3x+\dfrac{p}{x}\bigg)^8 &= \sum_{k=0}^8 \binom{8}{k} \big[3x\big]^{8-k}\bigg[\dfrac{p}{x}\bigg]^k \\[3pt]
&= \sum_{k=0}^8 \binom{8}{k} \big[3^{8-k}p^k\big]\big[x^{8-2k}\big] \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence we get

$$
\begin{aligned}\big[\text{coefficient of the term in } x^4\big] &= \big[\text{coefficient of the term in } x^6\big] \\[6pt]\binom{8}{2}\big[3^{8-2}p^2\big] &= \binom{8}{1}\big[3^{8-1}p\big] \\[6pt]28\big[3^6p^2\big] &= 8\big[3^7p\big] \\[12pt]20{,}412p^2 - 17{,}496p &= 0\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{5.1em} \answer{p = \dfrac{6}{7}} 
 \approx 0.857... \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
$$

title: Question 24
content:
Given that $(1 + x)^3(1 + px)^4 = 1 + qx + 93x^2 + \dots + p^4x^7$, find
the possible values of $p$ and $q$.
markScheme:
Using Pascal triangle
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5ede89c3-3d7f-44a4-9286-c2554a148745/images/aebac82f-9280-4cf9-ad52-e4db6b3a6da0/d6143401ad9783a3554c63b7ab804d89d1d7b5f1.svg)


we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
1 + qx + 93x^2 + \dots + p^4x^7 &= (1 + x)^3(1 + px)^4 \\[6pt]
&= \big(1 + 3x + 3x^2\hspace{-0.15em} + x^3\big)\hspace{-0.15em}\big(1 + 4px + 6p^2x^2\hspace{-0.15em} + 4p^3x^3\hspace{-0.15em} + p^4x^4\big)\end{aligned}
$$

Hence we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
qx &= 4px + 3x \hspace{2.1em} \\[6pt]
q &= 4p + 3 \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em} 93x^2 &= 6p^2x^2 + 12px^2 + 3x^2 \\[6pt] 
93 &= 6p^2 + 12p + 3 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, solving the equation $(2)$ for $p$, we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
6p^2 + 12p + 3 &= 93 \\[6pt]
6p^2 + 12p - 90 &= 0 \\[6pt]
p^2 + 2p - 15 &= 0 \\[7pt]
(p + 5)(p - 3) &= 0 \\[7pt]
p &= -5,\,3\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, substituting $p = -5,\,3$ in the
equation $(1)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.1em} q &= 4(-5) + 3 \\[6pt]
&= -17\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.3em} q &= 4(3) + 3 \\[6pt]
&= 15\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore
$\answer{p = -5,\,q=-17}$
and  $\answer{p = 3,\,q=15}$

title: Question 27
content: Jack and John have decided to play a game. They will be rolling a die seven times. One roll of a die is considered as one round of the game. On each round, John agrees to pay Jack $4 if $1$ or $2$ is rolled, Jack agrees to pay John $2 if $3,4,5$ or $6$ is rolled, and who is paid wins the round. In the end, who earns money wins the game. - Show that the probability that Jack wins exactly two rounds is $\dfrac{224}{729}$. [3] - - Explain why the total number of outcomes for the results of the seven rounds is $128$. - Expand $(1 + y)^7$ and choose a suitable value of $y$ to prove that $$ 128 = \binom{7}{0} + \binom{7}{1} + \binom{7}{2} + \binom{7}{3} + \binom{7}{4} + \binom{7}{5} + \binom{7}{6} + \binom{7}{7}. \vspace{-0.5em} $$ - Give a meaning of the equality above in the context of the seven rounds.[4] - - Find the expected amount of money earned by each player in the game. - Who is expected to win the game? - Is this game fair? Justify your answer. [3] - Jack and John have decided to play the game again. - Find an expression for the probability that John wins five rounds on the first game and two rounds on the second game. Give your answer in the form $$ \binom{7}{r}^2\bigg[\frac{1}{3}\bigg]^s\bigg[\frac{2}{3}\bigg]^t \vspace{0.25em} $$ where the values of $r,s$ and $t$ are to be found. - Use your answer to (d) (i) and seven similar expressions to write down the probability that John wins a total of seven rounds over two games as the sum of eight probabilities. - Hence prove that $$ \binom{14}{7} = \sum_{k = 0}^7 \binom{7}{k}^2. \vspace{-0.5em} $$ [9] - Now Jack and John roll a die $12$ times. Let $A$ denote the number of rounds Jack wins. The expected value of $A$ can be written as $$ \mathrm{E}[A] = \sum_{r=0}^{12} r\binom{12}{r} \left[\dfrac{a^{12-r}}{b^{12}}\right] \vspace{-0.25em} $$ - Find the value of $a$ and $b$. - Differentiate the expansion of $(1 + y)^{12}$ to prove that the expected number of rolls Jack wins is $4$. [6]
markScheme:
- The probability that Jack wins a round is $\dfrac{1}{3}$.
Hence the probability that Jack wins exactly two rounds is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \binom{7}{2}\bigg[\dfrac{1}{3}\bigg]^2\bigg[\dfrac{2}{3}\bigg]^5 &= \bigg[\dfrac{7\cdot6}{2}\bigg]\bigg[\dfrac{1}{3^2}\bigg]\bigg[\dfrac{2^5}{3^5}\bigg]  \\[5pt]
  &= \dfrac{7\cdot2^5}{3^6} \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{224}{729}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - On each round, either Jack wins or John wins. Hence in seven rounds, there are $2^7 = 128$ possible outcomes.
  - Using the binomial theorem, we have

    $$
    (1 + y)^7  =  \sum_{k = 0}^7 \binom{7}{k}\hspace{0.05em}y^k \hspace{0.3em} \qref{(1)}
    $$

    Hence, if we substitute $y = 1$ in the equation $(1)$, we get

    $$
    \hspace{0.7em} \answer{128 = \sum_{k = 0}^7 \binom{7}{k}}
    $$

  - The total number of outcomes equals to the sum of the number of ways Jack can win $k$ rounds over $k = 0,1,2,\dots,7$.

- 
  - The expected amount of money earned by Jack in the game is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.2em} \mathrm{E}[\$ \text{ earned by Jack}] &= 7\left[(\$\hspace{0.05em}4)\cdot\frac{1}{3} + (-\$\hspace{0.05em}2)\cdot\frac{2}{3}\right] \\[3pt]
    &\answer{= \$\hspace{0.05em}0.00}\end{aligned}
    $$

    The expected amount of money earned by John in the game is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \mathrm{E}[\$ \text{ earned by John}] &= 7\left[(-\$\hspace{0.05em}4)\cdot\frac{1}{3} + (\$\hspace{0.05em}2)\cdot\frac{2}{3}\right] \\[3pt]
    &\answer{= \$\hspace{0.05em}0.00}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Since no one is expected to earn money in the game, no one is expected to win the game.
  - Yes, this game is fair because no one is expected to win or lose the~game.

- 
  - The probability that John wins a round is $\dfrac{2}{3}$.
Hence the probability that John wins five rounds on the first
game and two rounds on the second game is

    $$
    \left[\binom{7}{5}\bigg[\dfrac{2}{3}\bigg]^5\bigg[\dfrac{1}{3}\bigg]^2\right]\left[\binom{7}{2}\bigg[\dfrac{2}{3}\bigg]^2\bigg[\dfrac{1}{3}\bigg]^5\right]  =  \hspace{0.525em}\answer{\binom{7}{5}^2\bigg[\dfrac{2}{3}\bigg]^7\bigg[\dfrac{1}{3}\bigg]^7}
    $$

  - Similarly as in (d) (i), the probability that John wins a total
of seven rounds over two games is

    $$
    \sum_{k = 0}^7 \binom{7}{k}^2\bigg[\dfrac{2}{3}\bigg]^7\bigg[\dfrac{1}{3}\bigg]^7 = \hspace{0.525em}\answer{\bigg[\dfrac{2^7}{3^{14}}\bigg]\sum_{k = 0}^7 \binom{7}{k}^2}
    $$

  - Equivalently, the probability that John wins $7$ rounds out of
$14$ is

    $$
    \binom{14}{7}\bigg[\dfrac{2}{3}\bigg]^7\bigg[\dfrac{1}{3}\bigg]^7 = \binom{14}{7}\bigg[\dfrac{2^7}{3^{14}}\bigg] \hspace{0.75em}
    $$

    Hence we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \binom{14}{7}\bcancel{\bigg[\dfrac{2^7}{3^{14}}\bigg]} &= \bcancel{\bigg[\dfrac{2^7}{3^{14}}\bigg]}\sum_{k = 0}^7 \binom{7}{k}^2 \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{\binom{14}{7} = \sum_{k = 0}^7 \binom{7}{k}^2} \hspace{0.15em}
    $$


- 
  - The expected value of $A$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3em} \mathrm{E}[A] &= \sum_{r=0}^{12} r\binom{12}{r}\bigg[\dfrac{1}{3}\bigg]^r\bigg[\dfrac{2}{3}\bigg]^{12-r} \\[6pt]
    &=  \sum_{r=0}^{12} r\binom{12}{r}\left[\dfrac{2^{12-r}}{3^{12}}\right]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence
$\answer{a = 2}$
and  $\answer{b = 3}$
  - Using the binomial theorem, we have

    $$
    (1 + y)^{12}  =  \sum_{k = 0}^{12} \binom{12}{k}\hspace{0.05em}y^k \hspace{1.2em} \qref{(2)}
    $$

    Hence, if we differentiate both sides of the equation $(2)$, we
get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}y}\left[(1 + y)^{12}\right] &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}y}\left[\sum_{r=0}^{12} \binom{12}{r} y^{r}\right] \hspace{0.9em} \\[6pt]
    12(1 + y)^{11} &= \sum_{r=0}^{12} r\binom{12}{r} y^{r-1} \qref{(3)}\end{aligned}
    $$

    To obtain $\dfrac{3^{12}}{2^{11}}$ on the left hand side and
$2^{1-r}$ on the right hand side of
    the equation $(3)$, we need to substitute $y = \dfrac{1}{2}$ in
this equation.

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    12\left(1 + \dfrac{1}{2}\right)^{11} &= \sum_{r=0}^{12} r\binom{12}{r} \bigg[\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg]^{r-1} \hspace{0.5em} \\[6pt]
    4\cdot\dfrac{3^{12}}{2^{11}} &= \sum_{r=0}^{12} r\binom{12}{r} \big[2^{1-r}\big] \qref{(4)}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, if we rewrite the equation $(4)$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4.5em} 4 &= \sum_{r=0}^{12} r\binom{12}{r} \left[\dfrac{2^{12-r}}{3^{12}}\right] \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{4 = \mathrm{E}[A]} \hspace{1.9em}
    $$

title: Question 6
content: Let $z = 2+{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $w = 1-2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$. - Find $zw$. [2] - Illustrate $z$, $w$ and $zw$ on the same Argand diagram. [3] - Let $\theta$ be the angle between $zw$ and $w$. Find $\theta$, giving your answer in radians.[3]
markScheme:
- The product of $z$ and $w$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  zw &= (2+{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})(1-2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) \\[6pt]
  &= 2-4{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}+{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}+2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 4-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we illustrate $z$, $w$ and $zw$ on the same Argand diagram, we
have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d16706e0-5faa-41a5-804d-8aaa9391a8e7/images/ed6df27d-739a-4366-8e0a-514cde709407/96f14dbc4defd6873946ae02a45c2e643f791342.svg)


- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arg w &= \tan^{-1}((-2)/1) \\[6pt]
  &= -1.107148\dots \hspace{1.3em} \end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arg zw &= \tan^{-1}((-3)/4) \\[6pt]
  &= -0.643501\dots \hspace{1.8em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8em} \theta &= |\arg w| - |\arg zw| \\[6pt]
  &= (1.107148\dots) - (0.643501\dots) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.464}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 7
content: Let $z = re^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{6}}$ where $r \in \mathbb{R}^+$. - For $r = \sqrt{3}$, - express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in the form $a+b{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ where $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$; - draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/25f0d8f7-978f-4d4f-985d-c76b02b32a2c/images/9d23235e-6a7d-47d4-bc54-39e966a1c5c6/633c15de281dbaeb852d4279b825abc3a94854e8.svg) - Given that the integer powers of $w = \dfrac{z}{6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}$ lie on a unit circle centred at the origin, find the value of $r$. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - If we express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in Cartesian form, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4em} z^2 &= 3e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{3}} \\[10pt]
    &= 3\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos\Big(\frac{\pi}{3}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\frac{\pi}{3}\Big)\Big] \\[4pt]
    &\answer{=\dfrac{3}{2} + \dfrac{3\sqrt{3}}{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
    $$

    and

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{5.3em} z^3 &= 3\sqrt{3}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{2}} \\[10pt]
    &= 3\sqrt{3}\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}\Big)\Big] \\[10pt]
    &\answer{=0+3\sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram, we
have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/25f0d8f7-978f-4d4f-985d-c76b02b32a2c/images/ecfbb324-4335-4248-af17-503361e08908/ecdfaa8e1f1031e684d45d25638e79596842fb1a.svg)



- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}| &= \sqrt{6^2 + 2^2} \hspace{2.2em} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{40} \\[6pt]
  &= 2\sqrt{10}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the properties of modulus,
we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |w^k| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}$}]  \\[16pt]
  |w|^k &= 1 \\[17pt]
  |w| &= 1 \\[15pt]
  \hspace{3.9em} \Big|\dfrac{z}{6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\Big| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [w = z/(6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})] \\[8pt]
  \dfrac{|z|}{|6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}|} &= 1 \\[9pt]
  \dfrac{r}{2\sqrt{10}} &= 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{r = 2\sqrt{10}} \hspace{1.3em}
  $$

title: Question 8
content:
Consider the equation $\dfrac{3z}{5-z^{*}}=\text{i}$, where
$z=x+\text{i}y$ and $x$, $y \in \mathbb{R}$.
Find the value of $x$ and the value of $y$.
markScheme:
We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{3z}{5-z^{*}}&=\text{i} \\[12pt]
\dfrac{3(x+\text{i}y)}{5-(x-\text{i}y)}&= \text{i}\\[12pt]
\dfrac{3x+3y\text{i}}{5-x+y\text{i}}&=\text{i}\\[12pt]
3x+3y\text{i}&=\text{i}(5-x+y\text{i}) \\[12pt]
3x+3y\text{i}&=5\text{i}-x\text{i}-y\\[12pt]
3x+3y\text{i}&=-y+(5-x)\text{i}\end{aligned}
$$

Complex numbers can be
equal only if their real and imaginary parts are equal.
Equating the real
parts, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
3x&=-y \\[8pt]
y&=-3x \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

Equating the imaginary parts, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
3y&=5-x \\[8pt]
3(-3x)&=5-x \hspace{4em} [\hspace{0.1em}\text{by equation (1)}\hspace{0.1em}]\\[8pt]
-9x&=5-x\\[8pt]
&\hspace{-0.55em}\answer{x=-\dfrac{5}{8}}\\
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting the value of $x$ in equation $(1)$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
y&=-3\left(-\dfrac{5}{8}\right)\\[12pt]
&\hspace{-0.55em}\answer{y=\dfrac{15}{8}}\end{aligned}
$$

title: Question 9
content: Let $z = re^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{3}}$ where $r \in \mathbb{R}^+$. - For $r = \sqrt{2}$, - express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in the form $a+b{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ where $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$; - draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59a008f3-3d50-44d9-869a-42b4824709d2/images/9f941692-8f3e-4cfd-9d12-fc50abaa27ce/7e711daec273ec9c0f630b852aae229a5a09d558.svg) - Given that the integer powers of $w = (3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})\hspace{0.05em}z$ lie on a unit circle centred at the origin, find the value of $r$. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - If we express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in Cartesian form, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{5.5em} z^2 &= 2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{2\pi}{3}} \\[9pt]
    &= 2\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos\Big(\frac{2\pi}{3}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\frac{2\pi}{3}\Big)\Big] \\[9pt]
    &\answer{=-1 + \sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \end{aligned}
    $$

    and

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3em} z^3 &= 2\sqrt{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\pi} \\[9pt]
    &= 2\sqrt{2}\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos \pi + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \pi \Big] \\[9pt]
    &\answer{=-2\sqrt{2} + 0{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram, we
have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59a008f3-3d50-44d9-869a-42b4824709d2/images/b1595772-f8bb-4154-802a-3fe48a2a9de8/ee3e2d0e8670f88c39e4d0221f05849bcdba3ebd.svg)



- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}| &= \sqrt{3^2 + (-3)^2} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{18} \\[6pt]
  &= 3\sqrt{2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the properties of modulus,
we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |w^k| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}$}]  \\[13pt]
  |w|^k &= 1 \\[14pt]
  |w| &= 1 \\[14pt]
  \hspace{3.1em} |(3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})z| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [w = (3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})z] \\[14pt]
  |3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}||z| &= 1 \\[12pt]
  3\sqrt{2}\hspace{0.05em}r &= 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{r = \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{6}} \hspace{1.4em}
  $$

title: Question 10
content: The complex numbers $z$ and $w$ correspond to the points A and B as shown on the diagram below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9662101a-846e-4330-acd8-a3cb1cce180f/images/03879786-889a-461a-8062-d630c448493e/0c46fa70e78de8ef6fa11a8d28566cc1742d4a83.svg) - Find the exact value of $|z - w|$. [2] - - Find the exact perimeter of triangle AOB. - Find the exact area of triangle AOB. [4]
markScheme:
- Using the cosine rule, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} |z - w|^2 &= |z|^2 + |w|^2 - 2|z||w|\cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right) \\[6pt]
  |z - w|^2 &= 5^2 + 5^2 - 2(5)(5)\hspace{-0.1em} \bigg[\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\bigg] \\[10pt]
  |z - w|^2 &= 25(2-\sqrt{3}) \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{|z - w| = \textstyle 5\sqrt{2-\sqrt{3}}} \hspace{4.3em}
  $$

- 
  - The exact perimeter of triangle AOB is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \text{perimeter} &= |z| + |w| + |z-w| \\[6pt]
    &= 5 + 5 + \textstyle 5\sqrt{2-\sqrt{3}} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \textstyle 10 + 5\sqrt{2-\sqrt{3}}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - The exact area of triangle AOB is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.1em} \text{area} &= \dfrac{1}{2}|z||w|\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right) \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{1}{2}(5)(5)\hspace{-0.1em}\bigg[\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg] \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{25}{4}}\end{aligned}
    $$

title: Question 17
content: Consider the complex numbers $u = 1 + 2 {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $v = 2 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$. - Given that $\dfrac{1}{u} + \dfrac{1}{v} = \dfrac{6\sqrt{2}}{w}$, express $w$ in the form $a + b {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ where $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$. [4] - Find $w^\ast$ and express it in the form $re^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\theta}$. [3]
markScheme:
- Substituting $u = 1+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and
$v = 2+{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ in the given equation,
we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.1em} \dfrac{6\sqrt{2}}{w} &= \dfrac{1}{u} + \dfrac{1}{v} \\[6pt]
  &=  \dfrac{1}{1 + 2 {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} + \dfrac{1}{2 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \\[6pt]
  &=  \dfrac{1}{1 + 2 {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\cdot\dfrac{1 - 2 {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{1 - 2 {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} + \dfrac{1}{2 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\cdot\dfrac{2 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{2 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1 - 2 {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{5} + \dfrac{2 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{5} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{3 - 3 {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{5} \qref{(1)} \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $w$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  w &= \dfrac{30\sqrt{2}}{3 - 3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \\[5pt]
  &= \dfrac{10\sqrt{2}}{1 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\cdot\dfrac{1 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}{1 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \\[5pt]
  &= \dfrac{10\sqrt{2}\hspace{0.05em}(1 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})}{2} \\[11pt]
  &= 5\sqrt{2}\hspace{0.05em}(1 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) \\[14pt]
  &\answer{= 5\sqrt{2} + 5\sqrt{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \hspace{4em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The conjugate of $w$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.1em} w^\ast &= 5\sqrt{2} - 5\sqrt{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\\[8pt]
  &= 10\bigg[\dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2} - \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\bigg] \\[6pt]
  &= 10\left[\cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4}\right) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{4}\right)\right] \\[9pt]
  &= 10\left[\cos\left(-\dfrac{\pi}{4}\right) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\left(-\dfrac{\pi}{4}\right)\right] \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 10\hspace{0.05em}e^{-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{4}}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by Euler's formula}]\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 21

title: Question 24
content:
On an Argand diagram, the complex numbers
$z_1 = 2 + 2\sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$,
$z_2 = 1 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $z_3 = z_1z_2$ are
represented by the vertices of a triangle.
The exact area of the triangle can be expressed in the form
$p+\sqrt{q}$. Find the value of $p$ and of $q$.
markScheme:
We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.1em} |z_1| &= \textstyle \sqrt{2^2+(2\sqrt{3})^2} \\[6pt]
&= 4 \\[12pt]
|z_2| &= \sqrt{1^2+(-1)^2} \\[6pt]
&= \sqrt{2}\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\arg z_1 &= \tan^{-1}(2\sqrt{3}/2) \\[6pt]
&= \ang{60} \\[12pt]
\arg z_2 &= \tan^{-1}(-1/1) \\[6pt]
&= -\ang{45}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, using the property of modulus, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
|z_3| &= |z_1z_2| \\[6pt]
&= |z_1||z_2| \hspace{2.1em} \\[6pt]
&= 4\sqrt{2}\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\arg z_3 &= \arg(z_1z_2) \\[6pt]
&= \arg z_1 + \arg z_2 \\[6pt]
&= \ang{15}\end{aligned}
$$

If we sketch the triangle whose vertices represent $z_1$, $z_2$ and
$z_3$ on an Argand diagram, we have
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9d725016-9066-4b8c-ac95-c47814030441/images/d6a47e5a-26b2-4956-8144-2fd2e75f4f4d/e1e467a933ff283d4afc5581ecd27d102258be6b.svg)


Hence the area of the triangle ABC is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text{area(A\^{B}C)} &= \text{area(A\^{O}C)} + \text{area(B\^{O}C)} - \text{area(A\^{O}B)} \\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{1}{2}(4)(4\sqrt{2})\sin \ang{45} + \dfrac{1}{2}(\sqrt{2})(4\sqrt{2})\sin \ang{60} - \dfrac{1}{2}(4)(\sqrt{2})\sin \left(\ang{60}+\ang{45}\right) \\[10pt]
&= (8\sqrt{2})\left(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right) + 4 \left(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right) - 2\sqrt{2}\,\Big(\sin \left(\ang{60}\right)\cos(\ang{45})+\cos(\ang{60})\sin(\ang{45}) \Big)\\[8pt]
&= 8+2\sqrt{3}-2\sqrt{2}\left(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\dfrac{1}{2}\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)\\[10pt]
&= 7+\sqrt{3}\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore,
$\answer{p=7}$and$\answer{q=3}$

title: Question 28
content: - Solve $2\sin(x+\ang{120}) = \sqrt{3}\cos(x + \ang{60})$, for $x \in [0,\ang{180}]$. [5] - Show that $\sin \ang{75} + \cos \ang{75} = \dfrac{\sqrt{6}}{2}$. [3] - Let $z = \sin 4\theta + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(1 - \cos 4\theta)$, for $z \in \mathbb{C}$, $\theta \in [0,\ang{90}]$. - Find the modulus and argument of $z$ in terms of $\theta$. - Hence find the fourth roots of $z$ in modulus-argument form. [14]
markScheme:
- Using the compound angle formulas for sine and cosine, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2\sin(x+\ang{120}) &= \sqrt{3}\cos(x + \ang{60}) \\[12pt]
  2\hspace{0.05em}(\sin x \cos \ang{120} + \cos x \sin \ang{120}) &= \sqrt{3}\hspace{0.05em}(\cos x \cos \ang{60} - \sin x \sin \ang{60}) \\[12pt]
  2\sin x \hspace{0.05em}(- \sin \ang{30}) + 2\cos x \cos \ang{30} &= \sqrt{3}\cos x \cos \ang{60} - \sqrt{3}\sin x \sin \ang{60} \\[6pt]
  2\sin x \bigg(\hspace{-0.3em}-\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg) + 2\cos x\bigg(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\bigg) &= \sqrt{3}\cos x \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg) - \sqrt{3}\sin x \bigg(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\bigg)  \\[6pt]
  -2\sin x + 2\sqrt{3}\cos x &= \sqrt{3}\cos x - 3\sin x  \\[12pt]
  \sin x &= -\sqrt{3}\cos x \\[12pt]
  \tan x &= -\sqrt{3} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.2em} \answer{x = \ang{120}}
  $$

- Using the compound angle formula for sine, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (\sin \ang{75} + \cos \ang{75})^2 &= (\sin \ang{75})^2 + (\cos \ang{75})^2 + 2\sin \ang{75}\cos \ang{75}\\[12pt]
  &= 1 + \sin \left(\ang{75} + \ang{75}\right) \\[12pt]
  &= 1 + \cos \ang{60} \\[7pt]
  &= 1 + \dfrac{1}{2} \\[4pt]
  &= \dfrac{6}{4} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, if we take the
square root of both sides of the equality $(1)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{\sin \ang{75} + \cos \ang{75} = \dfrac{\sqrt{6}}{2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - The modulus of $z$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3em} |z| &= \left[(\sin 4\theta)^2  + (1 - \cos 4 \theta)^2\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\[5pt]
    &= \left[(\sin 4\theta)^2 + (\cos 4 \theta)^2 + 1 - 2\cos 4\theta\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\[5pt]
    &= \left[2 - 2\cos 4 \theta\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\[5pt]
    &= \left[2\hspace{0.05em}(1 - \cos 4\theta)\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\[5pt]
    &= \left[2\big(1-(1 - 2\hspace{0.05em}(\sin 2\theta)^2\big)\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \hspace{2em} [\text{by double-angle formula}] \\[5pt]
    &= \left[4\hspace{0.05em}(\sin 2\theta)^2\right]^{\frac{1}{2}} \\[10pt]
    &= 2\hspace{0.05em}|\hspace{-0.05em}\sin 2\theta\hspace{0.05em}| \\[10pt]
    &\answer{= 2\sin 2\theta} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $\sin 2\theta \geq 0$ for $\theta \in [0,\ang{90}]$}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Using the double-angle formulas for sine and cosine, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \tan \left(\arg z\right) &= \dfrac{1- \cos 4\theta}{\sin 4\theta} \hspace{2.4em} \\[4pt]
    &= \dfrac{1-\big[1 - 2(\sin 2\theta)^2\big]}{2\sin 2\theta\cos 2\theta} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{\sin 2\theta}{\cos 2\theta} \\[10pt]
    &= \tan 2\theta\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the argument of $z$ is
$\answer{\arg z = 2 \theta}$
  - Hence, using part (c) and de Moivre's theorem, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3em} z^\frac{1}{4} &= (2\sin 2\theta \mathop{\mathrm{cis}}2\theta)^\frac{1}{4} \\[12pt]
    &= \sqrt[4]{2\sin 2\theta}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\left(\dfrac{2\theta + 2k\pi}{4}\right) \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \sqrt[4]{2\sin 2\theta}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\left(\dfrac{\theta + k\pi}{2}\right)}\end{aligned}
    $$

    for $k = 0,1,2,3$.

title: Question 32
content: Consider the complex numbers $z_1=-1+\sqrt{3}ai$ and $z_2=\dfrac{\sqrt{3}(a-1)}{3a+1}+i$. Where $a \in \mathbb{R}, a\neq-\tfrac{1}{3}$. Another complex number is defined such that $z_3=\dfrac{z_2}{z_1}$. Let $\theta=\arg({z_3})$, where $-\pi \leq \theta \leq \pi$. - Show that $\tan{\theta}$ is constant for $a \in \mathbb{R}, a\neq-\tfrac{1}{3}$. [4] - Hence, find the two possible values of $\theta$ and the intervals of $a$ for which they will occur.[3]

title: Question 35
content: The complex number $z$ is a root of the equation $|z+4i|=|z-10i|$. - Show that the imaginary part of $z$ is $3$.[2] - Let $\omega_1$ and $\omega_2$ be two possible values of $z$ such that $|z|=6$. - If $\omega_1$ is in the first quadrant sketch both solutions on an Argand diagram. - Hence find the arguments of $\omega_1$ and $\omega_2$.[4] A different complex number, $v$, is defined such that $$ \begin{align*} v&=\dfrac{\omega_{1}^k\,\omega_2}{-i} \end{align*} $$ Where $k$ is a real number that can take any value in the interval $-10\leq k \leq 10$ and $-\pi \leq \arg{(-i)} \leq \pi$. - - Find $\arg{(v)}$ in terms of $k$ and $\pi$. - Hence find all possible values of $k$ such that $v$ is a real number.[8]

title: Question 1
content:
Find the number of ways in which twelve different baseball cards can be
given to Emily, Harry, John and Olivia, if Emily is to receive $5$
cards, Harry is to receive $3$ cards, John is to receive $3$ cards and
Olivia is to receive $1$ card (in that order).
markScheme:
Choose $5$ from $12$ baseball cards for Emily, then choose $3$ from $7$
remaining cards for Harry, then choose $3$ from $4$ remaining cards for
John and give the last card which is left to Olivia.
Hence the total number of ways is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\binom{12}{5}\binom{7}{3}\binom{4}{3}\binom{1}{1} &= \dfrac{12!}{5!\cdot\cancel{7!}}\cdot\dfrac{\cancel{7!}}{3!\cdot\cancel{4!}}\cdot\dfrac{\cancel{4!}}{3!\cdot1!}\cdot 1  \\[6pt]
&= \dfrac{12!}{5!\cdot3!\cdot3!\cdot1!} \\[15pt]
&\answer{= 110\hspace{0.15em}880}\end{aligned}
$$

title: Question 5
content: In an art museum, there are 8 different paintings by Picasso, 5 different paintings by Van Gogh, and 3 different paintings by Rembrandt. The curator of the museum wants to hold an exhibition in a hall that can only display a maximum of 7 paintings at a time. The curator wants to include at least two paintings from each artist in the exhibition. - Given that 7 paintings will be displayed, determine how many ways they can be selected. [4] - Find the probability that more Rembrandt paintings will be selected than Picasso paintings or Van Gogh paintings. [2]
markScheme:
- Given that there must be at least 2 paintings by each artist, there are three cases to consider:
  
  - 3 Picasso, 2 Van Gogh, 2 Rembrandt
  - 2 Picasso, 3 Van Gogh, 2 Rembrandt
  - 2 Picasso, 2 Van Gogh, 3 Rembrandt

  Let $k_1$ be the total number of combinations from option 1, $k_2$ the total from option 2 and $k_3$ the total from option 3.
  In the first case, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k_1 &= {}^8C_3 \times {}^5C_2 \times {}^3C_2 \\[6pt]
      &= 1680
  \end{align*}
  $$

  In the second case, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k_2 &= {}^8C_2 \times {}^5C_3 \times {}^3C_2 \\[6pt]
      &= 840
  \end{align*}
  $$

  In the third case, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k_3 &= {}^8C_2 \times {}^5C_2 \times {}^3C_3 \\[6pt]
      &= 280
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Overall, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k &= k_1 + k_2 + k_3 \\[6pt]
      &= 1680 + 840 + 280
  \end{align*}
  $$

  In total there are $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{2800}\hspace{0.525em}$ ways in which the paintings can be selected.
- For there to be more Rembrandt paintings selected than Picasso or Van Gogh, there must be 3 by Rembrandt, 2 by Picasso and 2 by Van Gogh. From part (a), there are 280 possible combinations that fit this criteria, and 2800 combinations overall. Therefore

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      \mathrm{P}(3\mathrm{R}\,2\mathrm{P}\,2\mathrm{V}) &= \dfrac{280}{2800} \\[10pt]
  &\hspace{-5.5em}\tcbhighmath{\mathrm{P}(3\mathrm{R}\,2\mathrm{P}\,2\mathrm{V}) = \dfrac{1}{10}} 
  \end{align*}
  $$

title: Question 7
content: An arts and crafts store is offering a special package on personalized keychains. The store has a selection of $6$ distinct types of charms. Customers can personalize their keychains with between 1 and $3$ distinct charms from the selection mentioned above. Determine how many ways a customer can personalize a keychain if - The order of the selections is important. [3] - The order of the selections is not important. [3]
markScheme:
- A customer can select either 1, 2 or 3 unique charms, all of which are different. Therefore we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k &= {}^6P_1 + {}^6P_2 + {}^6P_3
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Using the formula for permutations, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k &= \dfrac{6!}{5!} + \dfrac{6!}{4!} + \dfrac{6!}{3!} \\[10pt]
      &= \dfrac{6\times\cancel{5!}}{\cancel{5!}} + \dfrac{6\times5\times\cancel{4!}}{\cancel{4!}} + \dfrac{6\times5\times4\times\cancel{3!}}{\cancel{3!}} \\[10pt]
      &= 6 + 30 + 120
  \end{align*}
  $$

  In total there are $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{156}\hspace{0.525em}$ ways in which a customer can personalize a keychain if the order is important.
- A customer can select either 1, 2 or 3 unique charms, all of which are different. Therefore we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k &= {}^6C_1 + {}^6C_2 + {}^6C_3
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Using the formula for combinations, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      k &= \dfrac{6!}{1!5!} + \dfrac{6!}{2!4!} + \dfrac{6!}{3!3!} \\[10pt]
      &= \dfrac{6\times\cancel{5!}}{1\times\cancel{5!}} + \dfrac{6\times5\times\cancel{4!}}{2\times\cancel{4!}} + \dfrac{\cancel{6}\times5\times4\times\cancel{3!}}{\cancel{3!}\times\cancel{3!}} \\[10pt]
      &= 6 + 15 + 20
  \end{align*}
  $$

  In total there are $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{41}\hspace{0.525em}$ ways in which a customer can personalize a keychain if the order is not important.

title: Question 8
content: Ten students are to be arranged in a new chemistry lab. The chemistry lab is set out in two rows of five desks as shown in the following diagram. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e170a0fe-977c-4bd7-b87e-9e1886187985/images/f8681d28-d470-4e1b-8738-223f58a3ae4c/42b953ec648c17bd92a6ba9406f0ca05241c501c.svg) - Find the number of ways the ten students may be arranged in the lab. [1] Two of the students, Hugo and Leo, were noticed to talk to each other during previous lab sessions. - Find the number of ways the students may be arranged if Hugo and Leo must sit so that one is directly behind the other. For example, Desk $1$ and Desk $6$. [2] - Find the number of ways the students may be arranged if Hugo and Leo must not sit next to each other in the same row. [3]
markScheme:
- $\answer{10! = 3\hspace{0.15em}628\hspace{0.15em}800}$
- Hugo and Leo may be arranged in the lab first in $(5)(2) = 10$ ways
so that one is directly behind the other. Then the rest of the
students may be arranged in $8! = 40\hspace{0.15em}320$ ways.
In this case, the number of ways the ten students may be
arranged in the lab is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{(10)(8!) = 403\hspace{0.15em}200}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Hugo and Leo may be arranged in the lab first in $(8)(2) = 16$ ways
so that they sit next to each other. Then the rest of the students
may be arranged in $8! = 40\hspace{0.15em}320$ ways.
In this case, the number of ways the ten students may be
arranged in the lab is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (16)(8!) = 645\hspace{0.15em}120\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, if Hugo and
Leo must not sit next to each other, the number of ways is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.5em} 10! - (16)(8!) &= 3\hspace{0.15em}628\hspace{0.15em}800 - 645\hspace{0.15em}120 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2\hspace{0.15em}983\hspace{0.15em}680}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 10
content: Julie works at a book store and has nine books to display on the main shelf of the store. Four of the books are non-fiction and five are fiction. Each book is different. Determine the number of possible ways Julie can line up the nine books on the main shelf, given that - the non-fiction books should stand together; [2] - the non-fiction books should stand together on either end; [2] - the non-fiction books should stand together and do not stand on either end. [2]
markScheme:
- Let $k$ be the number of possible ways that the 9 books can be
ordered with the 4 non-fiction books being arranged together.
  To find $k$, we can consider a two steps process. First, we can
treat the 4 non-fiction books as a single item, and so there are
$6!$ permutations of the 5 fiction books and the block of
non-fiction books. After that, we can arrange the non-fiction books
in $4!$ different ways. Thus, by the multiplication rule, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  k &= 6!\times 4! \hspace{0.3em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 17\hspace{0.15em}280}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let $m$ be the number of possible ways that the non-fiction books
can stand together on either end. There are $2$ ways in which the
non-fiction books can be on one end, and $5!$ ways to order the
fiction books next to them. Finally, the non-fiction books can be
ordered in $4!$ ways. Hence, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m &=  2\times 5! \times 4! \hspace{1.0em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 5\hspace{0.15em}760}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let $n$ be the number of possible ways that the non-fiction books
can stand together and do not stand on either end.
  Using the results found in parts (a)-(b), we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.8em} n &= k-m \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 11\hspace{0.15em}520}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 12
content: Sophia and Zoe compete in a freestyle swimming race where there are no tied finishes and there is a total of $10$ competitors. Find the total number of possible ways in which the ten swimmers can finish if Zoe finishes - in the position immediately after Sophia;[2] - in any position after Sophia.[3]
markScheme:
- Let $n$ be the number of possible ways in which Zoe finishes
immediately after Sophia. To find $n$, we can treat Sophia followed
by Zoe as one item. We can then order the 9 items in any order.
Hence, the value of $n$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  n &= 9! \\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.3em}\answer{= 362\hspace{0.15em}880}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let $m$ be the number of possible ways in which Zoe finishes in any
position after Sophia. Hence, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m &= \binom{9}{1}\times8!+\binom{8}{1}\times8!+\binom{7}{1}\times8!+\binom{6}{1}\times8!+\binom{5}{1}\times8!+.....\binom{1}{1}\times8! \\[10pt]
  &= (9 + 8 + 7 + 6 + 5 + \cdots + 1) \times 8!\\[12pt]
  &\hspace{0.3em}\answer{= 1\hspace{0.15em}814\hspace{0.15em}400}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 16
content: Sophie and Ella play a game. They each have five cards showing roman numerals I, V, X, L, C. Sophie lays her cards face up on the table in order I, V, X, L, C as shown in the following diagram. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39c87612-7c32-40b7-9150-936d318630c0/images/b4f00281-ba44-44fd-8ba3-6710c101617e/8c2117a8771870dcd1b10ba85dbc123753724df8.svg) Ella shuffles her cards and lays them face down on the table. She then turns them over one by one to see if her card matches with Sophie's card directly above. Sophie wins if no matches occur; otherwise Ella wins. - Show that the probability that Sophie wins the game is $\dfrac{11}{30}$.[6] Sophie and Ella repeat their game so that they play a total of $90$ times. Let the discrete random variable $X$ represent the number of times Sophie wins. - Determine: - the mean of $X$; - the variance of $X$. [5]
markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39c87612-7c32-40b7-9150-936d318630c0/images/ee00d62c-2dc7-40c3-89ae-032bc78b6386/5557f2430f2b6a1d2ae2b382374192f4abd645a4.svg)


  There are $5! = 120$ possible ways to lay down five cards in order
on the table.
  Hence the number of possible ways to lay down five cards with no
matches is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  120 - (45+20+10+0+1) &= 120 - 76 \hspace{1.8em} \\[8pt]
  &= 44\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the probability that Sophie wins the game
is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} \mathrm{P}(\text{Sophie wins}) &= \dfrac{44}{120} \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{11}{30}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - Since $X \sim \mathrm{B}(90,11/30)$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \mathrm{E}[X] &= np \\[6pt]
    &= 90\times\dfrac{11}{30} \hspace{3.3em} \\[8pt]
    &\answer{= 33}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the formula for the variance of
$X \sim \mathrm{B}(90,11/30)$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.75em} \mathrm{Var}(X) &= np(1-p) \\[6pt]
    &= 90\times\dfrac{11}{30}\times\hspace{-0.1em}\bigg[1 - \dfrac{11}{30}\bigg] \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 20.9}\end{aligned}
    $$

title: Question 17
content:
The barcode strings of a new product are created from four letters A, B,
C, D and ten digits $0,1,2,\dots,9$. No three of the letters may be
written consecutively in a barcode string. There is no restriction on
the order in which the numbers can be written.
Find the number of different barcode strings that can be created.
markScheme:
Let $n$ denote the number of different barcode strings that can be
created. Four letters and ten digits can be ordered in $14!$ ways. To
find $n$, subtract from $14!$ the number of possible barcode strings
with exactly three and exactly four consecutive letters.

$$
\begin{aligned}
n &= 14! - 10!\times\binom{4}{3}\times3!\times\binom{11}{2}\times2! - 10!\times\binom{4}{4}\times4!\times\binom{11}{1}\times1! \\[6pt]
&= 14! - 10!\times4\times3!\times11\times10 - 10!\times4!\times11 \\[12pt]
&\answer{= 7.66\times10^{10}}\end{aligned}
$$

title: Question 1
content: Let $f(x) = 0.2e^{x+2} - 4$, for $-3 \leq x \leq 2$. - On the following grid, sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. [3] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/4d1c7bf9-8d2a-4f7a-945e-f582b73039b2/219ede634589aee775d4d590dd79b30ff5c63914.svg) - Find the coordinates of: - the $x$-intercept; - the $y$-intercept. [2] The graph of $f$ is reflected in the $x$-axis, then translated 1 unit in the direction of the positive $x$-axis and 2 units in the direction of the positive $y$-axis to obtain the graph of a function $g$. - Find $g(x)$. [2]
markScheme:
- If we draw the graph of $y = f(x)$ for $-3 \leq x \leq 2$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/0c8cb343-6319-4c4b-bd01-6881dfb5c2ff/a0ce7feb5a9182c2d088b3711cfba75a324b8033.svg)


- 
  - Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.2em} 0.2e^{x+2} - 4 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &\approx 0.996 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are
$\answer{(0.996,0)}$
  - Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
    &= 0.2e^{0+2} - 4 \hspace{0.4em} \\[7pt]
    &\approx -2.52\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the
$y$-intercept are
$\answer{(0,-2.52)}$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.5em} g(x) &= -f(x-1) + 2 \\[6pt]
  &= -\big[0.2e^{(x-1)+2} - 4\big] + 2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -0.2e^{x+1} + 6}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 4
content: A population of goldfish decreases exponentially. The size of the population, $P$, after $t$ days is modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} P(t) = 8000\times2^{-t} + 100, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0. \\ \end{aligned} $$ - Write down the exact size of the initial population. [1] - Find the size of the population after $5$ days. [2] - Calculate the time it will take for the size of the population to decrease to $120$.[2] The population will stabilize when it reaches a size of $n$. - Write down the value of $n$. [1]
markScheme:
- Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 0$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.7em} P(0) &= 8000\times2^0 + 100 \\[6pt]
  &= 8000 + 100 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 8100}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 5$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.3em} P(5) &= 8000\times2^{-5} + 100 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 350}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $P(t) = 120$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  8000\times2^{-t} + 100 &= 120 \hspace{6.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{14.2em} \answer{t = 8.64 \text{ days}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11.9em} \lim_{t\rightarrow\infty} P(t) &= \lim_{t\rightarrow\infty} \big[8000\times2^{-t} + 100\big] \\[6pt]
  &= 0+100 \hspace{2em} [\text{since $2^{-t} \rightarrow 0$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$}] \\[10pt]
  &= 100 \text{ fish}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the value of $n$ is
$\answer{100}$

title: Question 10
content: A population of $50$ hamsters was introduced to a new town. One month later, the number of hamsters was $62$. The number of hamsters, $P$, can be modelled by the function $$ P(t) = 50\times b^t,\hspace{0.5em} t\geq0, \\[3pt] $$ where $t$ is the time, in months, since the hamsters were introduced to the town. - Find the value of $b$. [2] - Calculate the number of hamsters in the town after $6$ months. [2] A wildlife specialist estimates that the town has enough water and food to support a maximum population of $2000$ hamsters. - Calculate the number of months it takes for the hamster population to reach this maximum. [2]
markScheme:
- Solving the equation $P(1) = 62$ for $b$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  50\times b^1 &= 62 \hspace{2.1em} \\[6pt]
  b &= \dfrac{62}{50} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.4em}\answer{b = 1.24}
  $$

- Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 6$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.2em} P(6) &= 50\times(1.24)^6 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 182}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $P(t) = 2000$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  50\times(1.24)^t &= 2000 \hspace{3.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{15.6em} \answer{t \approx 17.1 \text{ months}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

title: Question 11
content: - Write the expression $4\ln 2 - \ln 8$ in the form of $\ln k$, where $k \in \mathbb{Z}$. [3] - Hence, or otherwise, solve $4\ln 2 - \ln 8 = -\ln (2x)$. [3]
markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  4\ln 2 - \ln 8 &= \ln \big(2^4\big) - \ln 8 \\[12pt]
  &= \ln 16 - \ln 8 \\[6pt] 
  &= \ln\Big(\dfrac{16}{8}\Big) \\[9pt]
  & \answer{= \ln 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Replacing the left hand side of the equation with $\ln 2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  4\ln 2 - \ln 8 &= -\ln (2x) \\[12pt]
  \ln 2  &= -\ln(2x) \hspace{2.2em} \\[12pt]
  -\ln 2 &= \ln(2x) \\[12pt]
  \ln \big(2^{-1}\big) &= \ln(2x) \\[12pt]
  2x &= 2^{-1} \\[12pt]
  2x &= \dfrac 1 2 \\[13pt]
  &\hspace{-0.525em} \answer{x = \dfrac{1}{4}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 13
content:
Find the value(s) of $x$ when
$27^{x+2} = \left(\dfrac{1}{9}\right)^{2x+4}$.
markScheme:
Using the properties of exponents, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
27^{x+2} &= \left(\dfrac{1}{9}\right)^{2x+4} \\[3pt]
\left(3^3\right)^{x+2} &= \left(\dfrac{1}{3^2}\right)^{2x+4} \\[9pt]
3^{3x+6} &= 3^{-4x-8} \\[16pt]
3x+6 &= -4x-8 \\[16pt]
7x &= -14 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\answer{x = -2} \hspace{0.5em}
$$

title: Question 18
content: Solve $\log_6(x) + \log_6(x-5) = 2$, for $x > 5$.
markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log_6(x) + \log_6(x-5) &= 2 \\[6pt]
\log_6(x(x-5)) &= \log_6 6^2 \\[5pt]
\log_6 (x^2-5x) &= \log_6 36 \\[5pt]
x^2-5x &= 36 \\[5pt]
x^2 - 5x - 36 &= 0 \\[6pt]
(x + 4)(x - 9) &= 0 \\[6pt]
x - 9 &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x + 4 > 0$}]\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\answer{x = 9} \hspace{1.6em}
$$

title: Question 20
content:
Find the values of $x$ when
$25^{x^2-2x} = \left(\dfrac{1}{125}\right)^{4x+2}$.
markScheme:
Using the properties of exponents, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
25^{x^2-2x} &= \left(\dfrac{1}{125}\right)^{4x+2} \\[3pt]
\left(5^2\right)^{x^2-2x} &= \left(\dfrac{1}{5^3}\right)^{4x+2} \\[9pt]
5^{2x^2-4x} &= 5^{-12x-6} \\[16pt]
2x^2 - 4x &= -12x-6 \\[16pt]
x^2 - 2x &= -6x - 3 \\[16pt]
x^2 + 4x + 3 &= 0 \\[17pt]
(x+3)(x+1) &= 0 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{3.45em}\answer{x = -3,-1}
$$

title: Question 21
content: Solve the equation $9^x + 2\cdot3^{x+1} = 1$.
markScheme:
If we substitute $y = 3^x$ in the equation $9^x + 2\cdot3^{x+1} = 1$, we
have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(3^x\right)^2 + 6\cdot3^x - 1 &= 0 \\[6pt]
y^2 + 6y - 1 &= 0\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, using the quadratic formula, we
get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{13em} y &= \dfrac{-6 + \sqrt{6^2 - 4(1)(-1)}}{2(1)} \hspace{2em} [\text{since $y = 3^x > 0$}] \\[4pt]
&= \dfrac{-6 + 2\sqrt{10}}{2} \\[12pt]
&= -3 + \sqrt{10}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, using the properties of
logarithms, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
3^x &= -3 + \sqrt{10} \hspace{2.6em} \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{0.3em} \answer{x = \log_3(-3 + \sqrt{10})}
$$

title: Question 23
content: Consider the function $f(x)=\dfrac{e^x-e^{-x}}{2}$, $x\in \mathbb{R}$. - Show that $f$ is an odd function. [2] Now, consider the function $g$ given by $g(x) = \dfrac{x^4+2}{2x}$ , $x\in \mathbb{R}, x \neq 0$. - By considering the graph of $y=f(x)-g(x)$, solve $f(x)>g(x)$ for $x\in \mathbb{R}$. [4]
markScheme:
- Evaluating $f(-x)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  f(-x) &= \dfrac{e^{-x}-e^{-(-x)}}{2} \\[10pt]
  &= \dfrac{e^{-x}-e^{x}}{2} \\[10pt]
  &= -\dfrac{e^{x}-e^{-x}}{2} \\[10pt]
  &= -f(x) \\[-8pt]
  \end{align*}
  $$

  $\answer{\text{Therefore, $f(x)$ is an odd function}}$
- If $f(x)-g(x)>0$, then $f(x)>g(x)$. Using G.D.C., we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cf76b687-c4cf-4f02-a51c-0d0d8c929218/images/0ae01be6-8c62-4dff-b5d4-bdc1c895874f/AA930a.PNG)


  We see that $f(x)-g(x)>0$ for $-4.55 < x < 0$ and $x > 4.55$.
  Therefore $f(x)>g(x)$ over the intervals
$\answer{-4.55 < x < 0 \text{ and } x > 4.55}$

title: Question 24
content:
Solve the equation $15^{4a} = 81^{a+2}$ for $a$. Express your answer in
terms of $\ln 3$ and $\ln 5$.
markScheme:
Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
15^{4a} &= 81^{a+2} \\[10pt]
(3\cdot5)^{4a} &= 3^{4(a+2)} \\[9pt]
\cancel{3^{4a}}\hspace{-0.15em}\cdot5^{4a} &= \cancel{3^{4a}}\hspace{-0.15em}\cdot3^8 \\[10pt]
5^{4a} &= 3^8 \\[10pt]
\ln 5^{4a} &= \ln 3^8 \\[10pt]
4a \ln 5 &= 8\ln 3\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{2.25em}\answer{a = \dfrac{2\ln 3}{\ln 5}}
$$

title: Question 29
content:
Solve the equation $14^{6x} = 64^{x+3}$ for $x$. Express your answer in
terms of $\ln 2$ and $\ln 7$.
markScheme:
Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
14^{6x} &= 64^{x+3} \\[10pt]
(2\cdot7)^{6x} &= 2^{6(x+3)} \\[9pt]
\cancel{2^{6x}}\hspace{-0.15em}\cdot7^{6x} &= \cancel{2^{6x}}\hspace{-0.15em}\cdot2^{18} \\[10pt]
7^{6x} &= 2^{18} \\[10pt]
\ln 7^{6x} &= \ln 2^{18} \\[10pt]
6x\ln 7 &= 18\ln 2\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{1.9em}\answer{x = \dfrac{3\ln 2}{\ln 7}}
$$

title: Question 35
content: - Show that $3\log_{a^3}x = \log_a x$ where $a$, $x\in \mathbb{R}^+$. [2] It is given that $\log_2 y + \log_8 4x^2 + \log_8 2x = 0$. - Express $y$ in terms of $x$. Give your answer in the form $y=bx^c$ where $b$, $c$ are constants.[6] The region $R$, is bounded by the graph of the function found in part (b), the $x$-axis, and the lines $x=1$ and $x=k$ where $k>1$. The area of $R$ is $\dfrac{3}{2}$. - Find the value of $k$.[4]
markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  3\log_{a^3}x &= 3 \, \dfrac{\log_a x}{\log_a a^3} \\[10pt]
  &= \cancel{3} \,\dfrac{\log_a x}{\cancel{3}} \\[10pt]
  &\answer{=\log_a x}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of logarithms and part (a), we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_2 y + \log_8 4x^2 + \log_8 2x  &= 0  \\[8pt]
  \log_2 y + \log_8 8x^3 &= 0 \\[8pt]
  \log_2 y + 3 \log_8 2x &= 0 \\[8pt]
  \log_2 y +  \log_2 2x &= 0  \\[8pt]
  \log_2 y &= -\log_2 2x   \\[8pt]
  \log_2 y &= \log_2 (2x)^{-1}   \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-0.5em}\answer{y = \dfrac{1}{2}x^{-1}} \end{aligned}
  $$

- First we find the area of $R$ using integration, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{Area of }R &= \int_1^k \dfrac{1}{2} \hspace{0.05em}x^{-1} \, \mathrm{d} x \\[8pt]
  &= \left[ \dfrac{1}{2}\ln x \right]_1^k \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{2}\ln k \\[8pt]
  \dfrac{3}{2}&= \dfrac{1}{2}\ln k \\[8pt]
  \ln k &= 3 \\[8pt]
  & \hspace{-0.5em}\answer{ k = e^3 } \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 37
content: The brightness of a star can be measured in terms of its apparent magnitude as seen from Earth. The apparent magnitude $M$ of a star is given by the formula $$ M = -2.5 \log\left(\dfrac{F}{F_0}\right) $$ where $F$ is the observed flux density and $F_0$ is a reference flux density. - Solve for $F$ in terms of $M$.[2] - Suppose that $M(F_1)=1$ and $M(F_6)=6$. Find the value of $\dfrac{F_1}{F_6}$.[1] Now, let's look at the difference in magnitude of two starts. Suppose that star $1$ has observed flux density of $F_1$ with magnitude $M_1$ while star $2$ has flux density $F_2$ with magnitude $M_2$. - Find an expression for the difference in magnitude $M_2-M_1$.[2] The apparent magnitude of the sun is $M_s=-26.8$ and the apparent magnitude of the full moon is $M_m=-12.7$. - Their brightness factor is $\dfrac{F_s}{F_m}=10^{\tfrac{a}{b}}$ where $a,b \in \mathbb{Q^+}$. Find $a$ and $b$.[2]

title: Question 38
content: Consider the function defined by $f(x) = (2x-6)\ln(x+3)+x$ for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $x>p$. - Find the value of $p$. [2] - Find an expression for $f'(x)$. [3] The graph of $y=f(x)$ has no points of inflexion. - Determine if the graph of $y=f(x)$ is concave down or concave up over its domain. [3] The function $g$ is defined by $g(x)=3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{x+3}\right)+x$, for $x\in \mathbb{R}$, $x>-3$. - Find an expression for $g'(x)$. [4] - Find the horizontal and vertical asymptotes of $g'(x)$.[2] - Find the exact value of the minimum of $y=g(x)$.[3] - Solve $f(x)-3$.[5]
markScheme:
- Due to the natural log term, $x+3>0$. Therefore
$\answer{ p=-3}$
- Differentiating $f$ with respect to $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\big[(2x-6)\ln(x+3)+x\big] \\[10pt]
  & \answer{=\dfrac{2x-6}{x+3}+2\ln(x+3)+1} \end{aligned}
  $$

- Differentiating $f'$ with respect to $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f''(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\left[\dfrac{2x-6}{x+3}+2\ln(x+3)+1\right] \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{(x+3)(2)-(2x-6)}{\left(x+3\right)^2} + \dfrac{2}{x+3} \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{2x+18}{(x+3)^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, over $x>-3$, we have $f''(x)>0$. Therefore,
$\answer{f \text{ is concave up}}$
- Differentiating $g$ with respect to $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\left[3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{x+3}\right)+x\right] \\[12pt]
  &=3(x+3)\left(-\dfrac{1}{(x+3)^2}\right)+1  \\[8pt]
  & =\dfrac{-3}{x+3}+1 \\[10pt] 
  & \answer{=\dfrac{x}{x+3}} \end{aligned}
  $$

- The denominator of $g'$ is zero when $x=-3$.
Hence,
$\answer{\text{the line \(x=-3\) is a vertical asymptote of the graph of \(y=g'(x)\)}}$
If we take the limit as $x$ tends to $\infty$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x\to \infty} g'(x) &= \lim_{x\to \infty} \dfrac{x}{x+3}%\cdot \dfrac{\dfrac{1}{x}}{\dfrac{1}{x}}
  \\[8pt]
  & = \lim_{x\to \infty} \dfrac{1}{1+\dfrac{3}{x}\rule[-2mm]{0pt}{7.2mm}} \\[6pt]
  & = 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence,
$\answer{\text{the line \(y=1\) is a horizontal asymptote of the graph of \(y=g'(x)\)}}$
- From part (d) we obtain a stationary point at $x=0$.
The second derivative of $g$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g''(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} \left[\dfrac{x}{x+3}\right] \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{3}{(x+3)^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, $g''(x)>0$ which implies that at $x=0$ the function $g$
reaches its minimum. Therefore, the minimum value of $g$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g(0) &= 3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)+0 \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= -3\ln(3)} \end{aligned}
  $$

- Using logarithm properties, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &< g(x) \\[12pt]
  (2x-6)\ln(x+3) + x &< 3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{x+3}\right) + x \\[12pt]
  (2x-6)\ln(x+3) &< -3\ln(x+3) \\[15pt]
  (2x-3)\ln(x+3) &< 0\end{aligned}
  $$

  Thus, we have two options

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \left[2x-3<0\enskip\&\enskip \ln(x+3)>0\right] &\text{  or  } \left[2x-3>0 \enskip\&\enskip \ln(x+3)<0\right] \\[12pt]
  \left[x<1.5\enskip\&\enskip\ln(x+3)>0\right]&\text{ or } \left[x>1.5\enskip\&\enskip \ln(x+3)<0\right] \\[12pt]
  x < 1.5\enskip & \&\enskip 1<x+3 \hspace{2em}[\text{since }\ln(x+3)>0\text{ for }x>1.5]\\[8pt]
  -2 <& \hspace{0.1em}x < 1.5 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore,
$f(x)<g(x)$ over $\answer{-2 <  x < 1.5}$

title: Question 1
content: Find the value of each of the following, giving your answer as an integer. - $\log_{10} 100$. [2] - $\log_{10} 50 + \log_{10} 2$. [2] - $\log_{10} 4 - \log_{10} 40$. [3]
markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.65em} \log_{10} 100 &= \log_{10} \big(10^2\big) \\[6pt]
  &= 2\log_{10} 10 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of logarithms, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_{10} 50 + \log_{10} 2 &= \log_{10} (50\cdot2) \hspace{2.4em} \\[6pt]
  &= \log_{10} 100 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of logarithms, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_{10} 4 - \log_{10} 40 &= \log_{10} \bigg(\dfrac{4}{40}\bigg) \hspace{2.5em} \\[3pt]
  &= \log_{10} \bigg(\dfrac{1}{10}\bigg) \\[9pt]
  &= \log_{10} \big(10^{-1}\big) \\[16pt]
  &= (-1) \log_{10} 10 \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= -1}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 3
content: Let $\log_2 a = p$, $\log_2 b = q$, $\log_2 c = r$. Write down the following expressions in terms of $p$, $q$ and $r$. - $\log_2\Big(\dfrac{ab}{c}\Big)$ [2] - $\log_2\Big(\dfrac{a^2c}{b^3}\Big)$ [2] - $\log_a b$ [2]

title: Question 4
content:
Consider
$a = \log_{63}64\times\log_{62}63\times\log_{61}62\times\dots\times\log_{2}3$.
Given that $a\in\mathbb{Z}$, find the value of $a$.
markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
a &= \log_{63}64\times\log_{62}63\times\log_{61}62\times\dots\times\log_{2}3 \\[11pt]
&= \dfrac{\log64}{\bcancel{\log63}}\times\dfrac{\bcancel{\log63}}{\bcancel{\log62}}\times\dfrac{\bcancel{\log62}}{\bcancel{\log61}}\times\cdots\times\dfrac{\bcancel{\log3}}{\log2} \\[6pt]
&=  \dfrac{\log64}{\log2} \\[6pt]
&=  \dfrac{\log2^6}{\log2} \\[6pt]
&=  \dfrac{6\hspace{0.05em}\cancel{\log2}}{\cancel{\log2}} \\[12pt]
&\answer{= 6}\end{aligned}
$$

title: Question 15
markScheme:
- 
  - Using the properties of logarithms, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \log_2 8 &= \log_2 \big(2^3\big) \\[6pt]
    &= 3\log_2 2 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 3}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the properties of logarithms, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \log_5\Big(\dfrac{1}{25}\Big) &= \log_5\big(5^{-2}\big) \hspace{1.4em} \\[6pt]

  - Using the properties of logarithms, we have

    \begin{aligned}

- Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_2 8 + \log_5\Big(\dfrac{1}{25}\Big) + \log_9 3 &= \log_{16} x \hspace{6.5em} \\[6pt]

  \hspace{2.7em} \answer{x = 64}

title: Question 16
markScheme:

title: Question 18
content:
Find the values of $x$ when
$25^{x^2-2x} = \left(\dfrac{1}{125}\right)^{4x+2}$.
markScheme:
Using the properties of exponents, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
25^{x^2-2x} &= \left(\dfrac{1}{125}\right)^{4x+2} \\[3pt]
\left(5^2\right)^{x^2-2x} &= \left(\dfrac{1}{5^3}\right)^{4x+2} \\[9pt]
5^{2x^2-4x} &= 5^{-12x-6} \\[16pt]
2x^2 - 4x &= -12x-6 \\[16pt]
x^2 - 2x &= -6x - 3 \\[16pt]
x^2 + 4x + 3 &= 0 \\[17pt]
(x+3)(x+1) &= 0 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{3.45em}\answer{x = -3,-1}
$$

title: Question 20
content: Find the value of - $\log_5 75 - \log_5 3$; [2] - $25^{\log_5 8}$. [4]
markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_5 75 - \log_5 3 &= \log_5\Big(\dfrac{75}{3}\Big) \hspace{3.1em} \\[6pt]
  &= \log_5 25 \\[10pt]
  &= \log_5\big(5^2\big) \\[12pt]
  &= 2 \log_5 5 \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  25^{\log_5 8} &= \big(5^2\big)^{\log_5 8} \\[8pt]
  &= 5^{2\log_5 8} \\[6pt]
  &= 5^{\log_5 (8^2)} \\[7pt]
  &= 5^{\log_5 64} \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= 64}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 21
content: Find the value of - $\log_7 98 - \log_7 2$; [2] - $49^{\log_7 6}$. [4]
markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_7 98 - \log_7 2 &= \log_7\Big(\dfrac{98}{2}\Big) \hspace{3.1em} \\[6pt]
  &= \log_7 49 \\[10pt]
  &= \log_7\big(7^2\big) \\[12pt]
  &= 2 \log_7 7 \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  49^{\log_7 6} &= \big(7^2\big)^{\log_7 6} \\[8pt]
  &= 7^{2\log_7 6} \\[6pt]
  &= 7^{\log_7 (6^2)} \\[7pt]
  &= 7^{\log_7 36} \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= 36}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 22
content:
Solve the equation $15^{4a} = 81^{a+2}$ for $a$. Express your answer in
terms of $\ln 3$ and $\ln 5$.
markScheme:
Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
15^{4a} &= 81^{a+2} \\[10pt]
(3\cdot5)^{4a} &= 3^{4(a+2)} \\[9pt]
\cancel{3^{4a}}\hspace{-0.15em}\cdot5^{4a} &= \cancel{3^{4a}}\hspace{-0.15em}\cdot3^8 \\[10pt]
5^{4a} &= 3^8 \\[10pt]
\ln 5^{4a} &= \ln 3^8 \\[10pt]
4a \ln 5 &= 8\ln 3\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{2.25em}\answer{a = \dfrac{2\ln 3}{\ln 5}}
$$

title: Question 24
content:
Solve $\log_{\sqrt{3}}(\sin x) - \log_{\sqrt{3}}(\cos x) = 1$, for
$0 < x < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$.
markScheme:
We have
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7f375b41-33b9-4587-922a-02c76aab5a0d/images/2bc01858-af34-4ec1-bef2-2c845c61c439/eea28ea6dc26969cf5c008612e865ae5046a04ef.svg)


Using the properties of logarithms and the right triangle above, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{4.1em} \log_{\sqrt{3}}(\sin x) - \log_{\sqrt{3}}(\cos x) &= 1 \\[6pt]
\log_{\sqrt{3}}\hspace{-0.2em}\Big(\dfrac{\sin x}{\cos x}\Big) &= 1 \\[8pt]
\log_{\sqrt{3}}(\tan x) &= 1 \\[10pt]
\tan x &= \sqrt{3} \\[10pt]
x &= \dfrac{\pi}{3} + n\pi \hspace{2.3em} [\text{for $n \in \mathbb{Z}$}] \\[6pt]
x &= \dfrac{\pi}{3} + 0 \hspace{3em} [\text{since $0 < x < \pi\hspace{-0.05em}/2$}] \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{2.1em} \answer{x = \dfrac{\pi}{3}}
$$

title: Question 25
content:
Solve the equation $14^{6x} = 64^{x+3}$ for $x$. Express your answer in
terms of $\ln 2$ and $\ln 7$.
markScheme:
Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
14^{6x} &= 64^{x+3} \\[10pt]
(2\cdot7)^{6x} &= 2^{6(x+3)} \\[9pt]
\cancel{2^{6x}}\hspace{-0.15em}\cdot7^{6x} &= \cancel{2^{6x}}\hspace{-0.15em}\cdot2^{18} \\[10pt]
7^{6x} &= 2^{18} \\[10pt]
\ln 7^{6x} &= \ln 2^{18} \\[10pt]
6x\ln 7 &= 18\ln 2\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{1.9em}\answer{x = \dfrac{3\ln 2}{\ln 7}}
$$

title: Question 26
content: The first three terms of a geometric sequence are $\ln x^9$, $\ln x^3$, $\ln x$, for $x > 0$. - Find the common ratio. [3] - Hence, solve $\displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^\infty 3^{3-k}\ln x = 27$. [5]
markScheme:
- We have $u_1 = 9\ln x$ and $u_2 = 3\ln x$.
Hence the common ratio is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{3\ln x}{9\ln x} \hspace{2.9em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{1}{3}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The $n$th term of the geometric sequence is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_n &= u_1r^{n-1} \\[6pt]
  &= 9\ln x\bigg(\dfrac{1}{3}\bigg)^{n-1} \\[8pt]
  &= 3^{3-n}\ln x\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_{\infty} &= \sum_{k=1}^\infty 3^{3-k}\ln x \hspace{1em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $S_{\infty} = 27$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{u_1}{1-r} &= 27 \hspace{2.8em} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{9\ln x}{1 - 1/3} &= 27 \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{27\ln x}{3-1} &= 27 \\[12pt]
  \ln x &= 2 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{x = e^2}
  $$

title: Question 27
content: The equation $e^{2x} - 12e^x = -32$ has two solutions, $x_1$ and $x_2$. - Find the value of $x_1$ and the value of $x_2$.[5] A second equation, $2\left(\log_{\,9}x\right)\left(\log_{\,3}x\right) - 6\log_{\,9}x - 2\log_{\,3}x = -6$, also has two solutions, $x_3$ and $x_4$. - - Show that this second equation can be expressed as $$ \begin{align*} \left(\log_{\,3}x\right)^2 -5\log_{\,3}x + 6 = 0 \end{align*} $$ - Hence find the value of $x_3$ and the value of $x_4$. [7] - Given that $x_1 + x_2 = a(x_3 + x_4)$, find the value of $a$. Give your answer in the form $b\ln c$, where $b,c \in \mathbb{R}$.[3]
markScheme:
- The equation can be written as a quadratic in $e^x$:

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \left(e^x\right)^2 - 12e^x + 32 = 0
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The equation can then be factorised:

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \left(e^x - 4\right)\left(e^x - 8\right) = 0
  \end{align*}
  $$

  From the first bracket, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  e^x - 4 &= 0 \\[8pt]
  e^x &= 4 \\[8pt]
  x &= \ln 4 \\[8pt]
  &= 2\ln 2
  \end{align*}
  $$

  And from the second bracket,

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  e^x - 8 &= 0 \\[8pt]
  e^x &= 8 \\[8pt]
  x &= \ln 8 \\[8pt]
  &= 3\ln 2
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Hence, $x_1 = 2\ln 2$ and $x_2 = 3\ln 2$.
- 
  - We are asked to write the second equation in terms of $\log_{\,3}x$, and currently the equation is expressed in terms of $\log_{\,3}x$ and $\log_{\,9}x$. Using the formula for changing the base, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \log_{\,9}x &= \dfrac{\log_{\,3}x}{\log_{\,3}9} \\[8pt]
    &= \dfrac{\log_{\,3}x}{\log_{\,3}3^2} \\[8pt]
    &= \dfrac{\log_{\,3}x}{2\log_{\,3}3} \\[8pt]
    \log_{\,9}x &= \dfrac{1}{2}\log_{\,3}x
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Substituting this expression into our original equation, we get

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    2\left(\log_{\,9}x\right)\left(\log_{\,3}x\right) - 6\log_{\,9}x - 2\log_{\,3}x &= -6 \\[8pt]
    2\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\left(\log_{\,3}x\right)\left(\log_{\,3}x\right) - 6\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\left(\log_{\,3}x\right) - 2\log_{\,3}x &= -6 \\[8pt]
    &\hspace{-10em}\tcbhighmath{\left(\log_{\,3}x\right)^2 - 5\log_{\,3}x + 6 = 0}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - The equation can be factorised as follows:

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \left(\log_{\,3}x - 2\right)\left(\log_{\,3}x - 3\right) = 0
    \end{align*}
    $$

    From the first bracket, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \log_{\,3}x - 2 &= 0 \\[8pt]
    \log_{\,3}x &= 2 \\[8pt]
    x &= 9
    \end{align*}
    $$

    And from the second bracket,

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \log_{\,3}x - 3 &= 0 \\[8pt]
    \log_{\,3}x &= 3 \\[8pt]
    x &= 27
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence, $x_3 = 9$ and $x_4 = 27$.

- We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  x_1 + x_2 &= a(x_3 + x_4) \\[8pt]
  2\ln 2 + 3\ln 2 &= a(9+27) \\[8pt]
  5\ln 2 &= 36a \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-0.5em}\tcbhighmath{a = \dfrac{5}{36}\ln 2}
  \end{align*}
  $$

title: Question 28
markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
a + b\log_4 7 + 60\log_{8} 14 &= 0 \\[13pt]
a + \dfrac{b\ln 7}{2\ln 2} + \dfrac{60\ln 14}{3\ln 2} &= 0 \\[9pt]
a\ln 2 + \dfrac{b}{2}\ln 7 + 20\ln (2\cdot7) &= 0 \\[9pt]
a\ln 2 + \dfrac{b}{2}\ln 7 + 20(\ln 2 + \ln 7) &= 0 \\[9pt]
(a + 20)\ln 2 + \bigg(\dfrac{b}{2}+20\bigg)\ln 7 &= 0\end{aligned}
$$

Hence we get
$\answer{a = -20}$
and  $\answer{b = -40}$

title: Question 29
content: The first three terms of an infinite sequence, in order, are $2\ln x,\,\, q\ln x,\,\, \ln \sqrt{x}\,\,\, \text{ where $\ x > 0$.} $ First consider the case in which the series is geometric. - - Find the possible values of $q$. - Hence or otherwise, show that the series is convergent. [3] - Given that $q>0$ and $S_\infty=8\ln{3}$, find the value of $x$. [3] Now suppose that the series is arithmetic. - - Show that $q=\dfrac{5}{4}$. - Write down the common difference in the form $m\ln x$, where $m \in \mathbb{Q}$. [4] - Given that the sum of the first $n$ terms of the sequence is $\ln \sqrt{x^5}$, find the value of $n$. [8]
markScheme:
- 
  - Given that the sequence is geometric, we have for the common ratio

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[8pt]
    &= \dfrac{q\ln x}{2\ln x} \\[8pt]
    &= \dfrac{q}{2}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Similarly,

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    r &= \dfrac{u_3}{u_2} \\[8pt]
    \dfrac{q}{2} &= \dfrac{\ln \sqrt{x}}{q\ln x} \\[8pt]
    \dfrac{q}{2} &= \dfrac{\frac{1}{2}\ln {x}}{q\ln x} \\[8pt]
    \dfrac{q}{2} &= \dfrac{1}{2q} \\[8pt]
    q^2 &= 1 \\[8pt]
    &\hspace{-0.49em}\tcbhighmath{q= \pm 1}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - Given that $r=\dfrac{q}{2}$, and $q= \pm 1$, we have $r = \pm \dfrac{1}{2}$. Hence $|r| < 1$.
    $\answer{\text{In both cases the series converges.}}$

- Given that $q>0$, $r = \dfrac{1}{2}$.
  Using the formula for the sum of an infinite geometric sequence, we~get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  S_{\infty} &= \dfrac{u_1}{1-r} \\[10pt]
  8 \ln 3 &= \dfrac{2\ln x}{1-\frac{1}{2}} \\[10pt]
  8 \ln 3 &= \dfrac{2\ln x}{\frac{1}{2}} \\[10pt]
  8 \ln 3 &= 4\ln x \\[10pt]
  2\ln 3 &= \ln x \\[10pt]
  \ln 3^2 &= \ln x \\[10pt]
  \ln 9 &= \ln x \\[10pt]
  &\hspace{-0.54em}\tcbhighmath{x = 9} 
  \end{align*}
  $$

- 
  - First we find the common difference $d$ as follows

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    d &= u_2 - u_1\\[10pt]
    d &= q\ln x - 2\ln x \\[10pt]
    d &= (q-2)\ln x
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Similarly,

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    d &= u_3 - u_2\\[10pt]
    (q-2)\ln x &= \ln\sqrt{x} - q\ln x \\[8pt]
    (q-2)\ln x &= \ln x^{1/2} - q\ln x \\[8pt]
    (q-2)\ln x &=  \dfrac{1}{2}\ln x - q\ln x \\[8pt]
    (q-2)\ln x &= \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2} - q\bigg)\ln x \\[8pt]
    q-2 &= \dfrac{1}{2}-q \\[8pt]
    2q &= \dfrac{1}{2} + 2 \\[8pt]
    2q &= \dfrac{5}{2} \\[8pt]
    &\hspace{-0.535em}\tcbhighmath{q = \dfrac{5}{4}}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - Given that $d = (q-2)\ln x$ and $q = \dfrac{5}{4}$, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    d &= \left(\dfrac{5}{4}-2\right)\ln x \\[10pt]
    &\hspace{-0.535em}\tcbhighmath{d = -\dfrac{3}{4}\ln x}
    \end{align*}
    $$


- Using the formula for the sum of $n$ terms of an arithmetic sequence, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  S_n &= \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d) \\[8pt]
  \ln \sqrt{x^5} &= \dfrac{n}{2}\left(2\hspace{0.1em}(2\ln x) + (n-1)\left(-\dfrac{3}{4}\ln x \right)\right) \\[8pt]
  \ln x^{5/2} &= \dfrac{n}{2}\left(\left(4\ln x + \left(-\dfrac{3}{4}\right)(n-1)\ln x\right) \right) \\[8pt]
  \dfrac{5}{2}\ln x &= \dfrac{n}{2}\left(4 - \dfrac{3(n-1)}{4}\right)\ln x \\[8pt]
  5 &= n\left(4 - \dfrac{3(n-1)}{4}\right) \\[8pt]
  5 &= 4n - \dfrac{3n(n-1)}{4} \\[8pt]
  20 &= 16n - 3n(n-1) \\[8pt]
  20 &= 16n - 3n^2 + 3n \\[8pt]
  3n^2 -19n +20 &= 0 \\[8pt]
  3n^2 -15n -4n +20 &= 0 \\[8pt]
  3n(n-5) - 4(n-5) &= 0 \\[8pt]
  (3n-4)(n-5) &= 0
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The solutions to the quadratic equation are $n=\dfrac{4}{3}$ and $n=5$.
  Since $n$ must be an integer, we have $\answer{n = 5}$

title: Question 30
content: - Show that $\log_{16}(\cos 2x + 7) = \log_4 \sqrt{\cos 2x + 7}$. [3] - Hence, or otherwise, solve $\log_4(\sqrt{10}\cos x) = \log_{16}(\cos 2x + 7)$, for $0 < x < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$.[5]
markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_{16}(\cos 2x + 7) &= \dfrac{\log_4(\cos 2x + 7)}{\log_4 16} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{\log_4(\cos 2x + 7)}{2\log_4 4} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{2}\log_4(\cos 2x + 7) \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= \log_4 \textstyle \sqrt{\cos 2x + 7}} \hspace{2.3em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the double angle formula for cosine, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.75em} \log_4(\textstyle \sqrt{10}\cos x) &= \log_{16}(\cos 2x + 7) \\[14pt]
  \log_4(\textstyle \sqrt{10}\cos x) &= \log_4 \textstyle \sqrt{\cos 2x + 7} \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \hspace{3em} \\[14pt]
  \textstyle \sqrt{10}\cos x &= \textstyle \sqrt{\cos 2x + 7} \\[14pt]
  10\cos^2 x &= \cos 2x + 7 \\[14pt]
  10\cos^2 x &= (2\cos^2x - 1) + 7  \\[14pt]
  8\cos^2 x &= 6 \\[10pt]
  \cos^2 x &= \dfrac{3}{4} \\[4pt]
  \cos x &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $0 < x < \pi\hspace{-0.05em}/2$}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{x = \dfrac{\pi}{6}} \hspace{1em}
  $$

title: Question 32
content: The arithmetic sequence has the sixth term of $u_6=\ln{2}$ and the eighth term of $u_8=\frac{3}{2}\ln{4}$. - - Show the common difference is $\ln2$. - Find $u_1$. - Hence, show that the sum of $n$ terms is given by $S_n=\left(n^2-9n\right)\ln {\sqrt{2}} $. Where $n \in \mathbb{Z^+}$. [5] A new function, $f(x)$, is formed using $S_n$ with the discrete variable $n$ being replaced with the continuous variable $x$, such that $x \in \mathbb{R}$. Hence $f(x)=\left(x^2-9x\right)\ln {\sqrt{2}}$. - - Write down the equation of the axis of symmetry of $f(x)$. - Sketch $f(x)$ on the grid below, identify the axis of symmetry and any axis intercepts. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b47a175-7f1f-4e12-9580-54726bb82f90/images/5f674790-b5af-473c-b8d4-3f746b96c744/q1037.png) - Hence or otherwise, find the minimum value of $S_n$ in the form $a\ln b$. Where $a,b \in \mathbb{Z}$ [5] Consider the linear function $g(x)=(6-3x)\ln {\sqrt 2}$. - - Solve $f(x)=g(x)$. - Hence, solve the inequality $f(x)[5]
markScheme:
- 
  - As the sequence is arithmetic we can write $u_8=u_6+2d$. Hence

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        \tfrac{3}{2}\ln{4}&=\ln{2}+2d \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\\
        2d&=3\ln{(\sqrt{4})}-\ln2\\
        2d&=2\ln{2}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]

title: Question 33
markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we rewrite the given equations as
follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log_5 5 + \log_5 x^2 &= \log_5 7y \\[6pt]
\log_5 5x^2 &= \log_5 7y \\[6pt]
5x^2 &= 7y \hspace{5em}{(1)} \\[6pt]
\log_7 (6x-1) &= 1 + \log_7 y \\[6pt]
\hspace{2.75em} \log_7 (6x-1) &= \log_7 7 + \log_7 y \\[6pt]
\log_7 (6x-1) &= \log_7 7y \\[6pt]
6x - 1 &= 7y \hspace{5em}{(2)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the equations (1) and (2),
we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
5x^2 &= 6x - 1 \\[6pt]
5x^2 - 6x + 1 &= 0 \\[6pt]
(5x - 1)(x - 1) &= 0 \\[6pt]
x &= \dfrac{1}{5} \text{ or } x = 1 \end{aligned}
$$

Substituting $x = \dfrac{1}{5}$ into the equation (1), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
5 \left(\dfrac{1}{5} \right)^2 &= 7y \hspace{2.5em}\\[12pt] 
\dfrac{1}{5} &= 7y \\[12pt]
y &= \dfrac{1}{35}\\
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting $x = 1$ into the
equation (1), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
5(1)^2  &= 7y \\[12pt] 
5 &= 7y \\[12pt]
y &= \dfrac{5}{7}\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the solutions are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\hspace{-2.15em}\answer{x = \dfrac{1}{5}, \, y = \dfrac{1}{35}} \\[12pt]
& \hspace{-1.9em}\answer{x = 1, \,\, y = \dfrac{5}{7}}\end{aligned}
$$

title: Question 35
content: - Show that $\log_2 \sqrt{3-\cos 2x} = \log_4 (3-\cos 2x)$. [3] - Hence, or otherwise, solve $\log_4 (3\sin x) \hspace{0.15em}+\hspace{0.15em} \dfrac{1}{4} = \log_2 \sqrt{3-\cos 2x}$, for $0 \hspace{-0.05em}<\hspace{-0.05em} x \hspace{-0.05em}<\hspace{-0.05em}\dfrac{\pi}{2}$.[5]
markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we deduce

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6em} \log_2 \sqrt{3-\cos 2x} &= \dfrac{\log_4 \sqrt{3-\cos 2x}}{\log_4 2} \\[5pt]
  &= \dfrac{\log_4 \sqrt{3-\cos 2x}}{\frac{1}{2}\log_4 4} \\[10pt]
  &= 2 \log_4 \hspace{-0.1em}\sqrt{3-\cos 2x} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $\log_4 4 = 1$}] \\[18pt]
  &\answer{= \log_4(3-\cos 2x)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of logarithms, we deduce

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \log_4 (3\sin x) + \dfrac{1}{4} &= \textstyle \log_2 \sqrt{3-\cos 2x} \\[4pt]
  \hspace{3.5em} \log_4 (3\sin x) + \dfrac{1}{4}\log_4 4 &= \log_4(3-\cos 2x) \hspace{2.5em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[7pt]
  \textstyle \log_4 (3\sin x) + \log_4\sqrt{2} &= \log_4(3-\cos 2x) \hspace{2.5em} [\text{since $\textstyle 4^{1/4} = \sqrt{2}$}\hspace{0.05em}] \\[10pt]
  \textstyle \log_4 (3\sqrt{2}\sin x)\hspace{-0.1em} &= \log_4(3-\cos 2x) \\[10pt]
  \textstyle 3\sqrt{2}\sin x &= 3-\cos 2x \qref{(1)} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $0 < x < \frac{\pi}{2}$, we
find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \textstyle 3\sqrt{2}\sin x &= 3 - (1 - 2\sin^2 x) \hspace{1.3em} [\text{by double angle identity}] \\[9pt]
  \textstyle 3\sqrt{2}\sin x &= 2 + 2\sin^2 x \\[9pt]
  \textstyle 2\sin^2 x - 3\sqrt{2}\sin x + 2 &= 0 \hspace{2.1em} [\text{rearranging terms to form quadratic}] \\[9pt]
  \sin x &= \dfrac{3\sqrt{2} \pm \sqrt{18-4\cdot2\cdot2}}{4} \\[9pt] 
  \sin x &= \dfrac{3\sqrt{2} - \sqrt{2}}{4} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $\sin x \neq \sqrt{2}$}] \\[9pt] 
  \sin x &= \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{3.1em} \answer{x = \dfrac{\pi}{4}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $0 < x < \textstyle \frac{\pi}{2}$}]
  $$

title: Question 2
content: Consider the function $f(x)=\dfrac{e^x-e^{-x}}{2}$, $x\in \mathbb{R}$. - Show that $f$ is an odd function. [2] Now, consider the function $g$ given by $g(x) = \dfrac{x^4+2}{2x}$ , $x\in \mathbb{R}, x \neq 0$. - By considering the graph of $y=f(x)-g(x)$, solve $f(x)>g(x)$ for $x\in \mathbb{R}$. [4]
markScheme:
- Evaluating $f(-x)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  f(-x) &= \dfrac{e^{-x}-e^{-(-x)}}{2} \\[10pt]
  &= \dfrac{e^{-x}-e^{x}}{2} \\[10pt]
  &= -\dfrac{e^{x}-e^{-x}}{2} \\[10pt]
  &= -f(x) \\[-8pt]
  \end{align*}
  $$

  $\answer{\text{Therefore, $f(x)$ is an odd function}}$
- If $f(x)-g(x)>0$, then $f(x)>g(x)$. Using G.D.C., we get

$\answer{-4.55 < x < 0 \text{ and } x > 4.55}$

title: Question 3
content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{4-ax}{5x - 2}$. - Write down the equation of the vertical asymptote of the graph of $y = f(x)$.[1] The line $y = -1.4$ is a horizontal asymptote to the graph of $y = f(x)$. - Find the value of $a$.[2] - The line $y = x - c$, where $c \in \mathbb{R}^+$, intersects the graph of $y = \big|f(x)\big|$ at exactly one point. Find the possible values of $c$. [4]
markScheme:

- The horizontal asymptote will be equal to $\displaystyle\lim_{x \to \pm \infty}f(x)$. We have
