title: Question 8
content: - Sketch the curve $y = -\left|\dfrac{5}{x-2}\right|$ and line $y = -x - 4$ on the same axes, clearly indicating any $x$ and $y$ intercepts and any asymptotes. [3] - Find the exact solutions to the equation $x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}$. [5]
markScheme:
- Let $f(x) = -\left|\dfrac{5}{x-2}\right|$ where $x \in \mathbb{R}$,
$x \neq 2$.
  Since $f(x) < 0$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $x \neq 2$, the curve
$y = f(x)$ has no $x$-intercepts.
  Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} y &= f(0) \\[12pt]
  &= -\left|-\dfrac{5}{2}\right| \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{5}{2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point A$(0,-5/2)$ is the
$y$-intercept of the curve $y = f(x)$.
  We have

  $$
  \lim_{x \rightarrow\pm\infty} f(x) = 0 \hspace{3.9em}
  $$

  Hence the $x$-axis is a horizontal asymptote of the curve
$y = f(x)$.
  The denominator of $f$ is zero when $x = 2$. Hence the line $x = 2$
is a vertical asymptote of the curve $y = f(x)$.
  The $x$ and $y$ intercepts of the line $y = -4-x$ are B$(-4,0)$ and
C$(0,-4)$.
  If we sketch the curve $y = f(x)$ and line $y = -x - 4$ on the same
axes, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3ce10e6d-6009-49da-a002-42ae1d773968/images/2248acaa-10a6-4043-b8a6-84823cf01ad6/38ce371d4e9621963b29074adf6413c8b9f71c7c.svg)


- If we solve the equation $x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}$ for $x < 2$, we
find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x + 4 &= -\dfrac{5}{x-2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x - 2 < 0$}] \\[9pt]
  \hspace{7.7em} (x+4)(x-2) &= -5 \\[12pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 8 &= -5 \\[12pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 3 &= 0 \\[13pt]
  (x + 3)(x - 1) &= 0 \\[13pt]
  x &= -3,\hspace{0.25em} 1\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we simplify the equation
$x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}$ for $x > 2$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x + 4 &= \dfrac{5}{x-2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x - 2 > 0$}] \\[9pt]
  \hspace{10em} (x+4)(x-2) &= 5 \\[13pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 8 &= 5 \\[13pt]
  x^2 + 2x - 13 &= 0\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the quadratic
formula, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{12em} x &= \dfrac{-2+\sqrt{2^2-4(1)(-13)}}{2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x > 2$}] \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{-2+2\sqrt{14}}{2} \\[12pt]
  &= -1 + \sqrt{14} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the
exact solutions to the equation $\text{\(x + 4 = \dfrac{5}{|x-2|}\)}$ are  $\answer{-3,\hspace{0.25em}1,\hspace{0.25em}\textstyle -1 + \sqrt{14}}$

title: Question 9
content: The function $f$ is defined by $f(x) = 1+ \dfrac{4x}{x+3}$, for $x \neq -3$. - Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, indicating clearly any asymptotes and points of intersection with the $x$ and $y$ axes. [4] - Find an expression for $f^{-1}$. [4] - Find all values of $x$ for which $f(x) = f^{-1}(x)$. [3] - Solve the inequality $|f(x)| < 2$. [4] - Solve the inequality $f(|x|) < 2$. [2]
markScheme:
- If we solve the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  1+ \dfrac{4x}{x+3} &= 0 \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{5x+3}{x+3} &= 0 \\[11pt]
  5x + 3 &= 0 \\[10pt]
  x &= -\dfrac{3}{5} \hspace{2.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point
P$(-3/5,0)$ is the $x$-intercept of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
  &= 1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point Q$(0,1)$ is the $y$-intercept of
the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x \rightarrow\pm\infty} f(x) &= 1 + \dfrac{4}{1} \hspace{3.7em} \\[6pt]
  &= 5\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the line $y = 5$ is a horizontal asymptote
of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  The denominator of $f$ is zero when $x = -3$. Hence the line
$x = -3$
is a vertical asymptote of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  If we sketch of the graph of $y = f(x)$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b02f9456-fc87-4d72-8046-b8ad6f17fd88/images/80e5d1bc-25e1-48da-ad0b-cf11c4df076c/a4ee5024679811f4302b4cf52d17f68170c60827.svg)


- If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = f^{-1}(x)$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \hspace{3.7em}  \\[8pt]
  f\left(y\right) &= x\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.7em} 1+ \dfrac{4y}{y+3} &= x \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{5y+3}{y+3} &= x \\[10pt]
  5y+3 &= xy+3x \\[16pt]
  (5-x)y &= 3x-3 \\[10pt]
  y &= \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence an expression for
$f^{-1}$ is
$\answer{f^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x}}$
- If we solve the equation $f(x) = f^{-1}(x)$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= f^{-1}(x) \\[9pt]
  1 + \dfrac{4x}{x+3} &= \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{5x+3}{x+3} &= \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x} \\[10pt]
  (5x+3)(5-x) &= (3x-3)(x+3) \\[12pt]
  \hspace{1.6em} 25x - 5x^2 + 15 -3x &= 3x^2 + 9x -3x - 9 \\[12pt]
  -8x^2 + 16x + 24 &= 0\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x^2 - 2x - 3 &= 0 \\[12pt]
  (x+1)(x-3) &= 0 \hspace{4em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{3.6em} \answer{x = -1,\hspace{0.25em}3}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \hspace{8.1em} \begin{array}{rcccl}
  && |f(x)| &<& 2 \\[13pt]
  -2 &<& f(x) &<& 2 \\[12pt]
  f^{-1}(-2) &<& x &<& f^{-1}(2) \hspace{2em} [\text{since $f^{-1}(f(x)) = x$}]
  \end{array}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $y = f^{-1}(x)$ for $x = -2$,
we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.4em} f^{-1}(-2) &= \dfrac{3(-2)-3}{5-(-2)} \\[3pt]
  &= -\dfrac{9}{7} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $y = f^{-1}(x)$ for
$x = 2$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.2em} f^{-1}(2) &= \dfrac{3(2)-3}{5-2}  \hspace{0.8em} \\[8pt]
  &= 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the set of solutions to the inequality
$|f(x)| < 2$ is
$\answer{-\frac{9}{7}<x<1}$
- If we solve the inequality $f(|x|) < 2$ for $|x|$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.5em} 1+ \dfrac{4|x|}{|x|+3} &< 2 \\[5pt]
  \dfrac{4|x|}{|x|+3} &< 1 \\[10pt]
  4|x| &< |x|+3 \\[16pt]
  3|x| &< 3 \\[16pt]
  |x| &< 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the set of solutions to the
inequality $f(|x|) < 2$ is
$\answer{-1<x<1}$

title: Question 12
content: Consider the function defined by $f(x) = (2x-6)\ln(x+3)+x$ for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $x>p$. - Find the value of $p$. [2] - Find an expression for $f'(x)$. [3] The graph of $y=f(x)$ has no points of inflexion. - Determine if the graph of $y=f(x)$ is concave down or concave up over its domain. [3] The function $g$ is defined by $g(x)=3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{x+3}\right)+x$, for $x\in \mathbb{R}$, $x>-3$. - Find an expression for $g'(x)$. [4] - Find the horizontal and vertical asymptotes of $g'(x)$.[2] - Find the exact value of the minimum of $y=g(x)$.[3] - Solve $f(x)-3$.[5]
markScheme:
- Due to the natural log term, $x+3>0$. Therefore
$\answer{ p=-3}$
- Differentiating $f$ with respect to $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\big[(2x-6)\ln(x+3)+x\big] \\[10pt]
  & \answer{=\dfrac{2x-6}{x+3}+2\ln(x+3)+1} \end{aligned}
  $$

- Differentiating $f'$ with respect to $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f''(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\left[\dfrac{2x-6}{x+3}+2\ln(x+3)+1\right] \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{(x+3)(2)-(2x-6)}{\left(x+3\right)^2} + \dfrac{2}{x+3} \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{2x+18}{(x+3)^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, over $x>-3$, we have $f''(x)>0$. Therefore,
$\answer{f \text{ is concave up}}$
- Differentiating $g$ with respect to $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\left[3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{x+3}\right)+x\right] \\[12pt]
  &=3(x+3)\left(-\dfrac{1}{(x+3)^2}\right)+1  \\[8pt]
  & =\dfrac{-3}{x+3}+1 \\[10pt] 
  & \answer{=\dfrac{x}{x+3}} \end{aligned}
  $$

- The denominator of $g'$ is zero when $x=-3$.
Hence,
$\answer{\text{the line \(x=-3\) is a vertical asymptote of the graph of \(y=g'(x)\)}}$
If we take the limit as $x$ tends to $\infty$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x\to \infty} g'(x) &= \lim_{x\to \infty} \dfrac{x}{x+3}%\cdot \dfrac{\dfrac{1}{x}}{\dfrac{1}{x}}
  \\[8pt]
  & = \lim_{x\to \infty} \dfrac{1}{1+\dfrac{3}{x}\rule[-2mm]{0pt}{7.2mm}} \\[6pt]
  & = 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence,
$\answer{\text{the line \(y=1\) is a horizontal asymptote of the graph of \(y=g'(x)\)}}$
- From part (d) we obtain a stationary point at $x=0$.
The second derivative of $g$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g''(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x} \left[\dfrac{x}{x+3}\right] \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{3}{(x+3)^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, $g''(x)>0$ which implies that at $x=0$ the function $g$
reaches its minimum. Therefore, the minimum value of $g$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g(0) &= 3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)+0 \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= -3\ln(3)} \end{aligned}
  $$

- Using logarithm properties, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &< g(x) \\[12pt]
  (2x-6)\ln(x+3) + x &< 3\ln\left(\dfrac{1}{x+3}\right) + x \\[12pt]
  (2x-6)\ln(x+3) &< -3\ln(x+3) \\[15pt]
  (2x-3)\ln(x+3) &< 0\end{aligned}
  $$

  Thus, we have two options

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \left[2x-3<0\enskip\&\enskip \ln(x+3)>0\right] &\text{  or  } \left[2x-3>0 \enskip\&\enskip \ln(x+3)<0\right] \\[12pt]
  \left[x<1.5\enskip\&\enskip\ln(x+3)>0\right]&\text{ or } \left[x>1.5\enskip\&\enskip \ln(x+3)<0\right] \\[12pt]
  x < 1.5\enskip & \&\enskip 1<x+3 \hspace{2em}[\text{since }\ln(x+3)>0\text{ for }x>1.5]\\[8pt]
  -2 <& \hspace{0.1em}x < 1.5 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore,
$f(x)<g(x)$ over $\answer{-2 <  x < 1.5}$

title: Question 3
content:
Given that $(x-4)$ is a factor of $f(x) = x^3 - 2x^2 + ax + b$ and that
division of $f(x)$ by $(x+2)$ leaves a remainder of $18$, find the value
of $a$ and the value of $b$.
markScheme:
Using the factor theorem, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(4) &= 0 \\[5pt]
4^3 - 2(4)^2 + a(4) + b &= 0 \\[6pt]
32 + 4a + b &= 0 \\[6pt]
4a + b &= -32 \hspace{2em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

Using the remainder
theorem, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(-2) &= 18 \\[5pt]
(-2)^3 - 2(-2)^2 + a(-2) + b &= 18 \\[6pt]
-16 - 2a + b &= 18 \\[6pt]
-2a + b &= 34  \hspace{6em} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, solving the
system of two linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $a$ and $b$, we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\answer{a = -11}\hspace{0.525em}\text{ and }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{b = 12}\end{aligned}
$$

title: Question 13
content: Let $f(x) = ax^3 + bx^2 + cx + d$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where $a,b,c,d \in \mathbb{Q}$. The diagram below shows part of the graph of $y = f(x)$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d78a10f2-621e-426c-91f2-9dea87dbacc5/images/89842500-91d4-4b78-a494-6ce2510b4acf/f2e9d58912ae2f10d7fdf9d12ee3b7594c2c45fb.svg) - Using the information shown in the diagram, find the values of $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d$.[4] - Let $g(x) = -\dfrac{3}{4}f(-2x+1)$. - Find the coordinates of the points where the graph of $y = g(x)$ intercepts the $x$-axis. - Find the $y$-intercept of the graph of $y = g(x)$. [3]
markScheme:
- From the diagram, we see that the roots of the polynomial equation
$f(x) = 0$ are $-3$, $-1$ and $3$.
  Hence, using the factor theorem, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= a(x-3)(x+1)(x+3) \\[6pt]
  &= a(x^2-9)(x+1) \\[6pt]
  &= a(x^3 + x^2 - 9x - 9) \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we substitute
$x = 0$ in the expression $(1)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.6em} f(0) &= a(0^3 + 0^2 - 9(0) - 9) \\[12pt]
  -3 &= -9a \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f(0) = -3$}] \\[6pt]
  a &= \dfrac{1}{3}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we substitute $a = 1/3$ in the
expression $(1)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= \dfrac{1}{3}(x^3 + x^2 - 9x - 9) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{3}x^3 + \dfrac{1}{3}x^2 - 3x - 3 \hspace{1.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{a = b = \dfrac{1}{3}}$
and  $\answer{c = d = -3}$
- 
  - Solving the equation $g(x) = 0$ for $x$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    -\dfrac{3}{4}f(-2x + 1) &= 0 \\[6pt]
    f(-2x + 1) &= 0 \\[12pt]
    -2x + 1 &= -3,\hspace{0.25em} -1,\hspace{0.25em} 3 \hspace{4em} \\[12pt]
    -2x &= -4,\hspace{0.25em} -2,\hspace{0.25em} 2 \\[12pt]
    x &= -1,\hspace{0.25em}1,\hspace{0.25em}2\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence
the coordinates of the $x$-intercepts of the graph of $y = g(x)$
are

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \answer{(-1,0),\hspace{0.25em}(1,0),\hspace{0.25em}(2,0)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Evaluating $y=g(x)$ for $x = 0$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{10.9em} y &= g(0) \\[10pt]
    &= -\dfrac{3}{4}f(2(0)+1) \\[6pt]
    &= -\dfrac{3}{4}f(1) \\[6pt]
    &= -\dfrac{3}{4}\hspace{-0.2em}\left[\dfrac{1}{3}(1)^3 + \dfrac{1}{3}(1)^2 - 3(1) - 3\right] \\[4pt]
    &=-\dfrac{3}{4}\hspace{-0.2em}\left[-\dfrac{16}{3}\right] \\[10pt]
    &= 4\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the $y$-intercept of the graph of
$y = g(x)$ is
$\answer{\mathrm{P}(0,4)}$

title: Question 17
content: Consider the family of polynomials of the form $P(x)=ax^3+bx^2+cx+d$ where coefficients $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d$ belong to the set $\{2,6,8,24\}$. - Find the number of possible polynomials if - each coefficient value can be repeated; - each coefficient must be different.[4] Consider the case where $P(x)$ has $x+3$ as a factor, two purely imaginary roots, and all the coefficients are different. - - By considering the sum of the roots, find the two possible combinations for coefficients $a$ and $b$. - Show that there is only one way to assign the values $a$, $b$, $c$, and $d$ if $P(0)=24$.[7] Now, consider the polynomial with the coefficients found in part (b) (ii). - - Express $P(x)$ as a product of one linear and one quadratic factor. - Determine the three roots of $P(x)$.[7]
markScheme:
- Let $X$ be the total number of polynomials.
  
  - Given that each coefficient value can be repeated, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    X&=4 \times 4 \times 4 \times 4\\[6pt]
    &=4^4\\[6pt]
    &=256.
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore, there are $\tcbhighmath{256}$ possible polynomials if the coefficients can be repeated.
  - Given that each coefficient must be different, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    X&=4!\\[6pt]
    &=4 \times 3 \times 2 \times 1\\[6pt]
    &=24.
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore, there are $\tcbhighmath{24}$ possible polynomials if each coefficient must be different.

- 
  - Let the roots be $x_1, x_2$ and $x_3$. Given that $x+3$ is a factor, $x_1=-3$ is a root. Complex roots occur in conjugate pairs, therefore if the other two roots are imaginary, we have $x_2 = \alpha \mathrm{i}$ and $x_3 = -\alpha \mathrm{i}$, where $\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$. Hence, the sum of the roots is given by

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    x_1 + x_2 + x_3 &= -3 + \alpha \mathrm{i} - \alpha \mathrm{i} \\[6pt]
    &= -3
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Using the formula for the sum of the roots, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    x_1 + x_2 + x_3 &= -\dfrac{b}{a} \\[6pt]
    -3 &= -\dfrac{b}{a} \\[6pt]
    3a &= b
    \end{align*}
    $$

    We have that $a$ and $b$ belong to the set $\{2,6,8,24\}$ and $3a=b$. Therefore,
    $\tcbhighmath{\text{The two possible combinations are $a=2,\,b=6$ and $a=8,\,b=24$.}}$
  - If $P(0)=24$, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    P(0) &= a(0)^3 + b(0)^2 + c(0) + d \\[6pt]
    24 &= d
    \end{align*}
    $$

    The coefficients must all be different. If $d=24$, $b \neq 24$, so we have from part (b)(i) that $a=2$ and $b=6$. Therefore $c=8$.
    $\tcbhighmath{\text{If $P(0)=24$, we must have $a=2,\,b=6,\,c=8$ and $d=24$.}}$

- 
  - Our polynomial is $P(x) = 2x^3 + 6x^2 + 8x + 24$. Given that $x+3$ is a factor, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    2x^3 + 6x^2 + 8x + 24 &= (x+3)(2x^2 + ex + 8) \\[6pt]
    &= 2x^3 +ex^2 + 8x + 6x^2 +3ex + 24 \\[6pt]
    2x^3 + 6x^2 + 8x + 24 &= 2x^3 + (e+6)x^2 + (8+3e)x +24
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Equating the coefficients of $x^2$ and $x$ on the LHS and RHS, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    6 &= e + 6 \\[6pt]
    8 &= 8 + 3e
    \end{align*}
    $$

    We must have $e=0$. Therefore

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    P(x) &= (x+3)(2x^2 + 8) \\[8pt]
    &\hspace{-2.1em}\tcbhighmath{P(x) = 2(x+3)(x^2 + 4)}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - We have from part (b)(i) that $x_1=-3$. To find the other two roots, we solve $x^2+4=0$:

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    x^2+4&=0 \\[6pt]
    x^2 &= -4 \\[6pt]
    x &= \pm \sqrt{-4} \\[6pt]
    x &= \pm 2\mathrm{i}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    $\boxed{\text{The roots of } P(x) \text{ are } x_1=-3,\, x_2=-2\mathrm{i}, \text{ and } x_3=2\mathrm{i}.}$

title: Question 18
content: This question asks you to investigate some properties of cubic functions and their tangents. Consider the cubic function $q(x)=x^3-6x^2-x+30$. - - Show that $x=5$ is a root of $q(x)=0$. - Hence, express $q(x)$ as a product of linear factors. - Find the equation of the tangent to $y=q(x)$ at $x=4$. - Sketch $y=q(x)$ and the tangent at $x=4$ on the same set of axes. [9] Consider the cubic function $f(x)=ax^3+bx^2+cx+d, \, a\neq 0,$ and the line $L(x)=mx+1$, with the point $(x_\ast, f(x_\ast))$ being a point of inflection on $f(x)$. Let $x_1,x_2,x_3$ be the roots of the equation $f(x)-L(x)=0.$ - - Show that the sum of the roots is a constant which is independent of the choice of line $L$. - Show that $y=f(x)$ has an inflection point at $x_\ast=\dfrac{x_1+x_2+x_3}{3}.$ [5] Suppose $y=L(x)$ is a tangent to $y=f(x)$ at the point $x=x_1$. - - Show that $f'(x)-L'(x)=3a(x-x_1)(x-\beta)$ for some $\beta$. - Hence show that $f(x)-L(x)=\dfrac{a}{2}(x-x_1)^2(2x+x_1-3\beta)$. - Assuming it exists, find the $x$-coordinate of the other point of intersection between the cubic and the line, in terms of $x_1$ and $x_\ast$. - Sketch the functions $f(x)$ and $L(x)$ on the same axes identifying the $x$-coordinate of the points of intersection and inflection. - In the case that $L(x)=0$, interpret the result in (c)(iii) in terms of the graph of the cubic function and its $x$-intercepts. [13]

title: Question 19
content: - Show that $\cos{3\theta}=4\cos^3{\theta}-3\cos{\theta}$. [4] Consider the following function $$ \begin{align*} f(x)&=4x^3-3x-\cos{3k} \end{align*} $$ Where $k$ is an angle in degrees such that $0 \leq k \leq 360^\circ$. - Hence, verify that $\cos{k}$ is one of the roots of $f(x)$.[2] Let the remaining two roots of $f(x)$ be $\alpha$ and $\beta$. - - Find $\alpha\beta$ in terms of $\cos{k}$. - Show that $\beta=-\alpha-\cos k$.[3] - Using your answers from part (c) show that $\alpha^2+\alpha \cos k +\cos^2 k -\tfrac{3}{4}=0$. [2] - Hence show that $\alpha = \frac{-\cos k + \sqrt{3}\sin k}{2}$ and $\beta = \frac{-\cos k - \sqrt{3}\sin k}{2}$. [4] It is known that for $0 \leq k \leq 360^\circ$ $f(x)$ has either $3$ distinct roots or a single distinct root and a repeated root. - Hence, find all of the values of $k$ for which $f(x)$ intersects the $x-$axis exactly $2$ times. [7]

title: Question 20
content: The cubic polynomial equation $x^3 + bx^2 + cx + d = 0$ has three roots $x_1, x_2$ and $x_3$. By expanding the product $(x-x_1)(x-x_2)(x-x_3)$, show that - - $b = -(x_1+x_2+x_3)$; - $c = x_1x_2 + x_1x_3 + x_2x_3$; - $d = -x_1x_2x_3$. [3] It is given that $b = -9$ and $c = 45$ for parts (b) and (c) below. - - In the case that the three roots $x_1, x_2$ and $x_3$ form an arithmetic sequence, show that one of the roots is $3$. - Hence determine the value of $d$. [5] - In another case the three roots form a geometric sequence. Determine the value of $d$. [6]
markScheme:
- Given the three roots $x_1$, $x_2$ and $x_3$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x^3 + bx^2 + cx + d &= (x-x_1)(x-x_2)(x-x_3) \\[6pt]
  &= (x^2 -(x_1+x_2)x + x_1x_2)(x-x_3) \\[8pt]
  &= x^3 - (x_1+x_2+x_3)x^2 + (x_1x_2+x_1x_3+x_2x_3)x - x_1x_2x_3\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, comparing the coefficients, we get
  
  - $\answer{b = -(x_1+x_2+x_3)}$
  - $\answer{c = x_1x_2 + x_1x_3 + x_2x_3}$
  - $\answer{d = -x_1x_2x_3}$

- 
  - Letting $\alpha = x_1 + \delta$, where $\delta$ is the common
difference of the arithmetic sequence $x_1$, $x_2$, $x_3$, we
have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.8em} x_1  &=  \alpha - \delta \\[6pt]
    x_2  &=  \alpha \\[6pt]
    x_3  &=  \alpha + \delta\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, using part (a)
(i), we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    x_1 + x_2 + x_3 &= -b \\[6pt]
    (\alpha - \delta) + \alpha + (\alpha + \delta) &= -(-9) \hspace{6em} \\[6pt]
    3\alpha &= 9 \\[6pt]
    \alpha &= 3 \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{x_2 = 3}
    $$

  - Using part (a) (ii), we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    x_1x_2 + x_1x_3 + x_2x_3 &= c \\[6pt]
    (3 - \delta)(3) + (3 - \delta)(3 + \delta) + (3)(3 + \delta) &= 45 \\[6pt]
    27 - \delta^2 &= 45 \\[6pt]
    -\delta^2 &= 18 \\[5pt]
    \delta &= \sqrt{18}\hspace{0.05em}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\hspace{2em}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, using part (a) (iii), we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4em} d &= -x_1x_2x_3 \\[5pt]
    &= -(3-\sqrt{18}\hspace{0.05em}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})(3)(3+\sqrt{18}\hspace{0.05em}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= -81}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Letting $\alpha = x_1$ and $r$ denote the common ratio of the
geometric sequence $x_1, x_2, x_3$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.2em} x_1  &=  \alpha \\[6pt]
  x_2  &=  \alpha r \\[6pt]
  x_3  &=  \alpha r^2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.25em} x_1 + x_2 + x_3 &= -b \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a) (i)}] \\[6pt]
  \alpha + \alpha r + \alpha r^2 &= -(-9) \\[6pt]
  \alpha (1+r+r^2) &= 9 \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x_1x_2 + x_1x_3 + x_2x_3 &= c \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a) (ii)}] \\[6pt]
  \alpha (\alpha r) + \alpha (\alpha r^2) + (\alpha r)(\alpha r^2) &= 45 \\[6pt]
  \alpha^2r(1+r+r^2) &= 45 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Taking the ratio
of the expressions $(1)$ and $(2)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\alpha^2r(\cancel{1+r+r^2})}{\alpha(\cancel{1+r+r^2})} &= \dfrac{45}{9} \hspace{4em} \\[5pt]
  \dfrac{\alpha^2r}{\alpha} &= \dfrac{45}{9} \\[15pt]
  \alpha r &= 5 \qref{(3)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the expression $(3)$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.5em} d &= -x_1x_2x_3 \hspace{3em} [\text{by (a) (iii)}] \\[5pt]
  &= -\alpha (\alpha r)(\alpha r^2) \\[5pt]
  &= -(\alpha r)^3 \\[5pt]
  &= -5^3 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -125}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 2
content:
Consider two consecutive positive integers, $k$ and $k+1$.
Show that the difference of their squares is equal to the sum of the two
integers.
markScheme:
The difference of the squares of $k$ and $k+1$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{9.5em}(k+1)^2 - k^2 &= k^2 + 2k + 1 - k^2 \\[6pt]
&= 2k + 1 \\[6pt]
&= k + (k + 1) \hspace{3em} [\text{sum of $k$ and $k+1$}]\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the difference of the squares of two consecutive positive integers
is equal to their sum.

title: Question 6
content: - Prove that $\dfrac{5}{x^2} = \dfrac{5}{x(x-2)}-\dfrac{10}{x^2(x-2)}$. [3] - Determine the set of numbers $x$ for which the proof in part (a) is valid. [2] $$ $$
markScheme:
- By working out the right side of the equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      \dfrac{5}{x(x-2)}-\dfrac{10}{x^2(x-2)} &= \dfrac{5x}{x^2(x-2)}-\dfrac{10}{x^2(x-2)} \\[9pt]
      &= \dfrac{5x-10}{x^2(x-2)} \\[9pt]
      &= \dfrac{5\ \cancel{(x-2)}}{x^2\ \cancel{(x-2)}} \\[9pt]
      &= \dfrac{5}{x^2}   .
  \end{align*}
  $$

- We cannot have a denominator equal to zero, and therefore

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      x^2 &\neq 0 \Rightarrow x \neq 0 \hspace{3.95em} \text{[from L.H.S.]} \\[8pt]
      x(x-2) &\neq 0 \Rightarrow x \neq 0 , 2 \hspace{3em} \text{[from R.H.S.]} \\[8pt]
      x^2(x-2) &\neq 0 \Rightarrow x \neq 0 , 2 \hspace{3em} \text{[from R.H.S.]}
  \end{align*}
  $$


Therefore the proof is valid for all values of $x$ except $x = 0$ and $x=2$.
$\answer{x \in \mathbb{R}, x \neq 0 \text{  and  } x\neq 2}$

title: Question 11
content:
The Fibonacci sequence is defined as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_0 &= 0,\hspace{0.25em} a_1 = 1,\hspace{0.25em} a_2 = 1, \\[6pt]
a_n &= a_{n-1}+a_{n-2} \hspace{0.5em}\text{for}\hspace{0.5em} n \geq 2. \qref{(FS)}\end{aligned}
$$

Prove by mathematical induction that
$a_1^2+a_2^2+\cdots+a_n^2=a_na_{n+1}$, where $n\in\mathbb{Z}^+$.
markScheme:
Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{8.3em} a_1^2+a_2^2+...+a_n^2=a_na_{n+1} \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$}]\end{aligned}
$$

Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.
Base case. For $n = 1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_1^2 &= 1^2 \\[6pt]
&= 1\cdot 1 \\[6pt]
&= a_1a_2\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_1^2+a_2^2+...+a_k^2 = a_ka_{k+1} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for some
$k \geq 1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_1^2+a_2^2+...+a_k^2 + a_{k+1}^2= a_{k+1}a_{k+2} \hspace{2.2em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_1^2+a_2^2+...+a_k^2 + a_{k+1}^2 &= \big(a_1^2+a_2^2+...+a_k^2\big) + a_{k+1}^2 \\[6pt]
&= a_ka_{k+1} + a_{k+1}^2 \hspace{3em} [\text{by (IH)}] \\[7pt]
&= \big(a_k + a_{k+1}\big)a_{k+1} \\[7pt]
&= a_{k+2}a_{k+1} \hspace{3em} [\text{by (FS)}] \\[7pt]
&= a_{k+1}a_{k+2}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

title: Question 14
content: Use mathematical induction to prove that $n^3-9n^2+26n-24$ is divisible by $6$ for all $n\geq 5$.
markScheme:
Let $P(n)$ be the proposition that $n^3-9n^2+26n-24$ is divisible by $6$.
The first step is to verify the base case ($n=5$).

$$
\begin{align*}
    P(5)&=(5)^3-9(5)^2+26(5)-24\\
    &=6
\end{align*}
$$

$P(5)$ is divisible by $6$ therefore it is true.

$$
    \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
$$

$\textcolor{white}{gap}$
Now we will form the assumption.
Assume $P(k)$ is true.

$$
\begin{align*}
    P(k)&=k^3-9k^2+26k-24\\
    &=6A  \tag*{\textbf{M1}}
\end{align*}
$$

Where $k, A\in \mathbb{Z^+}$ and $k\geq5$.
Now we will consider the $(k+1)^{\text{th}}$ case and by using the assumption we will show that $P(k+1)$ is divisible by $6$.

$$
\begin{align*}
    P(k+1)&=(k+1)^3-9(k+1)^2+26(k+1)-24\\
    &=\bm{k^3}+3k^2+3k+1-\bm{9k^2}-18k-9+\bm{26k}+26-\bm{24} \tag*{\textbf{M1}}
\end{align*}
$$

The terms in bold above are equivalent to the assumption, $P(k)$. Hence we can replace them with $6A$ and then simplify. This is known as the inductive step as we are inducting the assumption into the proof.

$$
\begin{align*}
    P(k+1)&=3k^2+3k+1-18k-9+26+6A \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\
    &=6A+3k^2-15k+18
\end{align*}
$$

We now need to show the remaining terms involving $k$ are divisible by $6$.

$$
\begin{align*}
    P(k+1)&=6A+3(k-2)(k-3) 
\end{align*}
$$

After factorising we can see that the expression $(k-2)(k-3)$ is the product of two consecutive numbers (recall $k\geq5$). This will always be an even number, hence we can replace it with $2B$, Where $B \in \mathbb{Z^+}$.

$$
\begin{align*}
    P(k+1)&=6A+3\times 2B\\
    &=6A + 6B\\
    &=6(A+B)
\end{align*}
$$

$P(k+1)$ is divisible by $6$.

$$
    \tag*{\textbf{R1}}
$$

$\textcolor{white}{gap}$
We must write a concluding sentence.

$$
\answer{\text{$P(5)$ is true and $P(k)$ being true implies $P(k+1)$ is true. We can therefore say, by the principle of mathematical induction, that $P(n)$ is true for all $n\geq 5$.}}
$$


$$
    \tag*{\textbf{R1}}
$$

$\textcolor{white}{gap}$

title: Question 16
content: Let $f(x) = (x+1)e^{-2x}$, $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find $f'(x)$. [2] - Prove by induction that $\dfrac{\mathrm{d}^nf}{\mathrm{d}x^n} = \big[n(-2)^{n-1} + (-2)^n(x+1)\big]e^{-2x}$ for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.[7]
markScheme:
- Using the product rule, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.2em} f'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\big[(x+1)e^{-2x}\big] \\[6pt]
  &= e^{-2x} - 2(x+1)e^{-2x} \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= \big[1 - 2(x+1)\big]e^{-2x}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let $\mathrm{P}(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.9em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^nf}{\mathrm{d}x^n} = \big[n(-2)^{n-1} + (-2)^n(x+1)\big]e^{-2x} \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using mathematical induction, we will prove that $\mathrm{P}(n)$
holds for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

Base case. For $n = 1$, from part (a), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\mathrm{d}f}{\mathrm{d}x} = \big[1 - 2(x+1)\big]e^{-2x}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that $\mathrm{P}(k)$ holds
for some $k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\mathrm{d}^kf}{\mathrm{d}x^k} = \big[k(-2)^{k-1} + (-2)^k(x+1)\big]e^{-2x} \hspace{0.5em} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for some $k \geq 1$.
Inductive step. To show that $\mathrm{P}(k+1)$ holds, we
need to show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.6em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^{k+1}f}{\mathrm{d}x^{k+1}} = \big[(k+1)(-2)^k + (-2)^{(k+1)}(x+1)\big]e^{-2x}\end{aligned}
$$

If we differentiate both sides of the equation (IH), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.55em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^{k+1}f}{\mathrm{d}x^{k+1}} &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\Big[\big[k(-2)^{k-1} + (-2)^k(x+1)\big]e^{-2x}\Big] \\[14pt]
&= \big[(-2)^k\big]e^{-2x} - 2\big[k(-2)^{k-1} + (-2)^k(x+1)\big]e^{-2x} \\[16pt]
&= \big[(-2)^k\big]e^{-2x} + \big[k(-2)^k + (-2)^{k+1}(x+1)\big]e^{-2x} \\[16pt]
&= \big[(k+1)(-2)^k + (-2)^{(k+1)}(x+1)\big]e^{-2x} \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence $P(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

title: Question 20
content: - Show that $\dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{n+1}} < \sqrt{n+1} - \sqrt{n}$, where $n \in \mathbb{Z},\hspace{0.1em} n\geq 0$. [3] - Hence show that $\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}} < 2\sqrt{2} - 2$. [2] - Prove by mathematical induction that $$ \hspace{4em} \sum_{r = 2}^n \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{r}} < 2\sqrt{n} - 2 \hspace{2em} \text{for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$, $n \geq 2$.} $$ [9]
markScheme:
- For any $n \in \mathbb{Z},\hspace{0.1em} n \geq 0$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} \sqrt{n+1} - \sqrt{n} &= \left[\dfrac{\sqrt{n+1} - \sqrt{n}}{1}\right] \left[\dfrac{\sqrt{n+1} + \sqrt{n}}{\sqrt{n+1} + \sqrt{n}}\right] \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{(\cancel{n}+1) - \cancel{n}}{\sqrt{n+1} + \sqrt{n}} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{n+1} + \sqrt{n}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.8em} \dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{n+1}} < \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{n+1} + \sqrt{n}} \hspace{2em} \big[\text{since $\sqrt{n+1} > \sqrt{n}$}\hspace{0.1em}\big]\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{\dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{n+1}} < \sqrt{n+1} - \sqrt{n}} \hspace{3.8em} \qref{(1)}
  $$

- Hence, substituting $n = 1$ in the inequality $(1)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{2}} &< \sqrt{2} - 1 \hspace{1em}\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}} < 2\sqrt{2} - 2}
  $$

- Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6em} \sum_{r = 2}^n \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{r}} < 2\sqrt{n} - 2 \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n\geq2$}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using math induction, we will prove that P$(n)$
$\text{holds for all \(n \in \mathbb{Z}^+\), \(n\geq2\).}$
  Base case. For $n = 2$, from part (b), we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}} < 2\sqrt{2} - 2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence P$(2)$
holds.
  Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for
some $k \geq 2$. In other words, we assume that

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{r = 2}^k \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{r}} < 2\sqrt{k} - 2 \hspace{1.5em} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  for some $k \geq 2$.
  Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need
to show that

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.2em} \sum_{r = 2}^{k+1} \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{r}} < 2\sqrt{k+1} - 2 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$


From the left hand side of the inequality $(2)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{8em} \sum_{r = 2}^{k+1} \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{r}} &= \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{k+1}} + \sum_{r = 2}^k \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{r}} \\[6pt]
&< \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{k+1}} + \big(2\sqrt{k} - 2\big) \hspace{2em} [\text{by (IH)}] \\[12pt]
&< \big(2\sqrt{k+1} - \cancel{2\sqrt{k}}\big) + \big(\cancel{2\sqrt{k}} - 2\big) \hspace{2em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[18pt]
&= 2\sqrt{k+1} -2\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(2)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 2$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that
P$(n)$ holds for all $\text{\(n\hspace{-0.2em}\in\hspace{-0.2em}\mathbb{Z}^+\hspace{-0.2em},\hspace{0.05em}n\hspace{-0.2em}\geq\hspace{-0.2em}2\)}$.

title: Question 23
content: - Use de Moivre's theorem to find the value of $\left[\cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right)\right]^{12}$. [2] - Use mathematical induction to prove that $$ \hspace{3.5em} (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^n = \cos (n\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (n\alpha) \hspace{1em} \text{for all } n \in \mathbb{Z}^+. $$ [6] Let $w = \cos \alpha + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha$. - Find an expression in terms of $\alpha$ for $w^n - (w^\ast)^n$, $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$, where $w^\ast$ is the complex conjugate of $w$. [2] - - Show that $ww^\ast = 1$. - Write down and simplify the binomial expansion of $(w - w^\ast)^3$ in terms of $w$ and $w^\ast$. - Hence show that $\sin (3\alpha) = 3\sin \alpha - 4 \sin^3 \alpha$. [5] - Hence solve $4\sin^3\alpha + (2 \cos \alpha - 3) \sin \alpha = 0$ for $0 \leq \alpha \leq \pi$. [6]
markScheme:
- Using de Moivre's theorem, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \left[\cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right)\right]^{12} &= \cos\Big(\dfrac{12\pi}{6}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \Big(\dfrac{12\pi}{6}\Big) \\[6pt]
  &= \cos 2\pi + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin 2\pi \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= 1}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.6em} (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^n = \cos (n\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (n\alpha) \hspace{2.5em} [\text{for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

Base case. For $n = 1$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.3em} (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^1 &= \cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha \\[3pt]
&= \cos (1\cdot\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (1\cdot\alpha)\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
(\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^k = \cos (k\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (k\alpha) \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for some $k \geq 1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{4em} (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^{k+1} = \cos ((k+1)\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin ((k+1)\alpha) \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.5em} &(\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^{k+1} = \\[5pt]
&= (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^k\cos \alpha - (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^k ({\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha) \\[6pt]
&= [\cos (k\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (k\alpha)]\cos \alpha - [\cos (k\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (k\alpha)] ({\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)  \hspace{2em} [\text{by (IH)}] \\[6pt]
&= \cos (k\alpha)\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (k\alpha) \cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\cos (k\alpha) \sin \alpha - \sin (k\alpha)\sin \alpha \\[6pt]
&= [\cos (k\alpha)\cos \alpha - \sin (k\alpha)\sin \alpha] - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}[\sin (k\alpha) \cos \alpha + \cos (k\alpha) \sin \alpha]  \\[6pt]
&= \cos((k+1)\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin((k+1)\alpha) \hspace{2em} [\text{by compound angle formulas}]\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

- Using de Moivre's theorem and the identity $(2)$ from part
(b), we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  w^n - (w^\ast)^n &= (\cos \alpha + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^n - (\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^n \\[6pt]
  &= [\hspace{0.05em}\cos (n\alpha) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (n\alpha)] - [\hspace{0.05em}\cos (n\alpha) - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (n\alpha)] \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (n\alpha)} \qref{(3)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - The product of $w$ and its conjugate is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.2em} ww^\ast &= (\cos \alpha + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)(\cos \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha) \\[6pt]
    &= \cos^2 \alpha - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\cos \alpha \sin \alpha + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha \cos \alpha + \sin^2 \alpha \\[6pt]
    &= \cos^2 \alpha + \sin^2 \alpha \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 1}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we simplify the binomial expansion of $(w - w^\ast)^3$, we
get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    (w - w^\ast)^3 &= w^3 - 3w^2w^\ast + 3w(w^\ast)^2 - (w^\ast)^3 \\[6pt]
    &= w^3 - 3w(ww^\ast) + 3w^\ast(ww^\ast) - (w^\ast)^3 \\[6pt]
    &= w^3 - 3w + 3w^\ast - (w^\ast)^3 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (d) (i)}] \hspace{0.7em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= w^3 - (w^\ast)^3 - 3(w - w^\ast)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Substituting $n = 1$ and $n = 3$ in the identity $(3)$ from part
(c), we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    n=1 &: \hspace{0.5em} w - (w^\ast) = 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha \\[6pt]
    n=3 &: \hspace{0.5em} w^3 - (w^\ast)^3 = 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (3\alpha)\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, from part d (ii), we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.3em} (w - w^\ast)^3 &= w^3 - (w^\ast)^3 - 3\hspace{0.05em}(w - w^\ast) \\[6pt]
    (2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha)^3 &= 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (3\alpha) - 3\hspace{0.05em}(2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha) \\[6pt]
    -8{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin^3 \alpha &= 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin (3\alpha) - 6{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \alpha \\[6pt]
    4\sin^3 \alpha &= -\sin (3\alpha) + 3 \sin \alpha \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{\sin (3\alpha) = 3 \sin \alpha -4\sin^3 \alpha} \hspace{0.9em}
    $$


- If we rewrite the given equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  4\sin^3\alpha + (2 \cos \alpha - 3) \sin \alpha &= 0 \\[6pt]
  2\sin \alpha \cos \alpha  &= 3\sin \alpha - 4\sin^3\alpha \\[7pt]
  \sin (2\alpha) &= \sin (3\alpha) \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (d) (iii)}] \hspace{1em} \qref{(4)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $(4)$ for $\alpha$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.7em} \alpha &= 0 \hspace{0.75em}\text{or}\hspace{0.75em} 3\alpha = k\pi - 2\alpha \hspace{2.2em} [\text{where $k$ is an odd integer}] \\[7pt]
  \hspace{8.7em} \alpha &= 0 \hspace{0.75em}\text{or}\hspace{0.75em} \alpha = \dfrac{k\pi}{5} \hspace{2em} [\text{where $k = 1,3,5$ since $\alpha \in [0,\pi]$}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{\alpha = 0,\hspace{0.25em} \dfrac{\pi}{5},\hspace{0.25em} \dfrac{3\pi}{5},\hspace{0.25em} \pi} \hspace{8.55em}
  $$

title: Question 24
content: Let $f(x) = (x-1)e^{\frac{x}{3}}$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find $f'(x)$. [2] - Prove by induction that $\dfrac{\mathrm{d}^nf}{\mathrm{d}x^n} = \bigg(\dfrac{3n + x - 1}{3^n}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}}$ for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. [7] - Find the coordinates of any local maximum and minimum points on the graph of $y = f(x)$. Justify whether such point is a maximum or a minimum. [5] - Find the coordinates of any points of inflexion on the graph of $y = f(x)$. Justify whether such point is a point of inflexion. [5] - Hence sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, indicating clearly the points found in parts (c) and (d) and any intercepts with the axes. [4]
markScheme:
- Using the product rule, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\big[(x-1)e^{\frac{x}{3}}\big] \\[6pt]
  &= e^{\frac{x}{3}} + \dfrac{1}{3}(x-1)e^{\frac{x}{3}} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \bigg(\dfrac{x+2}{3}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.7em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^nf}{\mathrm{d}x^n} = \bigg(\dfrac{3n + x - 1}{3^n}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}} \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

Base case. For $n = 1$, from part (a), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\mathrm{d}f}{\mathrm{d}x} = \bigg(\dfrac{3 + x - 1}{3}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}} \end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.1em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^kf}{\mathrm{d}x^k} = \bigg(\dfrac{3k + x - 1}{3^k}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
$$

for some $k \geq 1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.2em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^{k+1}f}{\mathrm{d}x^{k+1}} = \bigg[\dfrac{3(k+1) + x - 1}{3^{k+1}}\bigg]e^{\frac{x}{3}}\end{aligned}
$$

If we differentiate both sides of the equation (IH), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{4.9em} \dfrac{\mathrm{d}^{k+1}f}{\mathrm{d}x^{k+1}} &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\bigg[\bigg(\dfrac{3k + x - 1}{3^k}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}}\bigg] \\[6pt]
&= \bigg(\dfrac{1}{3^k}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}} + \dfrac{1}{3}\bigg(\dfrac{3k + x - 1}{3^k}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}} \\[6pt]
&= \bigg[\dfrac{1}{3^k} + \dfrac{3k + x - 1}{3^{k+1}}\bigg]e^{\frac{x}{3}} \\[6pt]
&= \bigg[\dfrac{3(k+1) + x - 1}{3^{k+1}}\bigg]e^{\frac{x}{3}}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.

- If we solve the equation $f'(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \bigg(\dfrac{x + 2}{3}\bigg)e^{\frac{x}{3}} &= 0 \\[6pt]
  x + 2 &= 0 \\[12pt] 
  x &= -2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence $-2$ is the only critical number of
$f$.
  Using the ID Test, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3446dd1a-9a13-43e5-8af3-ee3cf0e76f4c/images/6df8b040-2aba-4405-8103-6cc64148c86f/41f59f91431e030c029eab143139497c30f1df01.svg)


  The sign of $f'$ changes from negative to positive at $-2$.
  Hence, by the First Derivative Test, $f$ has a local minimum at
$-2$.
  Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = -2$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= f(-2) \\[6pt]
  &= (-2-1)e^{-\frac{2}{3}} \\[6pt]
  &= -3e^{-\frac{2}{3}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the graph of $y = f(x)$
has a local minimum at
$\answer{\mathrm{A}\big(\hspace{-0.2em}-2,-3e^{-\frac{2}{3}}\big)}$.
- If we solve the equation $f''(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \bigg[\dfrac{3(2) + x - 1}{3^2}\bigg]e^{\frac{x}{3}} &= 0 \\[6pt]  
  3(2) + x - 1 &= 0 \\[12pt] 
  x &= -5\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence there is at most one point of inflexion
on the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  Using the Concavity Test, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3446dd1a-9a13-43e5-8af3-ee3cf0e76f4c/images/44ae7137-2675-4b13-8b95-c1dd8eee70fc/1c4ca00263d0aa013c934479ae539a797857f949.svg)


  The graph of $y = f(x)$ changes concavity from downward to upward at
$-5$.
  Hence the graph of $y = f(x)$ has an inflexion point at $-5$.
  Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = -5$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= f(-5) \\[6pt]
  &= (-5-1)e^{-\frac{5}{3}} \\[6pt]
  &= -6e^{-\frac{5}{3}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the graph of $y = f(x)$
has the inflexion point at
$\answer{\mathrm{B}\big(\hspace{-0.2em}-5,-6e^{-\frac{5}{3}}\big)}$.
- We first note that the domain of the function
$f(x) = (x-1)e^{\frac{x}{3}}$ is $(-\infty,\infty)$.
  Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (x-1)e^{\frac{x}{3}} &= 0 \\[6pt]
  x-1 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  x &= 1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point
$\answer{\mathrm{C}(1,0)}$
is the $x$-intercept of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
  &= (0-1)e^{0} \\[6pt]
  &= -1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point
$\answer{\mathrm{D}(0,-1)}$
is the $y$-intercept of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x\rightarrow -\infty} f(x) &= \lim_{x\rightarrow -\infty} \big[(x-1)e^{\frac{x}{3}}\big] \\[6pt]
  &= 0\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x\rightarrow \infty} f(x) &= \lim_{x\rightarrow \infty} \big[(x-1)e^{\frac{x}{3}}\big] \\[6pt]
  &= \infty\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the $x$-axis is a horizontal
asymptote of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$ indicating the points A, B, C &
D, we have

title: Question 26
content: The following diagram shows the graph of $y=\arctan(2x-3)+\dfrac{3\pi}{4}$ for $x\in \mathbb{R}$, with asymptotes at $y=\dfrac{\pi}{4}$ and $y=\dfrac{5\pi}{4}$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/94f32658-f1f8-4e8a-a7ec-64540cbb0149/images/f7349dc1-1bf4-4e25-a560-7f6b11100f20/081334c23d135e25efc729fff5cf10e0f4fe7363.svg) - Describe a sequence of transformations that transforms the graph of $y=\arctan x$ to the graph of $y=\arctan(2x-3)+\dfrac{3\pi}{4}$ for $x\in \mathbb{R}$.[3] - Show that $\arctan p - \arctan q \equiv \arctan \left(\dfrac{p-q}{1+pq}\right)$.[3] - Verify that $\arctan(x+2)-\arctan(x+1) = \arctan\left( \dfrac{1}{(x+1)^2+(x+1)+1}\right)$.[3] - Using mathematical induction and the results from part (b) and (c), prove that[8] $$ \sum_{r=1}^n \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{r^2+r+1}\right) = \arctan(n+1)-\dfrac{\pi}{4} \hspace{0.8em} \text{for } n\in \mathbb{Z}^{+}. $$
markScheme:
- The function can be expressed as
$y=\arctan\left(2\left(x-\dfrac{3}{2}\right)\right)+\dfrac{3\pi}{4}$,
hence we get the following transformations in order

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{transformation $1$}&: \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{horizontal stretch by a factor of $\dfrac{1}{2}$}} \\[10pt]
  \text{transformation $2$}&:
  \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{horizontal translation $\dfrac{3}{2}$ units right}}\\[10pt]
  \text{transformation $3$}&: \hspace{0.5em}\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\text{vertical translation $\dfrac{3\pi}{4}$ units up}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Note that the vertical shift, which is transformation $3$, can also be performed before the horizontal transformations.
- Using the compound angle identity, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \tan\left(\arctan p - \arctan q \right) &= \dfrac{\tan(\arctan p)-\tan(\arctan q)}{1+\tan(\arctan p)\tan(\arctan q)} \\[12pt]
  &=\dfrac{p-q}{1+pq} \\[12pt]\\
  \intertext{Finally, taking the $\arctan$ on both sides}\\
  &\hspace{-2.85cm}\answer{\arctan p - \arctan q \equiv \arctan \left(\dfrac{p-q}{1+pq}\right)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the formula from part (b), we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arctan(x+2)-\arctan(x+1) &= \arctan\left(\dfrac{(x+2)-(x+1)}{1+(x+2)(x+1)}\right)\\[12pt]
  &= \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{((x+1)+1)(x+1)+1}\right)\\[12pt]
  &\hspace{0.2em}\answer{=\arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{(x+1)^2+(x+1)+1}\right)} \end{aligned}
  $$

- Let $\mathrm{P}(n)$ be the following statement:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{r=1}^n \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{r^2+r+1}\right) &= \arctan(n+1)-\dfrac{\pi}{4} \hspace{3em} \big[\,\text{for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$}\,\big]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using mathematical induction, we will prove that $\mathrm{P}(n)$
holds for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$.
  Base case. For $n = 1$, from part (a), we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{(1)^2+1+1}\right) &= \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right) \\[10pt]
  &= \arctan(2)-\arctan(1) \hspace{3em} \big[\text{by part (b,c)}\big]\\[12pt]
  &= \arctan(2)-\dfrac{\pi}{4}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence P$(1)$ holds.
  Inductive hypothesis. We assume that $\mathrm{P}(k)$
holds for some $k \geq 1$. In other words, we assume that

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{r=1}^k \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{r^2+r+1}\right) = \arctan(k+1)-\dfrac{\pi}{4} \hspace{0.5em} \qref{(IH)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  for some $k \geq 1$.
  Inductive step. To show that $\mathrm{P}(k+1)$ holds,
we need to show that

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{r=1}^{k+1} \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{r^2+r+1}\right) = \arctan(k+2)-\dfrac{\pi}{4}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we add the $k+1$ term to both sides of the equation (IH), we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{r=1}^{k+1} \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{r^2+r+1}\right) &= \arctan(k+1)-\dfrac{\pi}{4} + \arctan\left(\dfrac{1}{(k+1)^2+(k+1)+1}\right)\\[10pt]
  \big[\text{by part (c)}\big]\hspace{3em} &= \arctan(k+2) - \arctan(k+1) + \arctan(k+1)-\dfrac{\pi}{4}\\[12pt]
  &= \arctan(k+2)-\dfrac{\pi}{4}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence $P(k+1)$ holds
as well.
  Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k \geq 1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
  Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$.

title: Question 2
content: Let $f(x) = 2x$, $g(x) = 4x + 6$ and $h(x) = (f\circ g)(x)$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find $h(x)$. [2] - Find $h^{-1}(x)$. [3]
markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.3em} h(x) &= (f\circ g)(x) \\[6pt]
  &= f(g(x)) \\[6pt]
  &= f(4x+6) \\[6pt]
  &= 2(4x+6) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 8x+12}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we solve the equation $(h\circ h^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = h^{-1}(x)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h(h^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[12pt]
  h(y) &= x \\[12pt]
  8y+12 &= x \\[12pt]
  8y &= x-12 \\[6pt]
  y &= \dfrac{x-12}{8} \hspace{1.3em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{h^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x-12}{8}}
  $$

title: Question 4
content: Let $f(x) = x^3$ and $g(x) = 2x - 1$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find $g^{-1}(x)$. [2] - Find $(g\circ f)(x)$. [2] - Solve the equation $(g\circ f)(x) = 0$. [2]
markScheme:
- If we solve the equation $(g\circ g^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = g^{-1}(x)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g(g^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[12pt]
  g(y) &= x \\[12pt]
  2y - 1 &= x \\[12pt]
  2y &= x + 1 \\[6pt]
  y &= \dfrac{x + 1}{2} \hspace{1.9em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{g^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x+1}{2}} \hspace{0.6em}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (g\circ f)(x) &= g(f(x)) \\[6pt]
  &= g(x^3) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2x^3-1} \hspace{1.1em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $(g\circ f)(x) = 0$ for $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.5em} 2x^3-1 &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (b)}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{12.2em} \answer{x \approx 0.794} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

title: Question 5
content: Let $f(x) = x^2 + 2$ and $g(x) = x - 3$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find $f(3)$. [2] - Find $(g\circ f)(3)$. [2] - Find $g^{-1}(x)$. [2]
markScheme:
- Evaluating $f(x) = x^2 + 2$ for $x = 3$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.6em} f(3) &= 3^2 + 2 \\[6pt]
  &= 9 + 2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 11}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $(g\circ f)(x) = g(f(x))$ for $x = 3$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.4em} (g\circ f)(3) &= g(f(3)) \\[6pt]
  &= g(11) \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[6pt]
  &= 11 - 3 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 8}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we solve the equation $(g\circ g^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = g^{-1}(x)$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g(g^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[6pt]
  g(y) &= x \\[6pt]
  y - 3 &= x \\[6pt]
  y &= x + 3 \hspace{2.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{g^{-1}(x) = x+3} \hspace{0.8em}
  $$

title: Question 7
content: Let $f(x)=4x-2$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - The graph of a linear function $g$ is perpendicular to the graph of $f$ and passes through the origin. Find an expression for $g(x)$.[2] - The graph of a linear function $h$ is parallel to the graph of $f$ and passes through the point $(3,4)$. Find an expression for $h(x)$. [3]
markScheme:
- The slope of $f$ is $m_f=4$, then $m_g=-\dfrac{1}{4}$ is the slope of the function $g$ that is perpendicular to $f$, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  y-y_1&=m(x-x_1)\\[6pt]
   y-0&=-\dfrac{1}{4}(x-0)\\[6pt]
   y&=-\dfrac{1}{4}x
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Therefore, $\tcbhighmath{g(x)=-\dfrac{1}{4}x}.$
- The slope of the function $h$ is $m_h=4$ because $h$ is parallel to the graph $f$. We have,

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  y-y_1=m(x-x_1)\\[6pt]
  y-4&=4(x-3)\\[6pt]
  y-4&=4x-12\\[6pt]
  y=4x-8
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Therefore, $\tcbhighmath{h(x)=4x-8}.$

title: Question 10
content: The equation of a line $L_1$ is $2x + 3y = -5$. - Find the gradient of $L_1$. [2] A second line, $L_2$, is perpendicular to $L_1$. - State the gradient of $L_2$. [1] The point P$(4,0)$ lies on $L_2$. - Find the equation of $L_2$, giving your answer in the form $ax + by + d = 0$, where $a, b, d \in \mathbb{Z}$. [2] The point Q is the intersection of $L_1$ and $L_2$. - Find the coordinates of Q. [3]
markScheme:
- If we rewrite the equation of $L_1$ in the form $y = mx + c$, we
have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2x + 3y &= -5 \\[12pt]
  3y &= -2x - 5 \\[6pt]
  y &= -\dfrac{2}{3}x-\dfrac{5}{3} \hspace{0.4em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the gradient of $L_1$ is
$\answer{m_{L_1} = -\dfrac{2}{3}}$
- The gradient of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9em} m_{L_2} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{L_1}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $L_2 \perp L_1$}] \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{1}{(-2/3)} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{3}{2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the point-gradient formula with P$(4,0)$ and $m = 3/2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.2em} y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[5pt]
  y - 0 &= \dfrac{3}{2}\hspace{0.05em}(x - 4) \\[6pt]
  2y &= 3x - 12 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{3.45em} \answer{0 = 3x - 2y - 12}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  L_1&:\hspace{1.0em} 2x + 3y = -5 \hspace{3em}{(1)} \\[6pt]
  L_2&:\hspace{1.0em} 3x - 2y = 12 \hspace{3.25em}{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Solving
the system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $x$ and $y$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \hspace{-0.8em} \begin{array}{rcl}
  x &=& 2 \\[6pt]
  y &=& -3
  \end{array}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of Q are
$\answer{(2,-3)}$

title: Question 13
content: Let $f(x) = x^3 + 1$ and $g(x) = x-2$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find $f(2)$. [2] - Find $f^{-1}(x)$. [2] - Solve $(f\circ g)(x) = 0$. [3]
markScheme:
- Evaluating $f(x) = x^3 + 1$ for $x = 2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.6em} f(2) &= 2^3 + 1 \\[6pt]
  &= 8 + 1 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 9}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for $y = f^{-1}(x)$,
we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.6em} f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[6pt]
  f(y) &= x \\[6pt]
  y^3 + 1 &= x \\[6pt]
  y^3 &= x - 1 \\[5pt]
  y &= \sqrt[3]{x-1} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{2em} \answer{f^{-1}(x) = \sqrt[3]{x-1}}
  $$

- Solving the equation $(f\circ g)(x) = 0$ for $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(g(x)) &= 0 \\[7pt]
  f(x-2) &= 0 \\[6pt]
  \hspace{4.6em} (x-2)^3 + 1 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  x-2 &= \sqrt[3]{-1} \hspace{3em} [=-1] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.7em} \answer{x = 1}
  $$

title: Question 15
content: The following diagram shows the graph of $y = f(x)$, for $-4 \leq x \leq 5$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c34c19d0-884e-4539-a819-e275c2b0d6d7/images/663b2cb7-2f4f-4aae-ac6f-66128af5d430/8dc73726e7704b5f5e31e8ab0e8d2ebbdc109321.svg) - Write down the value of: - $f(1)$; - $f^{-1}(2)$. [2] - Find the domain of $f^{-1}$. [2] - Sketch the graph of $y = f^{-1}(x)$ on the same grid above. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - $\answer{f(1) = 3}$
  - $\answer{f^{-1}(2) = 0}$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{domain of $f^{-1}$} &= \text{range of $f$} \hspace{1.7em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= [-2,4]}\end{aligned}

- The graph of $y = f^{-1}(x)$ is a reflection of the graph of
$y = f(x)$ across the line $y = x$.
  Hence, if we sketch the graph of $y = f^{-1}(x)$ on the same grid

title: Question 16
content: - Express $2x^2 - 8x + 9$ in the form $a(x+b)^2 + c$ where $a,b,c \in\mathbb{Z}$. [2] - Given that $f(x) = x - 2$ and $(g\circ f)(x) = 2x^2 - 8x + 9$, find $g(x)$. [3]
markScheme:
- Using the method of completing the square, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2x^2 - 8x + 9 &= 2\big[x^2 - 4x\big] + 9 \\[6pt]
  &= 2\big[(x-2)^2 - 4\big] + 9 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
  &= 2(x-2)^2 - 8 + 9 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2(x-2)^2 + 1}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.3em} (g\circ f)(x) &= 2x^2 - 8x + 9 \\[6pt]
  g(f(x)) &=  2(x-2)^2 + 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[6pt]
  g(x-2) &= 2(x-2)^2 + 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{since $f(x) = x - 2$}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{g(x) = 2x^2 + 1} \hspace{3.4em}
  $$

title: Question 17
content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{\ln(x+2)}{2}$, for $x > -2$. The diagram below shows part of the graph of $f$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5ca4f0d8-2c1b-4539-b90a-140704aebde0/images/41cb6db4-c952-44a9-a5d0-dc5fd6907d15/0b26b0e195f4a087c10216491d624f903712efff.svg) - Find the coordinates of: - the $x$-intercept; - the $y$-intercept. [2] - Find the equation of the vertical asymptote to the graph of $f$. [2] - Find the area of the region enclosed by the graph of $f$, the $x$-axis and the $y$-axis. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.8em} \dfrac{\ln(x+2)}{2} &= 0 \\[4pt]
    x &= -1 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are
$\answer{(-1,0)}$
  - Evaluating $f(x)=\dfrac{\ln(x+2)}{2}$ for $x = 0$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.4em} f(0) &= \dfrac{\ln 2}{2} \\[8pt] 
    &\approx 0.347\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the
$y$-intercept are
$\answer{(0,0.347)}$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x \rightarrow 0^+} \ln x &= -\infty \hspace{3em} \\[7pt]
  \lim_{x \rightarrow -2^+} \ln (x+2) &= -\infty \\[6pt]
  \lim_{x \rightarrow -2^+} f(x) &= -\infty \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence
the equation of the vertical asymptote is
$\answer{x = -2}$
- The area of the region enclosed by the graph of $f$, the $x$-axis
and the $y$-axis is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{10em} A &= \int_{-1}^0 \dfrac{\ln(x+2)}{2}\,\mathrm{d}x \\[8pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.193 \text{ units}^2} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 18
content: Let $f(x) = e^x - 2$ and $g(x) = 3x + k$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where $k$ is a constant. - Find $(g\circ f)(x)$. [2] - Given that $\displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} (g\circ f)(x) = -4$, find the value of $k$. [3]
markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.8em} (g\circ f)(x) &= g(f(x)) \\[6pt]
  &= g(e^x - 2) \\[6pt]
  &= 3(e^x - 2) + k \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 3e^x - 6 + k}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty} (g\circ f)(x) &= -4 \hspace{6.9em} \\[4pt]
  \lim_{x \rightarrow -\infty}\hspace{-0.2em}\big[3e^x - 6 + k\big] &= -4 \\[4pt]
  3(0) - 6 + k &= -4 \\[9pt]
  - 6 + k &= -4 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.2em} \answer{k = 2}
  $$

title: Question 25
content: The function $f$ is given by $f(x) = \dfrac{4x^2 - 128}{x^2 - 16}$, for $x \neq \pm 4$. - Prove that $f$ is an even function. [2] - - Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. - Write down the range of $f$. [5]
markScheme:
- For any $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $x \neq \pm 4$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(-x) &= \dfrac{4(-x)^2 - 128}{(-x)^2 - 16} \\[5pt]
  &= \dfrac{4x^2 - 128}{x^2 - 16} \\[12pt]
  &= f(x)\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence $f$ is an even function.
- 
  - If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we
have

title: Question 28
content: A tyre manufacturing company has found that the number of tyres it produces, $N$, can be modelled by the function $$ N(t)=3t-9 $$ where $t$ is the number of hours the factory operates per day, with a minimum of 3 hours. The profit the company makes, $P$, in dollars, depends on the number of tyres produced, and is modelled by the function $$ P(N)=60N-850 $$ where $N$ is the number of tyres produced. - Find the company's profit or loss if it operates for $6$ hours per day.[2] - Find the company's profit in terms of the hours of operation per day, $t$.[2] - Determine the number of hours the company needs to operate the factory per day in order to earn a positive profit. Give your answer to the nearest hour.[2]
markScheme:
- Substituting $t=6$ in $N(t)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  N(6) &= 3(6)-9 = 9\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Thus, the profit is given by P(9)

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
   P(9) &= 60(9)-850 = -310
   \end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore, operating $6$
hours a day, the company has a loss:
$\boxed{\text{-310}}$
- The profit in terms of the hours of operation per day can be found
by the composite function $P\circ N$. Hence, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (P\circ N)(t) &= P(N(t)) \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  &= P(3t-9) \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}\\
  &= 60(3t-9)-850\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}\\
  &\hspace{-5em}\answer{(P\circ N)(t) = 180\hspace{0.05em}t-1390}\hspace{5em}{(1)}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{4mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The company has a positive profit if (1) is greater than 0. Hence

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (P\circ N)(t) &>0\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  180t-1390 &> 0 \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  t &> \dfrac{1390}{180} \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  t &> 7.72.\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore, the
factory needs to operate
$\answer{8}$
hours per day in order for the company to earn a positive profit.

title: Question 34
content:
The function $f$ is defined as $f(x) = \sqrt{\dfrac{6+2x}{6-2x}}$, for
$-3 \leq x < 3$.
Find the inverse function of $f$, stating its domain and range.
markScheme:
If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for $y = f^{-1}(x)$,
we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[16pt]
f(y) &= x \\[11pt]
\sqrt{\dfrac{6+2y}{6-2y}} &= x \\[6pt]
\dfrac{6+2y}{6-2y} &= x^2 \\[12pt]
6 + 2y &= 6x^2-2x^2y \\[16pt]
3 + y &= 3x^2-x^2y \\[16pt]
(x^2 + 1)y &= 3x^2 - 3 \\[12pt]
y &= \dfrac{3x^2 - 3}{x^2 + 1} \hspace{3em}  \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the
inverse function of $f$ is
$\answer{f^{-1}(x) =  \dfrac{3x^2 - 3}{x^2 + 1}}$
The domain of $f^{-1}$ is
$\answer{[0,\infty)}$
and range of $f^{-1}$ is
$\answer{[-3,3)}$

content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{5}{x+1}$, for $x \neq -1$. - For the graph of $f$, find: - the $x$-intercept; - the $y$-intercept; - the equation of the vertical asymptote. [5] Let $g(x) = x-3$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. The graphs of $f$ and $g$ intersect at points A and B. - Find the coordinates of A and B. [5] - Find the equation of the straight line that passes through A and B, giving your answer in the form $y = mx + c$. [3] - Write down the gradient of the line that is perpendicular to the line passing through A and B. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - Since the equation $f(x) = 0$ has no solutions, there are
$\answer{\text{no \(x\)-intercepts}}$
  - Evaluating $f(x) = \dfrac{5}{x+1}$ for $x = 0$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f(0) &= \dfrac{5}{0+1} \hspace{3.6em} \\[6pt]
    &= 5\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the $y$-intercept is
$\answer{\mathrm{P}(0,5)}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    &= 0 \hspace{4em} \\[6pt]
    x+1 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &= -1\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the vertical
asymptote is
$\answer{x = -1}$

- Solving the equation $f(x) = g(x)$ for $x$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} \dfrac{5}{x+1} &= x-3 \\[6pt]
  5 &= (x+1)(x-3) \\[9pt]
  5 &= x^2 - 2x - 3 \\[9pt]
  0 &= x^2 - 2x - 8 \\[10pt]
  0 &= (x+2)(x-4) \\[10pt]
  x &= -2,\hspace{0.25em}4 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $g(x) = x-3$
for $x = -2$ and $x = 4$, we find

  $$
  \hspace{3.1em} \begin{array}{rcccl}
  y &=& g(-2) &=& -5 \\[9pt]
  y &=& g(4) &=& 1
  \end{array}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{\mathrm{A}(-2,-5)}$
and
$\answer{\mathrm{B}(4,1)}$
- Using the gradient formula with A$(-2,-5)$ and B$(4,1)$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{\mathrm{AB}} &= \dfrac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1-(-5)}{4-(-2)} \\[10pt]
  &= 1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the point-gradient formula with
A$(-2,-5)$ and $m = 1$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[6pt]
  \hspace{0.15em} y - (-5) &= (1)(x-(-2)) \\[6pt]
  y + 5 &= x + 2 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{y = x-3} \hspace{0.15em}
  $$

- $\answer{m_{\perp\mathrm{AB}} = -1}$

title: Question 43
content: Consider $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{2} - \ln\left(\sqrt{x^2-4}\right)$. - Find the largest possible domain $D$ for $f$ to be a function. [2] The function $f$ is defined by $f(x) = \dfrac{1}{2} - \ln\left(\sqrt{x^2-4}\right)$, for $x \in D$. - Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, showing clearly the equations of asymptotes and the coordinates of any intercepts with the axes. [3] - Explain why $f$ is an even function. [1] - Explain why the inverse function $f^{-1}$ does not exist. [1] The function $g$ is defined by $g(x) = \dfrac{1}{2} - \ln\left(\sqrt{x^2-4}\right)$, for $x \in (2,\infty)$. - Find the inverse function $g^{-1}$ and state its domain. [4]
markScheme:
- The square root function is defined on $[0,\infty)$ and natural
logarithm function is defined on $(0,\infty)$.
  Hence $f$ is a function if

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \textstyle \sqrt{x^2-4} &> 0 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
  x^2-4 &> 0 \\[6pt]
  x^2 &> 4 \\[6pt]
  |x| &> 2 \\[6pt]
  x < -2 \hspace{0.5em}&\hspace{0.2em}\text{or}\hspace{0.7em} x > 2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the largest possible domain for $f$ to be a function is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{D = (-\infty,-2)\cup(2,\infty)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/18ea91ad-1794-4924-860f-5cce1a2aaaa5/images/52aadecb-f956-431e-9b31-87bfc4bc127b/c292af76cbb30669709b70ec8dbfa255472cb0f7.svg)


- $\answer{\text{The function \(f\) is even because its graph is symmetric about the \(y\)-axis.}}$
  OR
  $\answer{\text{The function \(f\) is even because it satisfies \(f(x) = f(-x)\) for all \(x \in D\).}}$
- $\answer{\text{The inverse function \(f^{-1}\) does not exist because \(f\) is not bijective.}}$
- If we solve the equation $(g\circ g^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = g^{-1}(x)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  g(g^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[15pt]
  g(y) &= x \\[10pt]
  \dfrac{1}{2} - \textstyle \ln\hspace{-0.1em}\big(\sqrt{y^2-4}\big) &= x \\[6pt]
  \textstyle \ln\hspace{-0.1em}\big(\sqrt{y^2-4}\big) &= \dfrac{1}{2} - x  \\[9pt]
  \textstyle \sqrt{y^2-4} &= e^{\left(\frac{1}{2} - x\right)} \\[12pt]
  y^2-4 &= e^{2\left(\frac{1}{2} - x\right)} \\[14pt]
  y^2 &= e^{1 - 2x} + 4 \\[13pt]
  y &= \textstyle \sqrt{e^{1 - 2x} + 4} \hspace{2.7em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence an expression for $g^{-1}$ is
$\answer{g^{-1}(x) = \sqrt{e^{1 - 2x} + 4}}$
  The domain of $g^{-1}$ is
$\answer{\mathbb{R}}$

title: Question 45
content: The graph of $y=f(x)$ for $0\leq x \leq 6$ is shown below ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/d9b698f4-a101-40b3-a118-dbc3aa80bdc7/AA1279-q1.JPEG) The odd function $h(x)$ has the domain $-6\leq x \leq 6$ and $h(x)=2f(x)$ for $0\leq x \leq 6$. - Sketch $h(x)$ on the axes above.[2] $f(x)$ is shown again below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/3a60566c-11b7-4cc2-ac58-301a1f0b734a/AA1279-q2.JPEG) - Sketch the graph of $y=[f(x)]^2$ on the axes above.[3] $f(x)$ is shown one more time below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/6712f3c3-7980-49b2-be9d-09510dd7213d/AA1279-q3.JPEG) - Sketch the graph of $y=\dfrac{1}{f(x)}$ on the axes above.[3]
markScheme:
- Let's start with graphing $y=2f(x)$.
  This is a vertical stretch by a scale factor of 2.
  The distance of all $y-$coordinates from the $x-$axis are multiplied by two.
  The key point $(2, 2)$ will become $(2, 4)$.  This is shown in the graph below in $\textcolor{red}{\text{red}}$.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/ee8f2b59-189d-4582-b80f-8543d1539c11/AA1279-a1.JPEG)


  The definition of an odd function is $f(-x)=-f(x)$. This transformation represents rotational symmetry of order $2$ about the origin which is equivalent to performing two reflections, one in each axis, in any order.
  Therefore, to complete the rest of the graph of $h(x)$, we can either take the graph of $y=2f(x)$ and rotate it $180^\circ$ about the origin or perform two reflections, one in each axis. Both result in the same final position.
  If we consider the reflection approach. First, we perform $f(x) \rightarrow f(-x)$, this is a reflection in the $y-$axis. This is the dotted blue line shown in the following graph.
  Then we consider $f(-x)\rightarrow-f(-x)$, this is a reflection in the $x-$axis.
  This fully transformed part is shown in solid $\textcolor{blue}{\text{blue}}$ in the following graph.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/e98b48c5-6b88-483c-9505-e090a80ebdda/AA1279-a2.JPEG)


  The final graph of $y=h(x)$ is shown below
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/36471d45-1f48-4d32-ac28-33498e303129/AA1279-a3.JPEG)



  $$
  \begin{align*}
      \answer{\text{Correct points at }(-2, -4)\text{ and }(-6,0)}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]
       \answer{\text{Correct transformation(s)}}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- First, let's look at the section of the graph $0\leq x \leq 2$.
  We can use the properties of the transformation $[f(x)]^2$ to identify some key points.
  We know that if $f(x)=0$ then $[f(x)]^2=0$.
  We also know that if $f(x)=1$ then $[f(x)]^2=1$.
  It is important to also realise that if $-1<f(x)<1$ then $[f(x)]^2<f(x)$.
  Therefore between $0<x<1$ then $[f(x)]^2<f(x)$.
  Using the end point of the first part of the curve we can see that $[f(2)]^2=4$.
  Using the key points $(0,0)$, $(1,1)$ and $(2,4)$ we can sketch the transformed curve, shown in $\textcolor{red}{\text{red}}$
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/1850a5f9-cc57-42c9-aced-4f5076f93f70/AA1279-a4.JPEG)


  Now, let's look at the section of the graph $2\leq x \leq 6$.
  We know the second section will start at $(2,4)$ and finish at $(6,0)$.
  Using the property if $f(x)=1$ then $[f(x)]^2=1$ we know the curve will intersect the original function at $f(x)=1$.
  Which we can see is at $(4,1)$.
  It is important to clearly show on the graph that $[f(x)]^2<f(x)$ when $0<f(x)<1$.
  With this in mind, using the key points $(2,4)$, $(1,4)$ and $(6,0)$ we can sketch the second part, shown in $\textcolor{blue}{\text{blue}}$
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/df6ea7d7-12e8-4c02-9e9e-59b469c720e1/AA1279-a5.JPEG)

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      &\answer{\text{Correct shape}}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]
      &\answer{\text{$f(x)=[f(x)]^2$ when $f(x)=0,1$}}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]
      &\answer{\text{$[f(x)]^2$} \text{ is less than } f(x) \text{ when } 0<f(x)<1}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Let's start by drawing the vertical asymptotes.
  They will occur at the $x$-intercepts of $f(x)$ which are $x=0$ and $x=6$. Shown below as the dotted red vertical lines
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c12c7015-df65-4beb-b764-cc77e7025623/images/e1ad22e1-6249-4f31-ba13-092dd647afbb/AA1279-a7.JPEG)

  Considering the asymptotes, we can see that as $x\rightarrow 0$ and $x\rightarrow 6$ then $f(x)\rightarrow 0$ (from the positive direction) therefore $\frac{1}{f(x)}\rightarrow \infty^+$.
  Hence we get the graph below in $\textcolor{blue}{\text{blue}}$.

title: Question 48
content: The function $f$ is defined by $f(x) = 1+ \dfrac{4x}{x+3}$, for $x \neq -3$. - Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, indicating clearly any asymptotes and points of intersection with the $x$ and $y$ axes. [4] - Find an expression for $f^{-1}$. [4] - Find all values of $x$ for which $f(x) = f^{-1}(x)$. [3] - Solve the inequality $|f(x)| < 2$. [4] - Solve the inequality $f(|x|) < 2$. [2]
markScheme:
- If we solve the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  1+ \dfrac{4x}{x+3} &= 0 \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{5x+3}{x+3} &= 0 \\[11pt]
  5x + 3 &= 0 \\[10pt]
  x &= -\dfrac{3}{5} \hspace{2.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point
P$(-3/5,0)$ is the $x$-intercept of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
  &= 1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point Q$(0,1)$ is the $y$-intercept of
the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lim_{x \rightarrow\pm\infty} f(x) &= 1 + \dfrac{4}{1} \hspace{3.7em} \\[6pt]
  &= 5\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the line $y = 5$ is a horizontal asymptote
of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  The denominator of $f$ is zero when $x = -3$. Hence the line
$x = -3$
is a vertical asymptote of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
  If we sketch of the graph of $y = f(x)$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b02f9456-fc87-4d72-8046-b8ad6f17fd88/images/80e5d1bc-25e1-48da-ad0b-cf11c4df076c/a4ee5024679811f4302b4cf52d17f68170c60827.svg)


- If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y = f^{-1}(x)$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \hspace{3.7em}  \\[8pt]
  f\left(y\right) &= x\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.7em} 1+ \dfrac{4y}{y+3} &= x \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{5y+3}{y+3} &= x \\[10pt]
  5y+3 &= xy+3x \\[16pt]
  (5-x)y &= 3x-3 \\[10pt]
  y &= \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence an expression for
$f^{-1}$ is
$\answer{f^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x}}$
- If we solve the equation $f(x) = f^{-1}(x)$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(x) &= f^{-1}(x) \\[9pt]
  1 + \dfrac{4x}{x+3} &= \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{5x+3}{x+3} &= \dfrac{3x-3}{5-x} \\[10pt]
  (5x+3)(5-x) &= (3x-3)(x+3) \\[12pt]
  \hspace{1.6em} 25x - 5x^2 + 15 -3x &= 3x^2 + 9x -3x - 9 \\[12pt]
  -8x^2 + 16x + 24 &= 0\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x^2 - 2x - 3 &= 0 \\[12pt]
  (x+1)(x-3) &= 0 \hspace{4em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{3.6em} \answer{x = -1,\hspace{0.25em}3}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \hspace{8.1em} \begin{array}{rcccl}
  && |f(x)| &<& 2 \\[13pt]
  -2 &<& f(x) &<& 2 \\[12pt]
  f^{-1}(-2) &<& x &<& f^{-1}(2) \hspace{2em} [\text{since $f^{-1}(f(x)) = x$}]
  \end{array}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $y = f^{-1}(x)$ for $x = -2$,
we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.4em} f^{-1}(-2) &= \dfrac{3(-2)-3}{5-(-2)} \\[3pt]
  &= -\dfrac{9}{7} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $y = f^{-1}(x)$ for
$x = 2$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.2em} f^{-1}(2) &= \dfrac{3(2)-3}{5-2}  \hspace{0.8em} \\[8pt]
  &= 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the set of solutions to the inequality
$|f(x)| < 2$ is
$\answer{-\frac{9}{7}<x<1}$
- If we solve the inequality $f(|x|) < 2$ for $|x|$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.5em} 1+ \dfrac{4|x|}{|x|+3} &< 2 \\[5pt]
  \dfrac{4|x|}{|x|+3} &< 1 \\[10pt]
  4|x| &< |x|+3 \\[16pt]
  3|x| &< 3 \\[16pt]
  |x| &< 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the set of solutions to the
inequality $f(|x|) < 2$ is
$\answer{-1<x<1}$
