title: Question 51
content: The function $f$ is defined by $f(x) = e^{2x}-4e^x+2$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $x \leq a$, where $a \in \mathbb{R}$. Part of the graph of $y = f(x)$ is shown in the following diagram. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4c5c56b3-ccff-4218-8eeb-ed43662a5361/images/6b8a627c-1929-4344-ac27-a9f1d77bd6ab/dc14321f698d30780f4ecaf20c082a22181a9565.svg) - Find the largest value of $a$ such that $f$ has an inverse function. [3] - For this value of $a$, find an expression for $f^{-1}(x)$, stating its domain. [5]
markScheme:
- From the diagram, we see that the $x$-coordinate of the local
minimum point on the graph of $y = f(x)$ is the largest value of $a$
such that $f$ has an inverse function.
  We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f'(x) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}\big[e^{2x}-4e^x+2\big] \\[6pt]
  &= 2e^{2x}-4e^x \\[9pt]
  &= \big[2e^x\big]\big[e^x - 2\big]\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we solve the equation $f'(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \big[2e^x\big]\big[e^x - 2\big] &= 0 \hspace{5.2em} \\[6pt]
  e^x - 2 &= 0 \\[7pt]
  e^x &= 2 \\[7pt]
  x &= \ln 2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{a = \ln 2}$
- If we solve the equation $(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x$ for
$y =  f^{-1}(x)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \hspace{3em} [\text{where $-2 \leq x < 2$}] \\[9pt]
  f(y) &= x \hspace{3em} [\text{where $y \leq \ln 2$}] \\[7pt]
  e^{2y}-4e^y+2 &= x \\[7pt]
  \big[(e^y)^2-4e^y\big]+2 &= x \\[7pt]
  \hspace{7.1em} \big[(e^y-2)^2 - 4\big]+2 &= x \hspace{3em} [\text{by completing the square}] \\[7pt]
  (e^y-2)^2 &= x+2 \\[7pt]
  e^y-2 &= \pm\sqrt{x+2} \\[7pt]
  e^y-2 &= -\sqrt{x+2} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $y \leq \ln 2$}] \\[7pt]
  e^y &= 2-\sqrt{x+2} \\[7pt]
  y &= \ln (2-\sqrt{x+2})\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{f^{-1}(x) = \ln (2-\sqrt{x+2}), \text{ for } x \in \mathbb{R}, -2 \leq x < 2}$

title: Question 52
content: This question asks you to investigate some properties of even and odd functions. Consider the functions $f_1(x)=\dfrac{5}{x^3}$ and $f_2(x)=3x^2+8$. - Determine whether: - The function $f_1(x)$ is an even function or an odd function, - The function $f_2(x)$ is an even function or an odd function.[4] Suppose $g(x)$ is a function with domain $\mathbb{R}$ and let $h$ and $j$ be the functions $$ \begin{align*} h(x)=\dfrac{g(x)+g(-x)}{2},\quad j(x)=\dfrac{g(x)-g(-x)}{2}\\[-12pt] \end{align*} $$ - - Show that $g(x)=h(x)+j(x).$ - Hence, show that $g(x)$ is the sum of an even and an odd function.[4] - Using the results from part (b), find the even part and the odd part of $g(x)=x^4+4x^3+5x^2-2x$[3] Let $f(x)$ be a function that is differentiable for all $x \in \mathbb{R}.$ - Show that: - if $f(x)$ is an even function, then $f'(x)$ is an odd function - if $f(x)$ is an odd function, then $f'(x)$ is an even function.[4] - Show that if $f(x)$ is an even function defined and differentiable at $x=0,$ then: - $f'(0)=0$, - $f^{2k+1}(0)=0$ for $k \in \mathbb{Z}^+$, - its Maclaurin series expansion contains only even powers of $x$.[5] - Show that if $f(x)$ is an odd function, then its Maclaurin series expansion contains only odd powers of $x.$ [5]
markScheme:
- 
  - Evaluating $f_1$ at $-x$, we get

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    f_1(-x) & =\dfrac{5}{(-x)^3} \\[8pt]
    &=-\dfrac{5}{x^3}\\[8pt]
    &= -f_1(x) \\[-10pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Since $f_1(-x)=-f_1(x)$, $\answer{\text{the function } f_1(x) \text{ is an odd function.}}$
  - Evaluating $f_2$ at $-x$, we get

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    f_2(-x) &=3(-x)^2+8 \\[8pt]
    &=3x^2+8\\[8pt]
    &= f_2(x) \\[-10pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Since $f_2(-x)=f_2(x),$ $\answer{\text{the function } f_2(x) \text{ is an even function.}}$

- 
  - Taking the sum of $h$ and $j$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    h(x)+j(x)&=\dfrac{g(x)+g(-x)}{2}+\dfrac{g(x)-g(-x)}{2}\\[12pt]
    &=\dfrac{2g(x)}{2}\\[12pt]
    &\hspace{-5.2em}\tcbhighmath{h(x)+j(x) = g(x)}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - Evaluating $h$ at $-x$, we get

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    h(-x)&=\dfrac{g(-x)+g(x)}{2}\\[12pt]
    &= \dfrac{g(x)+g(-x)}{2} \\[12pt]
    &=h(x)\\[-11pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore, $h(x)$ is an even function.
    Now, evaluating $j$ at $-x$, we get

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    j(-x)&=\dfrac{g(-x)-g(x)}{2}\\[12pt]
    &=-\dfrac{g(x)-g(-x)}{2}\\[12pt]
    &=-j(x)\\[-11pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore, $j(x)$ is an odd function.
    Since $g(x)=h(x)+j(x)$, any function $g(x)$ can be written as the sum of an even function and an odd function.

- Evaluating $g$ at $-x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  g(-x)&=(-x)^4+4(-x)^3+5(-x)^2-2(-x)\\[12pt]
  &=x^4-4x^3+5x^2+2x
  \end{align*}
  $$

  From part (b), the even part of $g(x)$ is $h(x)$.

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  h(x)&=\dfrac{g(x)+g(-x)}{2} \\[12pt]
  &=\dfrac{(x^4+4x^3+5x^2-2x)+(x^4-4x^3+5x^2+2x)}{2}\\[12pt]
  &=\dfrac{2x^4+10x^2}{2}\\[12pt]
  &\hspace{0.275em}\tcbhighmath{= x^4+5x^2}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The odd part of $g(x)$ is $j(x)$.

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  j(x)&=\dfrac{g(x)-g(-x)}{2}\\[12pt]
  &=\dfrac{(x^4+4x^3+5x^2-2x)-(x^4-4x^3+5x^2+2x)}{2}\\[12pt]
  &=\dfrac{8x^3-4x}{2}\\[12pt]    
  &\hspace{0.275em}\tcbhighmath{=4x^3-2x }
  \end{align*}
  $$

- 
  - Let's suppose that $f(x)$ is an even function. Thus, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    f(-x) &= f(x) \\[12pt]
    -f'(-x) &= f'(x)\\[12pt]
    f'(-x) &= -f'(x)\\[-9pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore,$\,\,\answer{\text{ $f'(x)$ is an odd function.}}$
  - Let's suppose that $f(x)$ is an odd function. Thus, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    f(-x) &= -f(x) \\[12pt]
    -f'(-x)&=-f'(x)\\[12pt]
    f'(-x) &= f'(x)\\[-9pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore, $\,\answer{\text{ $f'(x)$ is an even function.}}$

- 
  - By part (d), if $f(x)$ is an even function then $f'(x)$ is an odd function. We get

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    f'(-0)&=-f'(0)\\[12pt]
    f'(0) &=-f'(0)\\[12pt]
    2f'(0) &= 0 \\[12pt]
    &\hspace{-2.4em}\tcbhighmath{f'(0) = 0}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - Using part (d) (i), $f(x)$ even $\Rightarrow f'(x)$ odd.
    Using part (d) (ii), $f'(x)$ odd $\Rightarrow f''(x)$ even.
    By iteration, we have that every odd derivative is an odd function and every even derivative is an even function. That is, $f^{2k+1}(x)$ is odd and $f^{2k}(x)$ is even for $k \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. Hence,

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    f^{2k+1}(-x)&=-f^{2k+1}(x)\\[12pt]
    f^{2k+1}(-0)&=-f^{2k+1}(0)\\[12pt]
    f^{2k+1}(0) &=-f^{2k+1}(0)\\[12pt]
    2f^{2k+1}(0) &= 0 \\[12pt]
    &\hspace{-3.85em}\tcbhighmath{f^{2k+1}(0) = 0}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - The Maclaurin series expansion of $f(x)$ is

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    f(x)=f(0)+xf'(0)+\dfrac{x^2}{2!}f''(0)+\dfrac{x^3}{3!}f^{(3)}(0)+\cdots
    \end{align*}
    $$

    From part (ii), $f'(0)=0$ and $f^{2k+1}(0)=0$ for $k \in \mathbb{Z}^+$, which means that
    The only non-zero terms remaining in the Maclaurin series expansion are those of the form $\dfrac{x^{2k}}{(2k)!}f^{2k}(0)$, those with even powers of $x$, including the constant term.

- By part (d), if $f(x)$ is an odd function then $f'(x)$ is an even function and $f''(x)$ is an odd function. Using parts (d) (i) and (ii), by iteration, every even derivative is an odd function.
  We can say that $f^{2k}(x)$ is an odd function for $k \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. Thus, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  f^{2k}(-x) &= -f^{2k}(x) \\[12pt]
  f^{2k}(-0)&=-f^{2k}(0)\\[12pt]
  f^{2k}(0)&=-f^{2k}(0)\\[12pt]
  2f^{2k}(0) &= 0 \\[12pt]
  f^{2k}(0) &= 0
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The Maclaurin series expansion of $f(x)$ is

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  f(x)=f(0)+xf'(0)+\dfrac{x^2}{2!}f''(0)+\dfrac{x^3}{3!}f^{(3)}(0)+\cdots
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Therefore the terms with even powers in the Maclaurin series of $f(x)$ vanish and the Maclaurin series of $f(x)$ contains only terms with odd powers of $x$.

title: Question 4
content: Let $f(x) = x^2 - 2x - 8$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. - Write down the $y$-intercept of the graph of $y = f(x)$. [1] - Solve the equation $f(x) = 0$. [3] - Find the equation of the axis of symmetry of the graph of $y = f(x)$. [2]
markScheme:
- Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6em} y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
  &= 0^2 - 2(0) - 8 \\[6pt]
  &= -8\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the point
$\answer{\mathrm{P}(0,-8)}$
is the $y$-intercept of the graph of $y = f(x)$.
- Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x^2 - 2x - 8 &= 0 \hspace{4.8em} \\[6pt]
  (x + 2)(x - 4) &= 0 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{2.8em} \answer{x = -2,\hspace{0.25em} 4}
  $$

- Using the method of completing the square, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.7em} f(x) &= x^2 - 2x - 8 \\[6pt]
  &= \big[(x - 1)^2 - 1\big] - 8 \\[6pt]
  &= (x - 1)^2 - 9\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the axis of symmetry of the
graph of $y = f(x)$ is
$\answer{x = 1}$

title: Question 5
content: Let $f(x) = (x - 3)(x + 1)$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. For the graph of $f$, find: - the $y$-intercept; [2] - the $x$-intercepts; [2] - the coordinates of the vertex. [3]
markScheme:
- Evaluating $f(x) = (x - 3)(x + 1)$ for $x = 0$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4em} f(0) &= (0 - 3)(0 + 1) \\[6pt] 
  &= (-3)(1) \\[6pt]
  &= -3\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the $y$-intercept is
$\answer{\mathrm{A}(0,-3)}$
- Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (x - 3)(x + 1) &= 0 \\[6pt]
  x &= -1,\hspace{0.25em} 3 \hspace{1.5em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the
$x$-intercepts are
$\answer{\mathrm{B}(-1,0)}$
and
$\answer{\mathrm{C}(3,0)}$
- Using the method of completing the square, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.8em} f(x) &= (x - 3)(x + 1) \\[6pt]
  &= x^2 - 2x - 3 \\[6pt]
  &= \big[(x-1)^2 - 1\big] - 3 \\[6pt]
  &= (x-1)^2 - 4\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of the vertex
are  $\answer{(1,-4)}$

title: Question 6
content:
The equation $x^2 + kx + 4 = 0$ has two equal roots.
Find the possible values of $k$.
markScheme:
Since the quadratic function $q(x) = x^2 + kx + 4$ has two equal roots,
we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{6.9em} [\text{discriminant of $q$}] &= 0 \\[6pt]
k^2 - 4(1)(4) &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\triangle  = b^2 - 4ac] \\[6pt]
k^2 - 16 &= 0 \\[6pt]
k^2 &= 16 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{5.9em} \answer{k = \pm 4}
$$

title: Question 11
content: Consider $f(x) = x^2 + bx + c$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where $b,c \in \mathbb{Z}$. The graph of $f$ has a local minimum when $x = 2.5$. The distance between the two $x$-intercepts of the graph of $f$ is $7$. - Find the coordinates of the two $x$-intercepts. [2] - Find the value of $b$ and the value of $c$. [4]
markScheme:
- The axis of symmetry of the graph of $f$ is $x = 2.5$.
Hence the coordinates of the two $x$-intercepts are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \bigg(2.5-\frac{7}{2},0\bigg) = \hspace{0.525em}\answer{(-1,0)}\hspace{0.525em} \hspace{1em}\text{and}\hspace{1em}
  \bigg(2.5+\frac{7}{2},0\bigg) = \hspace{0.525em}\answer{(6,0)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The roots of the quadratic function $f(x) = x^2 + bx + c$ are
$x = -1$ and $x = 6$.
  Hence, using the factor theorem, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.4em} f(x) &= (x + 1)(x - 6) \\[6pt]
  &= x^2 - 5x - 6\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{b = -5}$
and  $\answer{c = -6}$

title: Question 14
content: A farmer is going to fence two equal adjacent parcels of land. These parcels share one side (which also requires fencing) as shown in the following diagram. The farmer has only $80$ metres of fence. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/01d00c8e-3868-4639-a655-8216a79b9c4e/images/70cc4897-882c-489b-9551-58f6c2e26bb3/580f23d360211ad7dd2c45e79d30c7d9c7d24f56.svg) - Write down the equation for the total length of the fence, $80$ m, in terms of $x$ and $y$. [1] - Write down the total area of both parcels of land in terms of $x$. [2] - Find the maximum area, in m$^2$, of one parcel of land. [3]
markScheme:
- $\answer{80 = 3x + 4y}$
- The total area of both parcels of land in terms of $x$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8em} A(x) &= x(2y) \\[18pt]
  &= 2xy \\[11pt]
  &= 2x\left(\dfrac{80 - 3x}{4}\right) \hspace{3em} [\text{from part (a)}] \\[7pt]
  &\answer{= 40x - \dfrac{3}{2}x^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = A(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/01d00c8e-3868-4639-a655-8216a79b9c4e/images/c3f7d568-52ea-4325-b521-9c031fcf4810/d34855549a850484b1041b3153951956e33882fa.svg)


  Hence the maximum area of one parcel of land is
$\dfrac{266.67}{2} \approx$
$\answer{133 \text{ m}^2}$

title: Question 16
content:
The equation $x^2 + (k-3)x - 3k = 0$ has two distinct real solutions.
Find the possible values of $k$.
markScheme:
Since the quadratic function $q(x) = x^2 + (k-3)x - 3k$ has two distinct
real roots, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.9em} [\text{discriminant of $q$}] &> 0 \\[6pt]
(k-3)^2 - 4(1)(-3k) &> 0 \hspace{3em} [\triangle  = b^2 - 4ac]  \\[6pt]
(k^2 - 6k + 9) + 12k &> 0 \\[6pt]
k^2 + 6k + 9 &> 0 \\[6pt]
(k + 3)^2 &> 0 \\[7pt]
|k + 3| &> 0 \hspace{3em}{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

From the inequality $(1)$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{3.7em} k + 3 < 0 \hspace{0.525em}&\text{ or }\hspace{0.525em} k + 3 > 0 \\[6pt]
k < \hspace{-0.1em} -3 \hspace{0.525em}&\text{ or }\hspace{0.525em} k > -3   \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence the set of possible values of $k$ is
$\answer{k\in\mathbb{R}\,;\,k\neq-3}$

title: Question 19
content: Let $f(x) = -6x^2 + bx + c$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$, where $b, c \in \mathbb{Z}$. - A horizontal line, $L$, intersects the graph of $y = f(x)$ at $(-1,h)$ and $(5,h)$, where $h \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find the equation of the axis of symmetry of the graph of $y = f(x)$. - Hence show that $b = 24$. [4] - Given $h=-8$, find the value of $c$. [3]
markScheme:
- 
  - The equation of the axis of symmetry is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    x &= \dfrac{-1 + 5}{2} \hspace{0.2em} \\[12pt]
    &\hspace{-0.5em}\answer{x= 2} \end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the axis of symmetry formula, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    x &= -\dfrac{b}{2a} \\[12pt]
    \hspace{10em} 2 &= -\dfrac{b}{2(-6)} \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)(i)}] \\[12pt]
    & \hspace{-0.5em} \answer{b = 24} \end{aligned}
    $$


- Since the line $L$ intersects the graph of $y = f(x)$ at $(-1,-8)$,
we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(-1) &= -8  \\[12pt]
  -6(-1)^2 + 24(-1) + c &= -8 \\[12pt]
  -6 - 24 + c &= -8 \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-0.45em} \answer{c = 22}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 21
content:
The quadratic equation $x^2 - kx + (k-1) = 0$ has roots $\alpha$ and
$\beta$. Without solving the equation, find the possible values of the
real number $k$ given that $\alpha^2 + \beta^2 = 17$.
markScheme:
Using Vieta's formulas, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha+\beta &=-\dfrac{a_1}{a_2} \\[4pt]
&= -\dfrac{(-k)}{1} \\[12pt]
&= k\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2.9em} \alpha\beta &= (-1)^2\bigg[\dfrac{a_0}{a_2}\bigg] \\[4pt]
&= \dfrac{k-1}{1} \\[12pt]
&= k-1\end{aligned}
$$

Hence we get

$$
\begin{aligned}(\alpha + \beta)^2  &= k^2 \\[6pt]\hspace{5.8em} \alpha^2 + \beta^2 + 2\alpha\beta &= k^2 \\[6pt]17 + 2(k - 1)  &=  k^2 \hspace{3em} [\text{since } \alpha^2 + \beta^2 = 17] \\[6pt]2k + 15  &=  k^2 \\[6pt]0 &= k^2 - 2k - 15 \\[7pt]0 &= (k+3)(k-5)\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{1.4em} \answer{k = -3,\hspace{0.25em}5}
$$

title: Question 28
content:
The line $y = x + 1$ touches the graph of the function
$g(x) = 2x^2 + kx + 3$ at one point. Find the possible values of $k$.
markScheme:
Letting $g(x) = y$ we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
2x^2 + kx + 3 &= x + 1   \\[10pt]
2x^2 + (k-1)x + 2 &= 0 \\[10pt]
[\hspace{0.1em}\text{discriminant of quadratic above}\hspace{0.1em}] &= 0 \\[10pt]
(k-1)^2 - 4(2)(2) &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\triangle  = b^2 - 4ac] \\[10pt]
k^2 - 2k + 1 - 16 &= 0 \\[10pt]
k^2 - 2k - 15 &= 0 \\[10pt]
(k - 5)(k + 3) &= 0 \\[10pt]
&\hspace{-0.5em} \answer{k = -3, \, 5}\end{aligned}
$$

title: Question 40
content: The arithmetic sequence has the sixth term of $u_6=\ln{2}$ and the eighth term of $u_8=\frac{3}{2}\ln{4}$. - - Show the common difference is $\ln2$. - Find $u_1$. - Hence, show that the sum of $n$ terms is given by $S_n=\left(n^2-9n\right)\ln {\sqrt{2}} $. Where $n \in \mathbb{Z^+}$. [5] A new function, $f(x)$, is formed using $S_n$ with the discrete variable $n$ being replaced with the continuous variable $x$, such that $x \in \mathbb{R}$. Hence $f(x)=\left(x^2-9x\right)\ln {\sqrt{2}}$. - - Write down the equation of the axis of symmetry of $f(x)$. - Sketch $f(x)$ on the grid below, identify the axis of symmetry and any axis intercepts. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b47a175-7f1f-4e12-9580-54726bb82f90/images/5f674790-b5af-473c-b8d4-3f746b96c744/q1037.png) - Hence or otherwise, find the minimum value of $S_n$ in the form $a\ln b$. Where $a,b \in \mathbb{Z}$ [5] Consider the linear function $g(x)=(6-3x)\ln {\sqrt 2}$. - - Solve $f(x)=g(x)$. - Hence, solve the inequality $f(x)[5]
markScheme:
- 
  - As the sequence is arithmetic we can write $u_8=u_6+2d$. Hence

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        \tfrac{3}{2}\ln{4}&=\ln{2}+2d \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\\
        2d&=3\ln{(\sqrt{4})}-\ln2\\
        2d&=2\ln{2}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]
        &=\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{\ln2}\hspace{2.525em} \text{...as required} \tag*{\textbf{AG}}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - We can use $u_6$ to find the first term

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        u_6&=u_1+5d\\
        \ln2&=u_1+5\ln2\\
        u_1&=\hspace{0.525em}\answer{-4\ln2} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - Using the sum of $n$ terms of an arithmetic sequence we can write

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        S_n&=\frac{n}{2}\left(2\times -4 \ln2 +(n-1)\times \ln2\right) \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\\
        &=\frac{n^2}{2}\ln2-\frac{9n}{2}\ln2\\
        &=\frac{\ln2}{2}\left(n^2-9n\right) \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]
        &=\hspace{0.525em}\answer{\left(n^2-9n\right)\ln{\sqrt{2}}} \hspace{2.525em} \text{...as required} \tag*{\textbf{AG}}
    \end{align*}
    $$


- 
  - Using the axis of symmetry formula, we can write

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        x&=-\frac{-9\ln{\sqrt{2}}}{2\ln{\sqrt{2}}}\\
        &\hspace{-0.525em}\answer{x=\tfrac{9}{2}} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - Here is the sketch of $f(x)$ with the desired features identified.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b47a175-7f1f-4e12-9580-54726bb82f90/images/ff26f159-934a-404d-946c-88a7dab4de40/a1037-1.png)


    $\answer{\text{Correct intercepts}}$ A1 and $\answer{\text{axis of symmetry}}$ A1.
  - Using the symmetry of $f(x)$ we can identify the minimum value(s) of $f(x)$ which has integer $x$ coordinates.
    Both points are equidistant from the axis of symmetry and they represent the minimum value of $S_n$.

    $$
    \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}
    $$

    $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b47a175-7f1f-4e12-9580-54726bb82f90/images/b53d4797-3cc2-48db-9678-27e521c1ec16/a1037-2.png)


    We can use the $x-$value from the graph to pick either $n=4$ or $n=5$ as both will yield the same minimum value. This solution will pick $n=4$, hence, the minimum value of $S_n$ is

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        S_4&=\left(4^2-9(4)\right)\frac{\ln2}{2}\\
        &=-20\frac{\ln2}{2}\\[6pt]
        &=\hspace{0.525em}\answer{-10\ln2} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\
    \end{align*}
    $$


- 
  - Equate the RHS of each function

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        \left(x^2-9x\right)\ln {\sqrt 2}&=(6-3x)\ln {\sqrt 2}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Cancel out the factor $\ln {\sqrt 2}$ and solve for $x$

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        x^2-9x&=6-3x\tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\\
        0&=x^2-6x-6
    \end{align*}
    $$

    We can solve this by completing the square.

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        (x-3)^2-9-6&=0\\
        x-3&=\pm\sqrt{15}\\
        x&=\hspace{0.525em}\answer{3\pm\sqrt{15}} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}   
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - By making a rough sketch of $g(x)$ on the graph we can solve the inequality\
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b47a175-7f1f-4e12-9580-54726bb82f90/images/e5de3f5e-73f3-4a69-a581-b579611281ae/a1037-3.png)


    We can identify the region the $f(x)<g(x)$. Hence

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        &\hspace{0.525em}\answer{3-\sqrt{15}<x<3+\sqrt{15}} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - $n$ must be a positive integer and lie entirely within the region identified in part (c)(ii).
    We know that $\sqrt{9}<\sqrt{15}<\sqrt{16}$, hence we can identify the minimum and maximum values of $n$.

    $$
    \tag*{\textbf{M1}}
    $$

    $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
    The minimum value must be an integer larger than $3-\sqrt{15}$.

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        -1<3-\sqrt{15}<0
    \end{align*}
    $$

    The minimum value of $n$ is $1$.
    Similarly, the maximum value must be an integer smaller than $3+\sqrt{15}$.

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        6<3+\sqrt{15}<7
    \end{align*}
    $$

    The maximum value of $n$ is $6$.
    Hence
$\answer{1\leq n\leq 6}$.

    $$
    \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    $$

    $\textcolor{white}{gap}$

title: Question 41
content: The quadratic function $f(x)$ has a vertex at $(h, -2)$. - The function can be written in the form of $f(x) = a(x-h)^2+k$. - If the equation of the axis of symmetry of $f(x)$ is $x=3$, write down the values of $h$ and $k$. - If the $y-$intercept of $f(x)$ is $-11$, find $a$. [4] A new function $g(x)$ is defined such that $g'(x)=f(x)$. - - Show that the function $f(x)$ has no real roots. - Hence, or otherwise, justify that $g(x)$ is a decreasing function. [3] The function $f(x)$ is vertically translated such that it now has $2$ distinct roots, $x_1$ and $x_2$, where $x_2>x_1$. The coordinates of the new vertex is $(3, m)$. Where $m>0$. - Show that $x_1=3- \sqrt{m}$ and $x_2=3+ \sqrt{m}$. [2] The area enclosed by $f(x)$ and the $x-$axis is $\frac{32}{3}$ units. - - Use the substitution $u=x-3$ to find $\displaystyle\int f(x)\,\,\mathrm{d}x$ in terms of $m$. - Hence find $m$. [6] - Hence, or otherwise, find the region(s) of $x$, for which $g(x)$ is a decreasing function. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - Written in vertex form the point $(h, k)$ is the location of the vertex, additionally, the vertex lies on the axis of symmetry.
    Hence $\hspace{0.525em}\answer{h=3}\hspace{0.525em}$ and $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{k=-2}\hspace{0.525em}$

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        \tag*{\textbf{A1A1}}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - From the question we are told $f(0)=-11$, hence

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        -11&=a(0-3)^2-2  \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\\[6pt]
        -9&=9a\\[6pt]
        &\hspace{-0.525em}\answer{a=-1}\hspace{0.525em}  \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    \end{align*}
    $$


- 
  - We can use the discriminant to show that $f(x)$ has no real roots.
    But first, we need to expand and simplify $f(x)$ into the general form.

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        f(x)&=-(x-3)^2-2\\[6pt]
        &=-(x^2-6x+9)-2\\[6pt]
        &=-x^2+6x-11
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Now using the coefficients $a, b$ and $c$ we can find the value of the discriminant

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        \triangle &= b^2-4ac  \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\\[6pt]
        &= (6)^2-4(-1)(-11)\\[6pt]
        &=36-44\\[6pt]
        &=-8
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence $\hspace{0.525em}\answer{f(x) \text{ has no real roots as } \triangle < 0}$.

    $$
    \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    $$

    $\textcolor{white}{gap}$
  - As $f(x)$ has no real roots and $a<0$ we can say that $f(x)$ is entirely below the $x-$axis.
    Here is a sketch to help visualise the function
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/79d0d534-041e-400d-b3ee-04705d11f2ca/images/84e2b57f-708a-480f-b6a5-37f847987a10/a1036-1.png)


    As $g'(x)=f(x)$, $\answer{\text{the gradient of } g(x) \text{ is always negative}}$ making $g(x)$ a decreasing function.

    $$
    \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    $$

    $\textcolor{white}{gap}$

- After the translation we can write $f(x)=-(x-3)^2+m$.
  Here is a new sketch of $f(x)$ with the new features identified.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/79d0d534-041e-400d-b3ee-04705d11f2ca/images/0d9d5b7b-4c0b-4e7d-8962-733845ae917c/a1036-2.png)


  The roots are found by solving $f(x)=0$

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      0&=-(x-3)^2+m \tag*{\textbf{M1}}\\[6pt]
      (x-3)^2&=m\\[6pt]
      x-3&=\pm \sqrt{m}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\[6pt]
      &\hspace{-0.525em}\answer{x_1=3 - \sqrt{m} \text{ and } x_2=3 + \sqrt{m}}\hspace{0.525em} \hspace{3em} \text{...as required} \tag*{\textbf{AG}}        
  \end{align*}
  $$

- 
  - Using the substitution $u=x-3$ we find that $\frac{du}{\mathrm{d}x}=1$, hence $\mathrm{d}u=\mathrm{d}x$.

    $$
    \begin{align*}
       \int f(x)\,\,\mathrm{d}x&= \int \left(-(x-3)^2+m\right)\,\,\mathrm{d}x \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\\[6pt]
       &=\int \left(-u^2+m\right)\,\,\mathrm{d}u\\[6pt]
       &=-\frac{1}{3}u^3+mu+c\\[6pt]
       &=\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{-\frac{1}{3}(x-3)^3+m(x-3)+c} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    \end{align*}
    $$

  - We are told that the area enclosed by $f(x)$ and the $x-$axis is $\frac{32}{3}$ we can visualise this, with the shaded area below being equal to $\dfrac{32}{3}$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/79d0d534-041e-400d-b3ee-04705d11f2ca/images/8a7ef13e-9784-41e5-80fa-0b5f132b451d/a1036-3.png)


hence

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        \int_{x_1}^{x_2}f(x)\,\,\mathrm{d}x&=\frac{32}{3} \\[6pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

Using the integral we found in part (i) and the roots we find in part (c) we can write

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        \left[-\frac{1}{3}(x-3)^3+m(x-3)\right]_{3-\sqrt{m}}^{3+\sqrt{m}}&=\dfrac{32}{3} \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}
    \end{align*}
    $$

Note, we do not need to include the constant of integration $c$, as this is a definite integral.\[6pt]
Next we can substitute in the limits of integration, simplify and then solve for $m$.

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        -\frac{1}{3}(3+\sqrt{m}-3)^3+m(3+\sqrt{m}-3) -&\\[6pt]
        \left(-\frac{1}{3}(3-\sqrt{m}-3)^3+m(3-\sqrt{m}-3)\right) &=\frac{32}{3}\\[6pt]
        -\frac{1}{3}(\sqrt{m})^3+m\sqrt{m}-\left(-\frac{1}{3}(-\sqrt{m})^3-m\sqrt{m}\right)&=\frac{32}{3} \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\\[6pt]
        -\frac{2}{3}(\sqrt{m})^3+2m\sqrt{m}&=\frac{32}{3}\\[6pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

Rewrite the radicals into index form

    $$
    \begin{align*}
        -\frac{2}{3}m^{\frac{3}{2}}+2m^{\frac{3}{2}}&=\frac{32}{3} \tag*{\textbf{(A1)}}\\[6pt]
        -2m^{\frac{3}{2}}+6m^{\frac{3}{2}}&=32\\[6pt]
        4m^{\frac{3}{2}}&=32\\[6pt]
        m^{\frac{3}{2}}&=8\\[6pt]
        m&=8^{\frac{2}{3}}\\[6pt]
        &\hspace{-0.525em}\tcbhighmath{m=4} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
    \end{align*}
    $$


- Using the answer from part (c) and (d)(ii) we know that

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      x_1&=3-\sqrt{4}\\
      &=1
  \end{align*}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      x_2&=3+\sqrt{4}\\
      &=5 \tag*{\textbf{(A1)}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  $g(x)$ is a decreasing function when the value of its gradient is negative.
  Here is a sketch of $f(x)$ with the roots identified
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/79d0d534-041e-400d-b3ee-04705d11f2ca/images/6ad573a4-0b86-4fee-89e3-237fceca483a/a1036-4.png)


  As $g'(x)=f(x)$  and $f(x)$ is negative to the left of $x_1$ and to the right of $x_2$, then $g(x)$ is a decreasing function for

  $$
  \begin{align*}
       \hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{x<1}\hspace{0.525em} \text{ and } \hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{x>5}\hspace{0.525em} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

title: Question 44
content: Consider the quadratic polynomial $p(x)=2kx^2 + 15kx + 3k + 6$, where $k\in\mathbb{R}$. - Find an expression for the product of the roots of $p(x)$ in terms of $k$. [1] - Find the values of $k$ for which $p(x)$ has two distinct negative real roots. [5]
markScheme:
- Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the two roots of $p(x)$. The product of the roots of a polynomial is given by
  $\dfrac{(-1)^na_0}{a_n}$
  In this case we have $n=2$, $a_0=3k+6$ and $a_n=2k$. Therefore

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \alpha\beta &= \dfrac{(-1)^2(3k+6)}{2k} \\[10pt]
  &\hspace{-1.2em}\tcbhighmath{\alpha\beta = \dfrac{3k+6}{2k}} 
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Using the quadratic formula, we can find an expression for the roots of the polynomial:

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  x &= \dfrac{-15k \pm \sqrt{(15k)^2 - 4(2k)(3k+6)}}{4k} \\[10pt]
  &= \dfrac{-15}{4} \pm \dfrac{\sqrt{201k^2 - 48k}}{4k}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  This implies that there must be at least one negative root, and it is therefore not possible to have two positive roots.
  If the product of the roots is positive, then the polynomial will have two negative roots.
  Using G.D.C. to plot $\alpha\beta$ as a function of $k$, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fb00108c-b3ff-42f3-aeed-bd72cebd43f7/images/8029e1d2-dfda-41d0-8f32-2a8f0cdb3a70/AA932a.PNG)


  Hence, we can see that the product $\alpha\beta$ is greater than zero when $k<-2$ and when $k>0$. Therefore, for values of $k$ in these intervals, the polynomial has two negative roots.
  For both roots to be distinct and real, the discriminant must be greater than zero. We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  b^2 - 4ac &> 0 \\[10pt]
  201k^2 - 48k &> 0 \\[10pt]
  k(201k - 48) &> 0 \\[10pt]
  k &<0 \text{ , } k > \dfrac{48}{201}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  For the roots to be distinct, real, and both negative, we must have $k<-2$ or $k>\dfrac{48}{201}$.
  Hence, $p(x)$ has two distinct negative real roots for $\answer{k<-2 \text{ and } k>\dfrac{48}{201}}$

title: Question 6
content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{3x-6}{x+1}$, for $x\neq-1$. - For the graph of $y = f(x)$, find the coordinates of: - the $x$-intercept; - the $y$-intercept. [3] - For the graph of $y = f(x)$, find the equation of: - the horizontal asymptote; - the vertical asymptote. [3] - Hence sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \dfrac{3x-6}{x+1} &= 0 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
    3x-6 &= 0 \\[10pt]
    x &= 2\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept
are  $\answer{(2,0)}$

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4.8em} y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{3(0)-6}{0+1} \\[6pt]
    &= -6\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $y$-intercept
are  $\answer{(0,-6)}$

- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \lim_{x \rightarrow \pm \infty} f(x) &= \dfrac{3}{1} \hspace{2.5em} \\[6pt]
    &= 3\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the horizontal
asymptote is
$\answer{y = 3}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    &= 0 \hspace{6em} \\[6pt]
    x+1 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &= -1\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the vertical
asymptote is
$\answer{x = -1}$

- Hence, if we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, we have

title: Question 7
content: The function $f$ is given by $f(x) = \dfrac{4x^2 - 128}{x^2 - 16}$, for $x \neq \pm 4$. - Prove that $f$ is an even function. [2] - - Sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. - Write down the range of $f$. [5]
markScheme:
- For any $x \in \mathbb{R}$, $x \neq \pm 4$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(-x) &= \dfrac{4(-x)^2 - 128}{(-x)^2 - 16} \\[5pt]
  &= \dfrac{4x^2 - 128}{x^2 - 16} \\[12pt]
  &= f(x)\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence $f$ is an even function.
- 
  - If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we
have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b4b2579c-edb3-474f-9012-eba8d8995131/images/99bd6e4e-6a5d-4072-8d6f-a53d9d744a19/6c198522156a50253fdb14e877863a1523046369.svg)


  - $\answer{(-\infty,4) \cup [8,\infty)}$

title: Question 8
content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{3x+4}{2x-5}$, for $x\neq\dfrac{5}{2}$. - For the graph of $y = f(x)$, find the coordinates of: - the $x$-intercept; - the $y$-intercept. [3] - For the graph of $y = f(x)$, find the equation of: - the horizontal asymptote; - the vertical asymptote. [3] - Hence sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. [2] - Find $f^{-1}(x)$. [3] The graphs of $f(x)$ and $f^{-1}(x)$ have two points of intersection. - Find the coordinates of the two points of intersection. Give your answers to two decimal places. [3] - Hence find the equation of the perpendicular bisector to the two points of intersection. [3]
markScheme:
- 
  - Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \dfrac{3x+4}{2x-5} &= 0 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
    3x+4 &= 0 \\[10pt]
    x &= -\dfrac{4}{3}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are $\answer{\left(-\dfrac{4}{3},0\right)}$
  - Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{3(0)+4}{2(0)-5} \\[6pt]
    &= -\dfrac{4}{5}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $y$-intercept are $\answer{\left(0,-\dfrac{4}{5}\right)}$

- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \lim_{x \rightarrow \pm \infty} f(x) &= \dfrac{3}{2} \hspace{2.5em} \\[6pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the horizontal asymptote is $\answer{y = \dfrac{3}{2}}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    [\text{denominator of $f$}] &= 0 \hspace{6em} \\[6pt]
    2x-5 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &= \dfrac{5}{2}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the vertical asymptote is $\answer{x = \dfrac{5}{2}}$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9bb89137-6a40-482f-8a89-a20425dad3b5/images/61d6ea19-c9b6-4e43-b863-25670815218d/aa1013a.PNG)


- We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  y &= \dfrac{3x+4}{2x-5} \hspace{5.5em} \left[\text{where } y = f(x)\right]
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Therefore

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  x &= \dfrac{3y+4}{2y-5} \hspace{3em} \left[\text{where } y = f^{-1}(x)\right] \\[8pt]
  x(2y-5) &= 3y+4 \\[8pt]
  2xy - 5x &= 3y +4 \\[8pt]
  2xy - 3y &= 5x + 4 \\[8pt]
  y(2x - 3) &= 5x + 4 \\[8pt]
  y &= \dfrac{5x+4}{2x-3} \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-3em}\tcbhighmath{f^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{5x+4}{2x-3}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Sketching $f(x)$ and $f^{-1}(x)$ on the same axes, we can find the points of intersection using the G.D.C.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9bb89137-6a40-482f-8a89-a20425dad3b5/images/897ceffb-d901-4e38-a2bb-f444d24cc122/aa1013b.PNG)


- The midpoint of AB is given by

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \left(\dfrac{x_1+x_2}{2} , \dfrac{y_1+y_2}{2}\right) &= \left(\dfrac{-0.45+4.45}{2} , \dfrac{-0.45+4.45}{2}\right) \\[8pt]
  &= (2,2)
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Point A and point B both lie on the line $y=x$, which has gradient $m=1$. Therefore the perpendicular bisector has gradient $m=-1$.
  The equation of the perpendicular bisector is given by

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[8pt]
  y - 2 &= -(x - 2) \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-0.525em}\tcbhighmath{y = -x + 4}
  \end{align*}
  $$

title: Question 3
content: Jeremy invests $\$8000$ into a savings account that pays an annual interest rate of $5.5$ %, compounded annually. - Write down a formula which calculates that total value of the investment after $n$ years. [2] - Calculate the amount of money in the savings account after: - $1$ year; - $3$ years. [2] - Jeremy wants to use the money to put down a $\$10\hspace{0.15em}000$ deposit on an apartment. Determine if Jeremy will be able to do this within a $5$-year timeframe.[2]
markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3d389660-6876-4d8b-af36-e47d89674806/images/768ccb37-8949-43dc-bc2a-9cc617ef40d9/eaedd006beb5ba238d9ad76a3a6f6101e049be71.svg)


  Hence, using the compound interest formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{FV} &= \mathrm{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} \\[5pt]
  &= 8000\bigg(1 + \dfrac{5.5}{100\times1}\bigg)^{1\times n} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 8000\hspace{0.05em}(1+0.055)^n} \hspace{3em}{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - Substituting $n = 1$ in the formula $(1)$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \mathrm{FV} &= 8000\hspace{0.05em}(1+0.055) \hspace{0.5em} \\[8pt]
    &\answer{= \$8440}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Substituting $n = 3$ in the formula $(1)$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \mathrm{FV} &= 8000\hspace{0.05em}(1+0.055)^3 \\[8pt]
    &=9393.9...\\[8pt]
    &\answer{\approx \$9390}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Substituting $n = 5$ in the formula $(1)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.2em} \mathrm{FV} &= 8000\hspace{0.05em}(1+0.055)^5 \\[8pt]
  &\approx \$10\hspace{0.15em}456\end{aligned}
  $$

  $\answer{\text{Yes, Jeremy will be able to do this within a \(5\)-year timeframe.}}$

title: Question 5
content: Only one of the following four sequences is arithmetic and only one of them is geometric. $$ \begin{array}{rcccccl} a_n &=& 1,\,5,\,10,\,15,\,\dots &\,\hspace{4em}\,& c_n &=& 1.5,\,3,\,4.5,\,6,\,\dots \\[12pt] b_n &=& \dfrac{1}{2},\,\dfrac{2}{3},\,\dfrac{3}{4},\,\dfrac{4}{5},\,\dots &\,\hspace{4em}\,& d_n &=& 2,\,1,\,\dfrac{1}{2},\,\dfrac{1}{4},\,\dots \end{array} $$ - State which sequence is arithmetic and find the common difference of the sequence. [2] - State which sequence is geometric and find the common ratio of the sequence.[2] - For the geometric sequence find the exact value of the eighth term. Give your answer as a fraction. [2]
markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  
  \begin{array}{rclc|crcl}
  a_2-a_1 &\neq& a_3-a_2 &\,\hspace{0.5em}\,&\,\hspace{0.5em}\,& c_2-c_1 &=& c_3-c_2 \\[12pt]
  5-1 &\neq& 10-5 &&& 3-1.5 &=& 4.5-3 \\[12pt]
  4 &\neq& 5 &&& 1.5 &=& 1.5 \\[12pt] \hline
  &&&&&&& \\
  b_2-b_1 &\neq& b_3-b_2 &&& d_2-d_1 &\neq& d_3-d_2 \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{2}{3}-\dfrac{1}{2} &\neq& \dfrac{3}{4}-\dfrac{2}{3} &&& 1-2 &\neq& \dfrac{1}{2}-1 \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{1}{6} &\neq& \dfrac{1}{12} &&& -1 &\neq& -\dfrac{1}{2}
  \end{array} \vspace{0.95em}
  $$

  Hence
$\answer{c_n}$
is arithmetic and
$\answer{d = 1.5}$
- We have

  $$
  
  \begin{array}{rclc|crcl}
  \dfrac{a_2}{a_1} &\neq& \dfrac{a_3}{a_2} &\,\hspace{0.5em}\,&\,\hspace{0.5em}\,& \dfrac{c_2}{c_1} &\neq& \dfrac{c_3}{c_2} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{5}{1} &\neq& \dfrac{10}{5} &&& \dfrac{3}{1.5} &\neq& \dfrac{4.5}{3} \\[12pt]
  5 &\neq& 2 &&& 2 &\neq& 1.5 \\[12pt] \hline
  &&&&&&& \\
  \dfrac{b_2}{b_1} &\neq& \dfrac{b_3}{b_2} &&& \dfrac{d_2}{d_1} &=& \dfrac{d_3}{d_2} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{2/3}{1/2} &\neq& \dfrac{3/4}{2/3} &&& \dfrac{1}{2} &=& \dfrac{1/2}{1} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{4}{3} &\neq& \dfrac{9}{8} &&& \dfrac{1}{2} &=& \dfrac{1}{2}
  \end{array} \vspace{0.95em}
  $$

  Hence
$\answer{d_n}$
is geometric and
$\answer{r = \dfrac{1}{2}}$
- Using the $n$th term formula $d_n = d_1r^{n-1}$ with $n = 8$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  d_8 &= d_1r^{8-1} \\[8pt]
  &= 2\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^{8-1} \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{1}{64}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 7
content: Consider an arithmetic sequence $2,6,10,14,\dots$ - Find the common difference, $d$. [2] - Find the $10$th term in the sequence. [2] - Find the sum of the first $10$ terms in the sequence. [2]
markScheme:
- We have $u_1 = 2$ and $u_2 = 6$.
Hence the common difference is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  d &= u_2 - u_1 \hspace{1.5em} \\[6pt]
  &= 6 - 2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 4}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1 + (n-1)d$ with $n = 10$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.8em} u_{10} &= u_1 + (10-1)d \\[6pt]
  &= 2 + (10-1)(4) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 38} \end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula $S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(u_1 + u_n)$
with $n=10$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_{10} &= \dfrac{10}{2}(u_1 + u_{10}) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{10}{2}(2 + 38) \\[11pt]
  &\answer{= 200} \end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 8
content: The fifth term, $u_5$, of a geometric sequence is $125$. The sixth term, $u_6$, is $156.25$. - Find the common ratio of the sequence. [2] - Find $u_1$, the first term of the sequence. [2] - Calculate the sum of the first $12$ terms of the sequence. [2]
markScheme:
- The common ratio is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  r &= \dfrac{u_6}{u_5} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{156.25}{125} \\[11pt]
  &\answer{= 1.25} \hspace{3.2em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_5r^{n-5}$ with $n = 1$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_1 &= u_5r^{1-5} \\[6pt]
  &= 125(1.25)^{1-5} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 51.2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula $S_n = \dfrac{u_1(r^n-1)}{r-1}$
with $n = 12$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} S_{12} &= \dfrac{u_1(r^{12}-1)}{r-1} \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{51.2((1.25)^{12}-1)}{1.25-1} \\[12pt]
  &=2775.4...\\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 2780}\hspace{3em}\text{rounded to 3 s.f.}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 10
content: Consider the infinite geometric sequence $9000$, $-7200$, $5760$, $-4608$, ... - Find the common ratio. [2] - Find the $25$th term. [2] - Find the exact sum of the infinite sequence. [2]
markScheme:
- We have $u_1 = 9000$ and $u_2 = -7200$.
Hence the common ratio is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[8pt]
  &= -\dfrac{7200}{9000} \hspace{2.9em} \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= -\dfrac{4}{5}} \end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with $n = 25$, we
find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_{25} &= u_1r^{25-1} \\[6pt]
  &= 9000\left(\hspace{-0.2em}-\dfrac{4}{5}\right)^{25-1} \\[8pt]
  &\answer{\approx 42.5}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_{\infty} &= \dfrac{9000}{1-(-4/5)} \hspace{1.9em} \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= 5000}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 12
content: A $3$D printer builds a set of $49$ Ei$\text{f}$fel Tower Replicas in different sizes. The height of the largest tower in this set is $64$ cm. The heights of successive smaller towers are $95$ % of the preceding larger tower, as shown in the diagram below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7c098710-c58c-4ef5-87d5-1552e9027719/images/e2ae24d8-0743-4825-b529-687c2f726965/AA724a.PNG) - Find the height of the smallest tower in this set. [3] - Find the total height if all $49$ towers were placed one on top of another. [3]
markScheme:
- We have a geometric sequence with the first term $u_1 = 64$ and the
common ratio $r = 0.95$.
  Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with $n=49$,
we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_{49} &= u_1r^{49-1} \\[6pt]
  &= 64(0.95)^{49-1} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{\approx 5.46 \text{ cm}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula $S_n = \dfrac{u_1(1-r^n)}{1-r}$
with $n=49$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.9em} S_{49} &= \dfrac{u_1(1-r^{49})}{1-r} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{64\hspace{0.05em}(1-0.95^{49})}{1-0.95} \\[12pt]
  &\approx 1176.33 \\[16pt] 
  &\answer{\approx 1180 \text{ cm}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 16
content: The fifth term, $u_5$, of an arithmetic sequence is $25$. The eleventh term, $u_{11}$, of the same sequence is $49$. - Find $d$, the common difference of the sequence. [2] - Find $u_1$, the first term of the sequence. [2] - Find $S_{100}$, the sum of the first $100$ terms of the sequence. [2]
markScheme:
- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_5 + (n-5)d$ with $n=11$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_{11} &= u_5 + (11-5)d \\[6pt]
  49 &= 25 + (11-5)d\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{5.8em}\answer{d = 4} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_5 + (n-5)d$ with $n=1$, we
find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.7em} u_1 &= u_5 + (1-5)d \\[6pt]
  &= 25 + (1-5)(4) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 9}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula $S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1+(n-1)d)$
with $n = 100$,
  we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.1em} S_{100} &= \dfrac{100}{2}(2u_1+(100-1)d) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{100}{2}(2(9)+(100-1)(4)) \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= 20\hspace{0.15em}700}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 18
content: The third term, $u_3$, of an arithmetic sequence is $7$. The common difference of the sequence, $d$, is $3$. - Find $u_1$, the first term of the sequence. [2] - Find $u_{60}$, the $60$th term of sequence. [2] The first and fourth terms of this arithmetic sequence are the first two terms of a geometric sequence. - Calculate the sixth term of the geometric sequence. [2]
markScheme:
- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_3 + (n-3)d$ with $n = 1$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_1 &= u_3 + (1-3)d \hspace{0.4em} \\[6pt]
  &= 7 + (1-3)(3) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 1}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_3 + (n-3)d$ with $n = 60$, we
find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_{60} &= u_3 + (60-3)d \\[6pt]
  &= 7 + (60-3)(3) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 178}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f2cc8beb-38d8-4fd2-b2a9-e3169e681425/images/54fb2a07-05e7-4685-b5f7-e496ff597450/ad62ab3f954984b454acd9a772d836d707c86a2f.svg)


  Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with $n = 6$,
we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_6 &= u_1r^{6-1} \\[6pt]
  &= 1(10)^{6-1} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{\approx 100\hspace{0.15em}000} \hspace{3em}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 21
content: Consider the following sequence of figures. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/02c0ba8c-31f6-4ac2-be07-11a5cc2d5804/images/4cf394f8-a1d5-4b83-86b2-cc2e25134ee1/AA008.PNG) Figure 1 contains $6$ line segments. - Given that Figure $n$ contains $101$ line segments, show that $n = 20$.[3] - Find the total number of line segments in the first $20$ figures. [3]
markScheme:
- We have an arithmetic sequence with $u_1 = 6$, $u_2 = 11$ and
$u_3 = 16$.
  The common difference is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  d &= u_2 - u_1 \\[6pt]
  &= 11 - 6 \\[6pt]
  &= 5\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, if we substitute $u_n = 101$, $u_1 = 6$
and $d = 5$ in $u_n = u_1 + (n-1)d$ and solve the resulting equation
for $n$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.9em} 101 &= 6 + (n-1)(5) \\[6pt]
  101 &= 5n+1 \\[6pt]
  100 &= 5n\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{n = 20}\hspace{2.3em}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula $S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(u_1 + u_n)$
with $n=20$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.5em} S_{20} &= \dfrac{20}{2}(u_1 + u_{20}) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{20}{2}(6 + 101) \\[12pt]
  &= 10(107) \\[16pt]
  &\answer{= 1070}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 23
content: In this question give all answers correct to the nearest whole number. A population of goats on an island starts at $232$. The population is expected to increase by $15$ % each year. - Find the expected population size after: - $10$ years; - $20$ years. [4] - Find the number of years it will take for the population to reach $15\hspace{0.15em}000$. [2]
markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1d40d8e7-1cb0-4476-8de2-71edeb3bc4c3/images/506a639a-3110-402d-8a30-3b43c6e52d46/537894a1e06c34454736a91f01647c46ca2f4fa3.svg)


  Hence the population size is expected to increase according to a
geometric sequence with the first term $u_1 = 232(1.15)$ and the
common ratio $r = 1.15$.
  
  - Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with $n = 10$,
we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.1em} u_{10} &= u_1r^{10-1} \\[6pt]
    &= [232(1.15)](1.15)^{10-1} \\[7pt]
    &\answer{\approx 939}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with $n = 20$,
we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.1em} u_{20} &= u_1r^{20-1} \\[6pt]
    &= [232(1.15)](1.15)^{20-1} \\[7pt]
    &\answer{\approx 3797}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Solving the equation $u_n = 15\hspace{0.15em}000$ for $n$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_1r^{n-1} &= 15\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[6pt]
  \hspace{1.5em} [232(1.15)](1.15)^{n-1} &= 15\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[7pt]
  n &\approx 29.8 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence it will take
$\answer{30 \text{ years}}$
for the population of goats to reach $15\hspace{0.15em}000$.

title: Question 25
content: In an arithmetic sequence, $u_5 = 24$, $u_{13} = 80$. - Find the common difference. [2] - Find the first term. [2] - Find the sum of the first $20$ terms in the sequence. [2]
markScheme:
- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_5 + (n-5)d$ with $n = 13$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_{13} &= u_5 + (13-5)d \\[6pt]
  80 &= 24 + (13-5)d \hspace{1.5em} \\[6pt]
  56 &= 8d\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{d = 7} \hspace{6.35em}
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_5 + (n-5)d$ with $n = 1$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_1 &= u_5 + (1-5)d \\[6pt]
  &= 24 + (1-5)(7) \hspace{0.9em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -4}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with
$n=20$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.7em} S_{20} &= \dfrac{20}{2}(2u_1 + (20-1)d) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{20}{2}(2(-4) + (20-1)(7)) \\[11pt]
  &\answer{= 1250}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 27

  Hence, using the compound interest formula, we get

title: Question 30
content: The first three terms of a geometric sequence are $u_1 = 32$, $u_2 = -16$, $u_3 = 8$. - Find the value of the common ratio, $r$. [2] - Find $u_6$. [2] - Find $S_{\infty}$. [2]
markScheme:
- The value of $r$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{16}{32} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -\dfrac{1}{2}} \hspace{3.6em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1 r^{n-1}$ with $n = 6$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_6 &= u_1 r^{6-1} \\[8pt]
  &= 32\bigg(\hspace{-0.3em} -\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)^{6-1} \\[4pt]
  &= 32\bigg(\hspace{-0.3em}-\dfrac{1}{32}\bigg) \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= -1}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.405em} S_{\infty} &= \dfrac{32}{1-(-1/2)} \hspace{5.45em} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{32}{3/2} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{64}{3}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 33
content: The Australian Koala Foundation estimates that there are about $45\hspace{0.15em}000$ koalas left in the wild in $2019$. A year before, in $2018$, the population of koalas was estimated as $50\hspace{0.15em}000$. Assuming the population of koalas continues to decrease by the same percentage each year, find: - the exact population of koalas in $2022$; [3] - the number of years it will take for the koala population to reduce to half of its number in $2018$. [3]
markScheme:
- We have a geometric sequence with

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2018:\hspace{0.5em} u_1 &= 50\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[6pt]
  2019:\hspace{0.5em} u_2 &= 45\hspace{0.15em}000\end{aligned}
  $$

  The
common ratio of the sequence is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.1em} r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{45\hspace{0.15em}000}{50\hspace{0.15em}000} \\[12pt]
  &= 0.9\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with $n = 5$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.5em} 2022:\hspace{0.5em} u_5 &= u_1r^{5-1} \\[6pt]
  &= 50\hspace{0.15em}000(0.9)^{5-1} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{= 32\hspace{0.15em}805}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $u_n = 25\hspace{0.15em}000$ for $n$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_1r^{n-1} &= 25\hspace{0.15em}000 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
  50\hspace{0.15em}000(0.9)^{n-1} &= 25\hspace{0.15em}000\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{13.5em} n \approx 7.58 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\[2pt]
  $$

  Because our starting year, 2018, is considered to be year 1 ($n=1$), it will take 6.58 years from then for the population to halve from $50\,000$ to $25\,000$.
  Hence it will take
$\answer{6.58 \text{ years}}$
for the koala population to reduce to half of its number in $2018$.

title: Question 38
content: Landmarks are placed along the road from London to Edinburgh and the distance between each landmark is $16.1$ km. The first landmark placed on the road is $124.7$ km from London, and the last landmark is near Edinburgh. The length of the road from London to Edinburgh is $667.1$ km. - Find the distance between the fifth landmark and London. [3] - Determine how many landmarks there are along the road. [3]
markScheme:
- We have an arithmetic sequence with $u_1 = 124.7$ and $d = 16.1$.
Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1 + (n-1)d$ with
$n = 5$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.6em} u_5 &= u_1 + (5-1)d \\[6pt]
  &= 124.7 + (5-1)(16.1) \\[6pt]
  &= 189\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the distance between the fifth
landmark and London is
$\answer{189\hspace{0.25em}\text{km}}$
- If we solve the inequality $u_n < 667.1$ for the largest value of
$n$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_1 + (n-1)d &< 667.1 \\[6pt]
  124.7 + (n-1)(16.1) &< 667.1 \\[6pt]
  n &< 34.7 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \hspace{1em} \\[6pt]
  n &= 34 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence there are
$\answer{34}$
landmarks along the road.

title: Question 41
content: Peter is playing on a swing during a school lunch break. The height of the first swing was $2$ m and every subsequent swing was $84$ % of the previous one. Peter's friend, Ronald, gives him a push whenever the height falls below $1$ m. - Find the height of the third swing. [2] - Find the number of swings before Ronald gives Peter a push. [2] - Calculate the total height of swings if Peter is left to swing until coming to rest. [2]
markScheme:
- We have a geometric sequence with the first term $u_1 = 2$ and the
common ratio $r = 0.84$.
  Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with $n = 3$,
we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_3 &= u_1r^{3-1} \\[6pt]
  &= 2\hspace{0.05em}(0.84)^{3-1} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{\approx 1.41 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the inequality $u_n < 1$ for $n$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_1r^{n-1} &< 1 \\[6pt]
  \hspace{3em} 2\hspace{0.05em}(0.84)^{n-1} &< 1 \\[7pt]
  4.98 &< n \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence
the swing needs a push after
$\answer{5}$
swings.
- Using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_{\infty} &= \dfrac{2}{1-0.84} \hspace{1.3em} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 12.5 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 42
content: On $1$st of January $2022$, Grace invests $\$P$ in an account that pays a nominal annual interest rate of $6$ %, compounded quarterly. title: Question 44
content: Consider the sum $\displaystyle S = \sum_{k = 4}^l (2k-3)$, where $l$ is a positive integer greater than $4$. - Write down the first three terms of the series. [2] - Write down the number of terms in the series. [1] - Given that $S = 725$, find the value of $l$. [3]
markScheme:
- $\answer{5,\, 7,\, 9}$
- $\answer{l-3}$
- From part (a), we have an arithmetic sequence with the first term
$u_1 = 5$ and the common difference $d = 2$.
  Hence, using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with $n = l-3$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S &= S_{l-3} \\[11pt]
  \hspace{4.5em}725 &= \bigg[\dfrac{l-3}{2}\bigg](2u_1 + ((l-3)-1)d) \\[6pt]
  725 &= \bigg[\dfrac{l-3}{2}\bigg](2(5) + (l-4)(2)) \\[6pt]
  725 &= \bigg[\dfrac{l-3}{2}\bigg](2 + 2l) \\[12pt]
  725 &= (l-3)(l+1) \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{4.65em} \answer{l = 28} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

title: Question 51
content:
The sum of the first three terms of a geometric sequence is $92.5$, and
the sum of the infinite sequence is $160$. Find the common ratio.
markScheme:
We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
S_3 &= 92.5 \hspace{4.8em} \\[6pt]
\dfrac{u_1(1-r^3)}{1-r} &= 92.5 \end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
S_{\infty} &= 160 \\[6pt]
\dfrac{u_1}{1-r} &= 160 \\[5pt]
u_1 &= 160(1-r)\end{aligned}
$$

Hence we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{u_1(1-r^3)}{1-r} &= 92.5 \hspace{8.5em} \\[6pt]
\dfrac{160(1-r)(1-r^3)}{1-r} &= 92.5 \hspace{8.5em} \\[12pt]
160(1-r^3) &= 92.5 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{9.3em} \answer{r = 0.75} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]

title: Question 57
content: The first three terms of a geometric sequence are $\ln x^9$, $\ln x^3$, $\ln x$, for $x > 0$. - Find the common ratio. [3] - Hence, solve $\displaystyle \sum_{k=1}^\infty 3^{3-k}\ln x = 27$. [5]
markScheme:
- We have $u_1 = 9\ln x$ and $u_2 = 3\ln x$.
Hence the common ratio is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{3\ln x}{9\ln x} \hspace{2.9em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{1}{3}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The $n$th term of the geometric sequence is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_n &= u_1r^{n-1} \\[6pt]
  &= 9\ln x\bigg(\dfrac{1}{3}\bigg)^{n-1} \\[8pt]
  &= 3^{3-n}\ln x\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_{\infty} &= \sum_{k=1}^\infty 3^{3-k}\ln x \hspace{1em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $S_{\infty} = 27$ for $x$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{u_1}{1-r} &= 27 \hspace{2.8em} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{9\ln x}{1 - 1/3} &= 27 \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{27\ln x}{3-1} &= 27 \\[12pt]
  \ln x &= 2 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{x = e^2}
  $$

Determine the value of n. [4] - Julie chooses a different bank and invests her $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$ in a savings account that offers an interest rate of $r\%$ per annum compounded monthly, where $r$ is set to two decimal places. Find the minimum value of $r$ needed for Julie to reach her goal after $10$ years. [3] - Xavier also wants to reach a savings goal of $\$30 \hspace{0.15em}000$. He doesn't trust his local bank so he decides to initially put his money into a safety deposit box where it does not earn any interest. His system is to add more money into the safety deposit box at the end of each year. At the end of each year he will add one third of the amount he added at the end of the previous year. - Show that Xavier will never reach his goal if his initial deposit into the safety deposit box is $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$. - Find the amount Xavier needs to initially deposit in order to reach his goal after $7$ years. Give your answer to the nearest dollar. [7]
markScheme:
- 
  - We have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/671b8958-56db-4c0f-b590-8354ee308bad/images/3bafd562-49e3-4def-9fe7-1b7fdc0f4b02/9dbbca0f5e685431fe27e5f6d20cddfa41909806.svg)


    Hence, using the compound interest formula, we have

  - We have

    Hence, using the compound interest formula, we have

    \hspace{3em} \mathrm{FV} &= \mathrm{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} \\[5pt]

    &\hspace{-0.525em}\answer{n = 13} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]

- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/671b8958-56db-4c0f-b590-8354ee308bad/images/2643f5e1-9380-40ff-988f-9c71b044704d/990e9181ddb4f41f6ff2aaf08aa718b7d5031131.svg)


  Hence, using the compound interest formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} \mathrm{FV} &= \mathrm{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} \\[5pt]
  30\hspace{0.15em}000 &= 16\hspace{0.15em}000\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100\times12}\bigg)^{12\times 10} \\[6pt]

  - The total amount of money in Xavier's safe after an infinite
number of years is expressed by

    $$

    \end{aligned}

the first term $u_1 = 16\hspace{0.15em}000$ and the common ratio
