title: Question 61
content: A bouncy ball is dropped from a height of $2$ metres onto a concrete floor. After hitting the floor, the ball rebounds back up to $80$ % of it's previous height, and this pattern continues on repeatedly, until coming to rest. - Show that the total distance travelled by the ball until coming to rest can be expressed by $2 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + 4(0.8)^3 + \cdots$[2] - Find an expression for the total distance travelled by the ball, in terms of the number of bounces, $n$. [2] - Find the total distance travelled by the ball. [2]
markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6c7dc2e3-7a08-4b87-96d6-7b2cab2e19ca/images/e45216f3-e445-40d8-b304-c2b6ab4f424b/866fc824efe482d8b182d4c5b9e109a2fdbd4aca.svg)


  Hence the total distance travelled by the ball until coming to rest
is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{2 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + 4(0.8)^3 + \cdots}\qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- First we manipulate the equation slightly


$$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2em} [\text{sum of $n$ terms of $(1)$}] &= 2 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + \cdots + 4(0.8)^{n-1} \\[14pt]
    &= \textcolor{blue}{-2 + 2} +\big[2 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + \cdots + 4(0.8)^{n-1}\big] \hspace{1.3em} \\[8pt]
    &= -2 + \big[4 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + \cdots + 4(0.8)^{n-1}\big] \hspace{1.3em} \\[8pt]
    &= -2 + \textcolor{red}{\big[u_1 + u_2 + u_3 + \cdots + u_{n}\big]} \hspace{1.3em} \\[8pt]
    \end{aligned}
$$

Now we can see this is the sum of a geometric sequence  to $n$ terms with $u_1 = 4$ and $r = 0.8$
Using the formula $S_n = \dfrac{u_1(1 - r^n)}{1-r}$ for the sum of $n$ terms of a geometric sequence we get

$$
    \begin{aligned}
    &= -2 + \bigg[\dfrac{4(1 - 0.8^{n})}{1 - 0.8}\bigg] \\[8pt]
    &= -2 + 20(1 - 0.8^{n}) \\[8pt]
    &= -2 + 20 - 20(0.8^n)\\[12pt]
    &\answer{= 18 - 20(0.8)^n}
    \end{aligned}
$$


- Using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$ with
  $u_1 = 4$ and $r = 0.8$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &= 2 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + 4(0.8)^3 + \cdots \\[14pt]
  &= -2 + \big[4 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + 4(0.8)^3 + \cdots\big] \\[8pt]
  &= -2 + \bigg[\dfrac{4}{1 - 0.8}\bigg] \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= 18 \text{ metres}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 64
content: Grant wants to save $\$40\hspace{0.15em}000$ over 5 years to help his son pay for his college tuition. He deposits $\$20\hspace{0.15em}000$ into a savings account that has an interest rate of $6\%$ per annum compounded monthly for $5$ years. - Show that Grant will not be able to reach his target. [2] - Find the minimum amount, to the nearest dollar, that Grant would need to deposit initially for him to reach his target. [3] Grant only has $\$20\hspace{0.15em}000$ to invest, so he asks his sister, Caroline, to help him accelerate the saving process. Caroline is happy to help and offers to contribute part of her income each year. Her annual income is $\$37 \hspace{0.15em}500$ per year. She starts by contributing one fifth of her annual income, and then decreases her contributions by half each year until the target is reached. Caroline's contributions do not yield any interest. - Show that Grant and Caroline together can reach the target in 5 years. [4] Grant and Caroline agree that Caroline should stop contributing once she contributes enough to complement the deficit of Grant's investment. - Find the whole number of years after which Caroline will stop contributing. [4]
markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b11dd291-1f8d-4420-97c1-327f5c8e98e0/images/99bf13a8-6e7b-42c8-a483-4544968211ec/64fb25df045f9e0b7a416f15dde7a9fce22438d5.svg)


  Hence, using the compound interest formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} \mathrm{FV} &= \mathrm{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} \\[5pt]
  &= 20\hspace{0.15em}000\bigg(1 + \dfrac{6}{100\times12}\bigg)^{12\times 5} \\[8pt]
  &\approx \$26\hspace{0.15em}977\end{aligned}
  $$

  Therfore, Grant
will not reach his target as the value of his investment after $5$
years is $\$26\hspace{0.15em}977$ which is less than his
$\$40\hspace{0.15em}000$ goal.
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b11dd291-1f8d-4420-97c1-327f5c8e98e0/images/d899604b-6ef3-4746-bea4-5206a555afa3/aaeeec80128922b9372aa176b0353a0a146271f3.svg)


  Hence, using the compound interest formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} \mathrm{FV} &= \mathrm{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} \\[5pt]
  \hspace{4.25em} 40\hspace{0.15em}000 &= \mathrm{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{6}{100\times12}\bigg)^{12\times 5} \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-1.5em}\answer{\mathrm{PV} \approx \$29\hspace{0.15em}655} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- The amount that Caroline contributes in the first year is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{P} &= \dfrac{1}{5}(37\hspace{0.15em}500) \\[6pt]
  &= \$7\hspace{0.15em}500\end{aligned}
  $$

  The total
amount that Caroline contributes after $5$ years is expressed by

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  A &= 7500 + 7500\left( \dfrac 1 2 \right) + 7500\left( \dfrac 1 2 \right)^2 +  + \dots + 7500\left( \dfrac 1 2 \right)^{4} 
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  We have a geometric series with the first term
$u_1 = 7500$ and $r = \dfrac{1}{2}$.
  Hence, using the formula $S_n = \dfrac{u_1(r^n - 1)}{r - 1}$ with
$\text{\(n = 5\)}$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{A} &= S_{5} \\[8pt]
  \hspace{2.75em} &= 7\hspace{0.15em}500\bigg[\dfrac{\left( \frac 1 2 \right)^5 - 1}{\frac{1}{2} - 1}\bigg] \\[12pt]
  &\approx \$14\hspace{0.15em}531 
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore, the total amount that Grant and Caroline can save in $5$
years is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.5em} \text{Total amount} &\approx 26\hspace{0.15em}977 + 14\hspace{0.15em}531 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.35em}\answer{ \approx \$41\hspace{0.15em}508}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, Grant and Caroline together can reach the target as the total
amount saved exceeds the target of $\$40\hspace{0.15em}000$.
- The amount Caroline must contribute to help Grant reach the target
is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.75em} C &= 40\hspace{0.15em}000 - 26\hspace{0.15em}977 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[6pt]
  &= \$13\hspace{0.15em}023\end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  7500 + 7500\left( \dfrac 1 2 \right) + 7500\left( \dfrac 1 2 \right)^2 +  \dots \hspace{1em} &> 13\hspace{0.15em}023\end{aligned}
  $$

  We have a geometric series with the first term $u_1 = 7500$ and
$r = \dfrac{1}{2}$.
  Hence, using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{u_1(r^n - 1)}{r - 1}$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  7500\bigg[\dfrac{\left( \frac 1 2 \right)^n - 1}{\frac{1}{2} - 1}\bigg]\hspace{0.2em} &> 13\hspace{0.15em}023 \\[12pt]
  n &> 2.92358 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, Caroline will stop contributing after
$\answer{3\hspace{0.3em} \text{years}}$

title: Question 66
content: It is known that the number of trees in a small forest will decrease by $5$ % each year unless some new trees are planted. At the end of each year, $600$ new trees are planted to the forest. At the start of $2021$, there are $8200$ trees in the forest. - Show that there will be roughly $9060$ trees in the forest at the start of $2026$. [4] - Find the approximate number of trees in the forest at the start of $2041$. [4]
markScheme:
- The number of trees in the forest at the start of $2022$ will be

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{T}_1 &= 8200\times0.95 + 600 \hspace{2.8em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  The number of trees in the forest at the start of $2023$ will be

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.65em} \mathrm{T}_2 &= \mathrm{T}_1\times0.95 + 600 \\[7pt]
  &= \left(8200\times0.95 + 600\right)0.95 + 600 \\[6pt]
  &= 8200\times0.95^2 + 600(0.95 + 1)\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the number
of trees in the forest at the start of $2026$ will be

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{T}_5 &= 8200\times0.95^5 + 600\hspace{0.05em}(0.95^4 + 0.95^3 + 0.95^2 + 0.95 + 1) \\[8pt]
  &\answer{\approx 9060}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The approximate number of trees in the forest at the start of $2041$
will be

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{T}_{20} &= 8200\times0.95^{20} + 600\bigg[\sum_{k=0}^{19}0.95^k\bigg] \\[2pt]
  &= 8200\times0.95^{20} + 600\bigg[\dfrac{1 - 0.95^{20}}{1 - 0.95}\bigg] \\[12pt]
  &\answer{\approx 10\hspace{0.15em}638}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 70
content: The first two terms of an infinite geometric sequence, in order, are $$ 3\log_3x,\,\, 2\log_3x,\,\, \text{where $x > 0$.} $$ - Find the common ratio, $r$. [2] - Show that the sum of the infinite sequence is $9\log_3 x$. [3] The first three terms of an arithmetic sequence, in order, are $$ \log_3x,\,\, \log_3 \dfrac{x}{3},\,\, \log_3\dfrac{x}{9},\,\, \text{where $x > 0$.} $$ - Find the common difference $d$, giving your answer as an integer. [3] Let $S_6$ be the sum of the first $6$ terms of the arithmetic sequence. - Show that $S_6 = 6\log_3 x - 15$. [3] - Given that $S_6$ is equal to one third of the sum of the infinite geometric sequence, find $x$, giving your answer in the form $a^p$ where $a,p \in \mathbb{Z}$. [3]
markScheme:
- The common ratio is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{2\log_3 x}{3\log_3 x} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{2}{3}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_{\infty} &= \dfrac{3\log_3x}{1 - 2/3} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{3\log_3x}{1/3} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 9\log_3x} \hspace{5em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the properties of logarithms, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.9em} d &= u_2 - u_1 \\[6pt]
  &= \log_3 \dfrac{x}{3} - \log_3x \\[6pt]
  &= (\cancel{\log_3x} - \log_33) - \cancel{\log_3x} \hspace{0.5em} \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= -1}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with
$n=6$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.8em} S_6 &= \dfrac{6}{2}(2u_1 + (6-1)d) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{6}{2}(2(\log_3 x) + (6-1)(-1)) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{6}{2}(2\log_3 x - 5) \\[11pt]
  &\answer{= 6\log_3 x - 15}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we solve the equation $S_6 = \dfrac{1}{3}S_{\infty}$ for $x$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  6\log_3 x - 15 &= \dfrac{1}{3}(9\log_3x) \hspace{3.6em} \\[8pt]
  6\log_3 x - 15 &= 3\log_3x \\[12pt]
  3\log_3x &= 15 \\[12pt]
  \log_3x &= 5 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{x = 3^5} \hspace{2.5em}
  $$

title: Question 71
content: Given a sequence of integers, between $20$ and $300$, which are divisible by $9$. - Find their sum. [2] - Express this sum using sigma notation. [2] An arithmetic sequence has first term $-500$ and common difference of $8$. The sum of the first $n$ terms of this sequence is negative. - Find the greatest value of $n$. [2]
markScheme:
- We have an arithmetic sequence $27,\, 36,\, 45,\,\dots,\, 297$ with
$u_1 = 27$ and $d = 9$.
  The number of terms in the sequence is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.8em} n &= \floor*{\dfrac{300}{9}} - 2 \\[6pt]
  & = 31\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(u_1 + u_n)$ with $n = 31$, $u_1 = 27$ and
$u_n = 297$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} S_{31} &= \dfrac{31}{2}(27 + 297) \\[5pt]
  &\answer{= 5022}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Alternatively,
using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with $n = 31$, $u_1 = 27$ and
$d = 9$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.6em} S_{31} &= \dfrac{31}{2}(2(27) + (31-1)(9)) \\[5pt]
  &\answer{= 5022}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Since $u_1 = 27$, $d = 9$ and $n = 31$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} S_{31}  &= 27 + (27 + 9) + (27 + 2\cdot9) + \cdots + (27 + 30\cdot9) \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= \displaystyle{\sum_{n = 1}^{31}} (27 + (n-1)(9))} \\[5pt]
  &\hspace{0.3em}\text{or} \\[5pt]
  &\answer{= \displaystyle{\sum_{n = 1}^{31}} 9(n+2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with $u_1 = -500$ and $d = 8$,
we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_n &< 0 \\[6pt]
  \hspace{4em} \dfrac{n}{2}(2(-500) + (n-1)(8)) &< 0 \\[6pt]
  n(-500 + (n-1)(4)) &< 0 \\[8pt]
  n &< 126 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence
the greatest value of $n$ is
$\answer{125}$

title: Question 73
content: Alex and Ben are playing a game with a spinner. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d53e81ee-2e98-435d-b647-8093ca28ed96/images/1c126bd7-bbe0-4764-8c02-02e9c68e288a/AA1170_q1%20(2).JPEG) The triangular shaped spinner has three equal sized regions with two regions labelled LOSE and one labelled WIN. In turn $1$ Alex spins the spinner first. If she lands on WIN then the game ends and Alex has won in turn $1$. If she lands on LOSE then Ben spins. If he lands on WIN then the game ends and Ben has won in turn $1$. If they both land on LOSE then the game continues into turn $2$. The same process repeats until someone lands on WIN. Alex always spins first for each new turn. Let the turn that the game ends be the discrete random variable $T$. Where $T=1,2,3,4,...$. - Show that the probability that Alex wins and $T=2$ is $\displaystyle\frac{4}{27}$. [2] - Hence complete the missing values in the first four columns of the probability distribution for $T$ when Alex wins. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d53e81ee-2e98-435d-b647-8093ca28ed96/images/0534e4df-9229-45ce-89b9-38f75ac0db9d/AA1170_table.JPEG) [2] - Show that when Alex wins the values of $\text{P}(T=t)$ form a geometric sequence. [2] - Justify that as $T \rightarrow \infty$ the sequence has a sum. [1] - Hence show that the probability Alex wins the game is $\displaystyle\frac{3}{5}$. [2] - Alex and Ben play the same game 10 times. The discrete random variable $W$ is the number of times Alex wins. - Determine the probability that $W$ is within one standard deviation of the mean. - Determine the probability that $W$ is larger than $\mathrm{E}(W)$ given $W$ is within one standard deviation of the mean. [7] Alex and Ben want to keep playing the same game with only one change. They decide to create a new heptagonal spinner. The spinner has $7$ equally sized regions. Each region must be labelled either WIN or LOSE. They want to label the spinner such that the probability of Alex winning the game is $\frac{7}{10}$. - How many of the regions should be labeled WIN? You must justify your answer. [5]

title: Question 76
content: This question asks you to explore the sequence defined by $$ u_n=\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}(\alpha^n-\beta^n) $$ where $\alpha$ and $\beta$ are the roots of the quadratic equation $x^2-4x+1=0, \, \alpha > \beta$ and $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. - Find the value of $\alpha$ and the value of $\beta$. Give your answers in the form $a \pm \sqrt{b}$, where $a,b \in \mathbb{Z^+}$.[3] - Hence find the values of $u_1$ and $u_2$. [4] - Show that $\alpha^2 = 4\alpha -1$ and $\beta^2 = 4\beta - 1$. [1] - Hence show that $u_{n+2} = 4u_{n+1}-u_n$.[4] - Suppose that $u_n$ and $u_{n+1}$ are integers. Show that $u_{n+2}$ is also an integer.[2] - Hence show that $u_n$ is an integer for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.[2] Now consider the sequence defined by $$ v_n = \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^n + \beta^n\right). $$ - Find the exact values of $v_1$ and $v_2$.[4] - Express $v_{n+2}$ in terms of $v_{n+1}$ and $v_n$.[4] - Hence show that $v_n$ is a multiple of $\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$ for all $n \in \mathbb{Z^+}$.[4]
markScheme:
- Completing the square for $x^2-4x+1=0$ we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  (x-2)^2-3&=0 \\[8pt]
  (x-2)^2 &= 3 \\[8pt]
  x - 2 &= \pm\sqrt{3} \\[8pt]
  x &= 2 \pm\sqrt{3}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Given that $\alpha > \beta$, we have $\answer{\alpha = 2 + \sqrt{3} \text{ and } \beta = 2 - \sqrt{3}}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  u_1 &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha - \beta\right) \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(2 + \sqrt{3} - \left(2 - \sqrt{3}\right)\right) \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-1.3em}\tcbhighmath{u_1 = 1} \hspace{3em}\text{[By using G.D.C.]}\\[8pt]
  u_2 &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^2 - \beta^2\right) \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\left(2 + \sqrt{3}\right)^2 - \left(2 - \sqrt{3}\right)^2\right) \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-1.3em}\tcbhighmath{u_2 = 4} \hspace{3em}\text{[By using G.D.C.]}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Given that $\alpha$ is a root of the quadratic equation, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \alpha^2 - 4\alpha + 1 &= 0 \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-1.3em}\tcbhighmath{\alpha^2 = 4\alpha -1}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Similarly

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \beta^2 - 4\beta + 1 &= 0 \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-1.3em}\tcbhighmath{\beta^2 = 4\beta -1}\\[-1cm]
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Using the expressions from part (c), we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  u_{n+2} &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n+2}-\beta^{n+2}\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n}\alpha^2-\beta^{n}\beta^2\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n}(4\alpha - 1)-\beta^{n}(4\beta - 1)\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(4\alpha^{n+1}-\alpha^n - 4\beta^{n+1}+\beta^n\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(4\left(\alpha^{n+1}-\beta^{n+1}\right)-\left(\alpha^n-\beta^n\right)\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{4\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n+1}-\beta^{n+1}\right)-\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}(\alpha^n - \beta^n) \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-2.25em}\tcbhighmath{u_{n+2} = 4u_{n+1}-u_n}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Using the results from part (d), we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  u_n \text{ and } u_{n+1} &\text{ are integers} \\[12pt]
  -u_n \text{ and } 4u_{n+1} &\text{ are integers} \\[12pt] 
  4u_{n+1}-u_n &\text{ is an integer} \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-0.845cm}\tcbhighmath{u_{n+2} \text{ is an integer}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Using part (e), we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  u_1 &= 1 \text{ is an integer (by part (b))} \\[12pt]
  u_2 &= 4 \text{ is an integer (by part (b))}\\[12pt] 
  u_3 & \text{ is an integer (by part (e))} \\
  & \enskip \vdots & \\[3pt]
  u_n & \text{ is an integer (by part (e))} \\[-9pt]
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Hence,$\hspace{0.525em} we conclude that u_n is an integer for all n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$.$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  v_1 &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha + \beta\right) \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(2 + \sqrt{3} + 2 - \sqrt{3}\right) \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-1em}\tcbhighmath{v_1 = \dfrac{2\sqrt{3}}{3}} \\[8pt]
  v_2 &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^2 + \beta^2\right) \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\left(2 + \sqrt{3}\right)^2 + \left(2 - \sqrt{3}\right)^2\right) \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(4 + 4\sqrt{3} + 3 + 4 -4\sqrt{3} + 3\right)\\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-1em}\tcbhighmath{v_2 = \dfrac{7\sqrt{3}}{3}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- By a procedure similar to part (d), we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  v_{n+2} &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n+2}+\beta^{n+2}\right) \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n}\alpha^2+\beta^{n}\beta^2\right) \\[8pt]
  \end{align*}
  $$

  From part (c) we have $\alpha^2=4\alpha-1$ and $\beta^2=\beta-1$.

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  v_{n+2} &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n}(4\alpha - 1)+\beta^{n}(4\beta - 1)\right) \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(4\alpha^{n+1}-\alpha^n + 4\beta^{n+1}-\beta^n\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(4\left(\alpha^{n+1}+\beta^{n+1}\right)-\left(\alpha^n+\beta^n\right)\right) \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{4\sqrt{3}}{6}\left(\alpha^{n+1}+\beta^{n+1}\right)-\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{6}(\alpha^n + \beta^n) \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-2.05em}\tcbhighmath{v_{n+2}= 4v_{n+1}-v_n}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- First suppose that $v_n$ and $v_{n+1}$ are both multiples of $\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$. Let $v_n=\dfrac{p\sqrt{3}}{3}$ and $v_{n+1}=\dfrac{q\sqrt{3}}{3}$ where $p,q \in \mathbb{Z}$. Using the result from part (h), we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  v_{n+2} &= \dfrac{4q\sqrt{3}}{3} - \dfrac{p\sqrt{3}}{3} \\[8pt]
  &= (4q-p)\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{3}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  If $v_n$ and $v_{n+1}$ are both multiples of $\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$, then $v_{n+2}$ is also. From part (g) we notice that $v_1$ and $v_2$ are both multiples of $\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{3}$.
  Therefore,$\hspace{0.525em}  v_n \text{is a multiple of } \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{3} \text{ for all } n \in \mathbb{Z}^+ $

title: Question 78
content: The cubic polynomial equation $x^3 + bx^2 + cx + d = 0$ has three roots $x_1, x_2$ and $x_3$. By expanding the product $(x-x_1)(x-x_2)(x-x_3)$, show that - - $b = -(x_1+x_2+x_3)$; - $c = x_1x_2 + x_1x_3 + x_2x_3$; - $d = -x_1x_2x_3$. [3] It is given that $b = -9$ and $c = 45$ for parts (b) and (c) below. - - In the case that the three roots $x_1, x_2$ and $x_3$ form an arithmetic sequence, show that one of the roots is $3$. - Hence determine the value of $d$. [5] - In another case the three roots form a geometric sequence. Determine the value of $d$. [6]
markScheme:
- Given the three roots $x_1$, $x_2$ and $x_3$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x^3 + bx^2 + cx + d &= (x-x_1)(x-x_2)(x-x_3) \\[6pt]
  &= (x^2 -(x_1+x_2)x + x_1x_2)(x-x_3) \\[8pt]
  &= x^3 - (x_1+x_2+x_3)x^2 + (x_1x_2+x_1x_3+x_2x_3)x - x_1x_2x_3\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, comparing the coefficients, we get
  
  - $\answer{b = -(x_1+x_2+x_3)}$
  - $\answer{c = x_1x_2 + x_1x_3 + x_2x_3}$
  - $\answer{d = -x_1x_2x_3}$

- 
  - Letting $\alpha = x_1 + \delta$, where $\delta$ is the common
difference of the arithmetic sequence $x_1$, $x_2$, $x_3$, we
have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.8em} x_1  &=  \alpha - \delta \\[6pt]
    x_2  &=  \alpha \\[6pt]
    x_3  &=  \alpha + \delta\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, using part (a)
(i), we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    x_1 + x_2 + x_3 &= -b \\[6pt]
    (\alpha - \delta) + \alpha + (\alpha + \delta) &= -(-9) \hspace{6em} \\[6pt]
    3\alpha &= 9 \\[6pt]
    \alpha &= 3 \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \answer{x_2 = 3}
    $$

  - Using part (a) (ii), we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    x_1x_2 + x_1x_3 + x_2x_3 &= c \\[6pt]
    (3 - \delta)(3) + (3 - \delta)(3 + \delta) + (3)(3 + \delta) &= 45 \\[6pt]
    27 - \delta^2 &= 45 \\[6pt]
    -\delta^2 &= 18 \\[5pt]
    \delta &= \sqrt{18}\hspace{0.05em}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\hspace{2em}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, using part (a) (iii), we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4em} d &= -x_1x_2x_3 \\[5pt]
    &= -(3-\sqrt{18}\hspace{0.05em}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})(3)(3+\sqrt{18}\hspace{0.05em}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= -81}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Letting $\alpha = x_1$ and $r$ denote the common ratio of the
geometric sequence $x_1, x_2, x_3$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.2em} x_1  &=  \alpha \\[6pt]
  x_2  &=  \alpha r \\[6pt]
  x_3  &=  \alpha r^2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.25em} x_1 + x_2 + x_3 &= -b \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a) (i)}] \\[6pt]
  \alpha + \alpha r + \alpha r^2 &= -(-9) \\[6pt]
  \alpha (1+r+r^2) &= 9 \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x_1x_2 + x_1x_3 + x_2x_3 &= c \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a) (ii)}] \\[6pt]
  \alpha (\alpha r) + \alpha (\alpha r^2) + (\alpha r)(\alpha r^2) &= 45 \\[6pt]
  \alpha^2r(1+r+r^2) &= 45 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Taking the ratio
of the expressions $(1)$ and $(2)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\alpha^2r(\cancel{1+r+r^2})}{\alpha(\cancel{1+r+r^2})} &= \dfrac{45}{9} \hspace{4em} \\[5pt]
  \dfrac{\alpha^2r}{\alpha} &= \dfrac{45}{9} \\[15pt]
  \alpha r &= 5 \qref{(3)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the expression $(3)$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.5em} d &= -x_1x_2x_3 \hspace{3em} [\text{by (a) (iii)}] \\[5pt]
  &= -\alpha (\alpha r)(\alpha r^2) \\[5pt]
  &= -(\alpha r)^3 \\[5pt]
  &= -5^3 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -125}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 2
content:

title: Question 7
content: Consider three planes represented by the following system of equations: $$ \begin{align*} \Pi_1: -2x + ay + 4z &= 2 \\[6pt] \Pi_2: x + by - 2z &= -1 \\[6pt] \Pi_3: 2x - y + cz &= 3 \end{align*} $$ Where $a,b,c \in \mathbb{R}$. - State the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$ for which - The system has infinite solutions. - The system is inconsistent. [7] - In the case where the system has infinite solutions, describe the geometric relationship between the three planes. [2] - In the case where the system is inconsistent, identify one of the geometric relationships that could exist between the three planes. [2]
markScheme:
- If we convert the given system of equations into an augmented matrix, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e8f9c4b4-8442-45bf-8389-6c5abb138ec8/images/3f804c21-6625-4b1d-a6cc-56f4ed650a1e/aa1012a.PNG)


  Hence, using the method of Gaussian Elimination, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e8f9c4b4-8442-45bf-8389-6c5abb138ec8/images/da6543cf-8657-43e1-8040-dec0d15cf8cf/aa1012b.PNG)


  
  - From row 2, if the system has infinite solutions, we must have $a + 2b = 0$.
    This implies that if $a = -2b$, there are infinite solutions to the system.
    However, we also note from row 3, that if $a - 1 = 0$ and $c + 4 = 0$, then the system is inconsistent. In this case we have $a = 1$ and $c = -4$.
    There are infinite solutions to the system if $a = -2b$, $c \in \mathbb{R}$ unless $a=1$, $b=-0.5$ and $c=-4$.
  - As noted in part (i), if $a = 1$ and $c = -4$, the system is inconsistent.
    However, we also note that if $a \neq 1$ and $c = -4$, Gaussian Elimination leads to
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e8f9c4b4-8442-45bf-8389-6c5abb138ec8/images/7cd78d6b-425a-48e9-b2b6-e41b3b6fdb70/aa1021b.png)


    In this case, we can also have an inconsistent system.
    From part (a), if $a = -2b$ then the system is consistent (has infinite solutions), however consider when $a \neq -2b$.
    It follows that $a+2b =k$, where $k \neq 0$, this leads to
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e8f9c4b4-8442-45bf-8389-6c5abb138ec8/images/757dcf45-e7bd-4832-b55b-c311d8f0a8d8/aa1012a2.png)


    Using row 2

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    ky &=0 \\
    \intertext{As $k \neq 0$ then}
    y &= 0 
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Using row 3, this value of $y$ shows an inconsistency as shown below.

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    (a-1)y &=5 \\
    (a-1)\times0 &= 5 \\
    0 &= 5 
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence...
    $\answer{\text{The system is inconsistent if } a = 1 \text{ and } c = -4, b \in \mathbb{R} \text{ or if } a \neq 1, a \neq -2b \text{ and } c = -4.}$

- From (a) (i), we note that $\Pi_1$ is a multiple of $\Pi_2$. They are therefore equations representing the same plane.
  $\answer{\Pi_1 \text{ and } \Pi_2 \text{ are coincidental, }\Pi_3 \text{ intersects both planes in a straight line.}}$
- In total there are 4 different geometric realtionships between the planes when the system is inconsistent.
  First, from part (a) (i) we note that the system is inconsistent if $a=1$, $b=-0.5$ and $c=-4$. In this case,
  $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{\Pi_1 \text{ and } \Pi_2 \text{ are coincidental and } \Pi_3 \text{ is parallel to both planes.}}\hspace{0.525em}$
  Second, from (a) (ii), we have one scenario where $a=1$, $b \neq -0.5$ and $c=-4$. In this case,
  $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{\Pi_1 \text{ and } \Pi_3 \text{ are parallel and } \Pi_2 \text{ intersects both planes.}}\hspace{0.525em}$
  Thirdly, if $a \neq 1$, $b=-0.5$ and $c=-4$,
  $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{\Pi_2 \text{ and } \Pi_3 \text{ are parallel and } \Pi_1 \text{ intersects both planes.}}\hspace{0.525em}$
  Finally, if $a \neq 1$, $a \neq -2b$ and $c=-4$, then $\Pi_1$ intersects $\Pi_2$ on a line, $\Pi_1$ intersects $\Pi_3$ on a different line and $\Pi_2$ intersects $\Pi_3$ on another different line. Additionally,$\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{\text{All three of these lines of intersection are parallel.}}\hspace{0.525em}$

title: Question 4
content: Let $f(t) = 3t^2 + 27$, where $t > 0$. The graph of a function $g$ is obtained when the graph of $f$ is transformed by $$ \begin{aligned} &\text{a stretch by a scale of\hspace{0.05em} $\dfrac{1}{9}$ \hspace{0.05em}parallel to the $y$-axis, followed by} \\ &\text{a horizontal translation of 4 and a vertical translation of -5}\\ \end{aligned} $$ - Find $g(t)$, giving your answer in the form $a(t - b)^2 + c$. [4] A particle moves along a straight line so that its velocity in m s$^{-1}$, at time $t$ seconds, is given by $g(t)$. - Find the distance the particle travels between $t = 7$ and $t = 10$. [3]
markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} g(t) &= \dfrac{1}{9}f(t - 4) - 5  \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1}{9}\big[3(t - 4)^2 + 27\big] - 5 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{1}{3}(t - 4)^2 -2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The distance the particle travels between $t = 7$ and $t = 10$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.8em} \text{distance} &= \int_7^{10} \left|g(t)\right| \mathrm{d}t \\[2pt]
  &= \int_7^{10} \left|\dfrac{1}{3}(t - 4)^2 -2\right| \mathrm{d}t \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= 15 \text{ m}}  \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$
